HEADLINE: Cold Warrior 

BYLINE:  By Leon Aron; Leon Aron, a resident scholar and the director of Russian studies at the American Enterprise Institute, is the author of a biography of Boris Yeltsin.

 BODY:
 KHRUSHCHEV
The Man and His Era.
By William Taubman.
Illustrated. 876 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $35.
 HE was one of Stalin's most trusted henchmen, up to his elbows in blood -- yet he dealt Stalinism, the Soviet system and the world Communist movement a wound from which they would never recover. He brutally crushed the Hungarian revolution -- yet he opened the gates of the gulag for millions, and authorized the publication of Solzhenitsyn's "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich." He built the Berlin Wall and put nuclear-tipped missiles into Cuba -- yet he ordered deep unilateral cuts in Soviet conventional forces and initiated the first detente with the United States. He was crude, dogmatic and merciless; also generous, public-spirited and forgiving.
He was Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev: a top Soviet leader since the mid-1930's, the dominant member of the post-Stalin leadership (1953-57) and the Soviet Union's unchallenged dictator-ruler between 1957 and 1964. Although eminently worthy of a serious biography, Khrushchev until now has been the subject of rather thin Kremlinological exegeses. In "Khrushchev: The Man and His Era," which took almost two decades to research and write, William Taubman, a professor of political science at Amherst College, finally gives us what we (and Khrushchev) deserve: a portrait unlikely to be surpassed any time soon in either richness or complexity. 
Taubman has made use of materials from over two dozen Russian and American archives, of more than 70 personal interviews (including ones with Khrushchev's children, grandchildren, in-laws and other relatives), of published and unpublished memoirs, innumerable newspaper and magazine articles, even Soviet newsreels. The list of published books and articles consulted by the author extends across 13 pages. This volume, with its brisk, enjoyable narrative, succeeds in every sense: sweep, depth, liveliness, color, tempo. Each chapter shines with mastery and authority. 
A conscientious biography of a worthy subject cannot help being a portrait of the times, and Taubman's book fully lives up to the "and his era" of the subtitle. It is a multifaceted study of the key political and economic forces of the first 47 years -- almost two-thirds of the total -- of the Soviet civilization: from the revolution of October 1917, which found the 23-year-old Nikita (with only four years of parochial school) a skilled metalworker in the heart of Russia's coal mining region, to Oct. 13, 1964, when, returning from a Presidium meeting in the Kremlin, he pushed his briefcase into his son's hands and sighed: "It's over. I'm retired." 
In between, as he climbs up the increasingly bloody pole to the pinnacle of Soviet power, we follow Nikita Sergeyevich through virtually all the key events of Soviet history. Some he witnessed, some he helped to shape: the doomed struggle of the anti-Stalin opposition inside the party during the 1920's; the horrors of Stalinist "collectivization"; the Great Purge of 1936-39, when, as a member of tribunals, he sent thousands to torture and death; the wholesale arrests, deportations and executions that he supervised in western Ukraine after Hitler and Stalin divided Poland in 1939; the Kiev and Kharkov disasters during World War II and the Stalingrad triumph, in all of which he played a role as Stalin's political emissary to the armies in the field. 
Khrushchev was one of the three Soviet leaders closest to an increasingly insane and paranoid Stalin during the post-World War II years (the two others were the secret police chief Lavrenty Beria and Deputy Prime Minister Georgy Malenkov). Following the tyrant's death in 1953, he first disposed of the universally feared Beria (who was arrested and shot as a "spy") before proceeding gradually to outmaneuver Malenkov and another top rival, Stalin's foreign minister, Vyacheslav Molotov.
Then came February 1956 and the weightiest of Khrushchev's claims to a place in history (and one of the 20th century's greatest surprises): the "secret speech" to a party congress detailing Stalin's crimes. There were, to be sure, obvious tactical reasons for it: Khrushchev lessened or obscured his own very formidable culpability in the regime's war on the Soviet people, and he also undermined his rivals Molotov and Malenkov, whose complicity in the purges was demonstrably greater than his own. Yet power struggle considerations cannot fully account for Khrushchev's de-Stalinization, especially since he resumed his attack on Stalin in broad daylight at the 1961 party congress, four years after all his competitors had been vanquished. 
Even though he limited his description of Stalin's crimes solely to Communist victims (passing in silence over millions of "class enemies" and other categories), Khrushchev knew how enormous the stakes were. "Stalin personifies the multiple victories of the Soviet people," one Presidium bigwig objected. "Examining possible mistakes . . . will raise doubts about the correctness of our whole course." Another top leader lamented: "If these are facts, can we really call this Communism? This is unforgivable." 
The four-hour speech was listened to by several thousand people in "deathly silence." The shock was palpable. Two weeks later, after he read the speech, Poland's Communist dictator Boleslaw Bierut had a heart attack and died. Within months, workers rose up in Poznan. Then the Hungarian revolution exploded.
Taubman provides a number of explanations, all plausible and helpful, as clues to Khrushchev's de-Stalinizing impulse, but characteristically he respects the reader and refrains from ex cathedra pronouncements. This is as it should be: here was an instance of human mystery of the highest order, of an inextinguishable spark that ignites an irresistible human inclination to choose, albeit often inconsistently and by degrees, good over evil, liberty over slavery, truth over lies. Even decades of brutalization and degradation by so supremely talented an "engineer of human souls" as Stalin proved no match for these imperatives of the human spirit. 
Those who successfully plotted against Khrushchev in October 1964 cited many perfectly valid reasons for his removal: the failures in agriculture, the embarrassment and loss of face caused by his boorish behavior abroad (including the famous shoe-banging episode at the United Nations), the "adventurism" of the Cuban fiasco, the man's rudeness and arrogance. Still, to the neo-Stalinists who would rule the Soviet Union for the next 20 years, Khrushchev's cardinal sin, without doubt, was the secret speech. Summoned six years after his ouster to the Party Control Committee to be berated for publishing his memoirs in the West, a very sick 76-year-old Khrushchev told his accusers: "I too was infected by Stalin, but I also freed myself from him, whereas you did not." As late as 1984, 13 years after his death, Politburo members railed against the "scandalous disgraces" Khrushchev had committed "in relation to Stalin." "He soiled and stained us," one said. "He dealt an irreversible blow to the positive image of the Soviet Union in the eyes of the world," another added.
Even in defeat Khrushchev proved dangerous to them -- perhaps, in the end, more dangerous than ever. For his demise demonstrated to a young and up-and-coming Mikhail Gorbachev, along with his liberal alter ego, Aleksandr Yakovlev, a key lesson of Soviet (and Russian) history: liberalizations from above are subverted by the resistance of functionaries (and the liberalizer-in-chief is inevitably overthrown in a palace coup) unless a project of liberty is protected by an alliance with the Russian people, who, like any other people, thirst for truth, justice, dignity and trust. 
When in power, Gorbachev and Yakovlev pursued that alliance by permitting the intelligentsia to tell people the truth in newspapers, magazines, books and television programs. Indeed, Gorbachev acknowledged his debt to Khrushchev after he became general secretary in 1985 by scheduling the first party congress over which he presided to coincide, 30 years to the day, with Khrushchev's secret speech. There followed the firestorm of glasnost, and within three short years (1988-90) the entire legitimizing mythology of the Soviet party-state went up in smoke, leaving behind a charred empty shell that Boris Yeltsin kicked aside in August 1991.
Khrushchev had a hand in it all, and his life represents a hefty slice of history, admirably served up in this monumental biography, one that is likely to be definitive for years to come. In the end, it is hard to summarize this man better than Taubman does: "complicit in great evil yet also the author of much good." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nikita S. Khrushchev and Fidel Castro on the floor of the United Nations General Assembly, September 1960. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: The Wayward Media 

BYLINE:  By Ted Widmer; Ted Widmer is the director of the C. V. Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience at Washington College in Chestertown, Md.

 BODY:
 WHAT LIBERAL MEDIA?
The Truth About Bias and the News.
By Eric Alterman.
322 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $25.

DEMOCRACY
AND THE NEWS
By Herbert J. Gans.
168 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $26.
 "THE only authors whom I acknowledge as American are the journalists," Alexis de Tocqueville wrote. "They indeed are not great writers," he added with Old European disdain, "but they speak the language of their country and make themselves heard." Of course, merely because Tocqueville said it does not mean that it was true (he also urged remedial instruction in Greek for our underachieving writers). But in this case, our favorite cheese-eating surrender monkey was quite correct in his diagnosis. Journalism is still essential to the health of democracy in America, and two new clinical studies argue that the patient is not faring well.
Eric Alterman and Herbert J. Gans write from very different perspectives. Alterman, the louder of this odd couple, is an outspoken columnist for The Nation and MSNBC.com. As its title implies, "What Liberal Media?" issues a riposte to the notion that a vast left-wing conspiracy controls America's airwaves and newsprint, recently argued in Bernard Goldberg's "Bias" and routinely promoted as gospel on the right. Gans, a mild-mannered Columbia University sociologist, is less concerned with political nuance and more with the declining quality of the information peddled as news. Both have important things to say. 
Alterman is ready for a bar fight, and he comes out swinging. His first targets are Goldberg and Ann Coulter, the acidulous commentator whose mini-skirts and mini-thoughts have ensured her a wide following on the paleolithic end of the political spectrum. Alterman dusts off some of her more outrageous quotations (wishing that Timothy McVeigh had blown up The New York Times, to cite one example), which more or less refute themselves, and then proceeds to the more serious argument that "the right is working the refs" the way loudmouthed coaches do -- to gain whatever tactical advantage they can. 
In fact, Alterman argues, the bias is hard to find. The Times was hardly soft on the Clinton administration, chasing after Whitewater for years, and The Washington Post has been slouching rightward for some time. Talk radio is Death Valley for the left, and the world of television punditry is not much better. Throughout the book, the idea of a liberal reporter seems a faint anachronism -- like the typewriter or Jimmy Olsen's bow tie -- when contrasted to the disciplined nexus of private foundations, talk shows and dirt-seeking oppo men that the right uses to get out its message. Alterman vividly presents this nether world as something out of Dante's "Inferno" -- the trust-funders with deep pockets, like Richard Mellon Scaife; the Internet bottom-feeders who traffic in rumors and half-truths (Matt Drudge); the braying hosts and guests on shows like "The O'Reilly Factor" and "The McLaughlin Group," who never shut their mouths to listen to one another (where's the duct tape when you actually need it?). 
But it's one thing to rant about the right, and it's another to show tangible proof that democracy is being tampered with. This Alterman sets out to do in his two best chapters, detailing the press's dismissive treatment of Al Gore in 2000 and its indifference to the actual counting of the votes in Florida. Alterman suggests persuasively that the press mollycoddled George W. Bush in the months leading to the election. Another interesting revelation is that the Republicans were poised to launch a "massive talk radio operation" to attack the verdict if Gore won the electoral count but lost the popular vote. History turned out differently, as we know, and Gore was excoriated as a sore loser for even questioning the result. By working the refs, the Bush team ended up winning the Super Bowl. 
Alterman is not afraid to name names, and he goes after many of the sacred cows of his profession. David Broder may need smelling salts after reading his portrayal. Chris Matthews is quoted gushing that George Bush proved his leadership quality and fulfilled Hemingway's "very definition of courage" (grace under pressure) by throwing a strike at Yankee Stadium to open Game 3 of the 2001 World Series. On that basis, I would like to nominate Pedro Martinez as secretary general of NATO and Roger Clemens as secretary of agriculture. Tim Russert, on "Meet the Press," asked Laura Bush if her husband had become president because of divine intervention (tactfully, she said no). 
The book appears to have been written quickly, and at times it shows. From a historian's perspective, Alterman could have spent far less time on the minutiae of recent television broadcasts and more on the deeper background of the changes in the media industry over the last two decades. He makes a good case that a narrow federal appeals court decision in 1986 paved the way for the corporate control of radio that now slants the news (the two votes in the 2-1 decision came from Antonin Scalia and Robert Bork). But there is little on the rise of the Internet and the cable industry, the purchase and collapse of local family-owned newspapers around the country (abetted by USA Today), the 1996 Telecommunications Act, the AOL Time Warner merger and other steps toward the dumbing down of political reporting. All have something to do with the story. Nor is there much on the long prehistory of media bashing in this country, from both sides. There's another book's worth of material in the story of our evolution from muckraking to H. L. Mencken to Joe McCarthy, Richard Nixon, Dan Quayle and their successors (on second thought, evolution may not be the right word). To some extent, a book seeking to explain Rush Limbaugh's popularity must explore cultural as well as political factors. And it would be strengthened if it examined liberal shortcomings more forcefully -- why is it that liberals fare badly on live radio and on television? That is a difficult but important question. Still, "What Liberal Media?" is bold, counterintuitive and cathartic. 
"Democracy and the News" is a more modest offering, clocking in at under 170 pages. Gans has enjoyed a long and eminent career, and if his writing is a tad academic, he still radiates decency and common sense. Like Tocqueville, he also brings something of the neutral tone of a foreign observer (he arrived in his early teens as a refugee), and he is refreshingly free of partisan bias. 
But that does not mean Gans is less worried than Alterman. From his more sociological perch, he fears that an economic and political "disempowerment spiral" is removing citizens from meaningful participation in the life of the Republic, endangering democracy by making it "upscale," like so much froth on a caffe latte. He finds a convenient villain in a press that has grown corporate and corpulent, seeking excessive rates of profit, replacing hard news with soft features and blurring the once inviolable division between church (the editorial side) and state (the business end). 
These are all fair critiques. The problem is that Gans, like the rest of us, has no workable idea about what to do next. Yes, if more people voted, we would have truer democracy. Yes, if the press did a better job informing people and helped them to vote for the best candidates, based on real comprehension of the issues, government would improve. And if frogs had wings, they wouldn't bump their bottoms. Near the end of the book, Gans issues a series of cautious recommendations, most of which are quite plausible. He thinks that more of the media costs of running for office should be subsidized by the government. Reporters should make national stories local so that their implications are easier to understand. And journalists should pay more attention to the enormous power of lobbyists in Washington. But despite his good intentions, there is a wistful, elegiac quality to this book that does not translate easily into hard policy recommendations. 
Recent news suggests that the story may soon need updating, however. A group of investors led by venture capitalists from Chicago is seeking parity through the creation of an alternative radio network that tilts left. Predictably, Hollywood talent is being lined up, although that could doom the effort from the start. What would excite Limbaugh more than a long soliloquy on globalization from Barbra Streisand, perhaps set to the tune of "The Way We Were"? Or Harry Belafonte reprising Paul Robeson's classic Chinese Communist ballads? Still, the planning of this network, like the writing of these books, is a sign that democracy is once again recalibrating itself. We can all hope that a genuine debate will ensue.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
A Director Whose Life Could Have Been a Movie

BYLINE:  By DAVID THOMSON; David Thomson's books include "The New Biographical Dictionary of Film" and "Rosebud: The Story of Orson Welles."

 BODY:
THERE was a time when the director Nicholas Ray was the battleground for critical thinking about movies. "Ray or Ray?" asked the London magazine Sight & Sound. They meant Satyajit or Nicholas? -- moral purpose or mere beauty? A deeper question lurked, one we have never solved: is film an art form? Or something far more complicated?
 It seems clear, though, nearly 24 years after his death, that a full life of Nicholas Ray might make a remarkable American portrait -- the moments of glory, the years of chaos; the aching integrity and the corruption; his chronic seductiveness, and the way so many admirers once regarded him as a model of the besieged American film director. Just to list the Ray films taken from him, re-cut without his permission and rendered less than he intended because "they" (the money people) were hostile would make a classic panorama of Hollywood horrors. But then you'd have to recount the ways in which Ray himself betrayed his own ventures. He's the director as auteur and shambles, glory and ruin. You can't have one without the other. And if that difficult diet leaves you less sure that you have a stomach for the movies, so be it. 
 Does this preamble register today? Twenty-four years is time enough for so much forgetting, even if the Museum of Modern Art is doing the best it can to remember. On Thursday it began a monthlong retrospective in which it is showing everything by Ray in the best available prints so that anyone can have a fresh chance on a big screen to encounter one of the most dynamic fillers of the frame that film has ever known. Yes, there are poor scripts, conventional subjects, miscastings, but there is Nick Ray using color, form, movement, music, sound and actors. And it is still intoxicating. To be conservative about it, if you haven't seen "They Live by Night," "In a Lonely Place," "The Lusty Men," "Rebel Without a Cause," "Bigger Than Life" and "Bitter Victory" before, and if you love film, there's nowhere else to be.
If you prefer the romantic approach, here's Jean-Luc Godard: "There was theater (Griffith), poetry (Murnau), painting (Rossellini), dance (Eisenstein), music (Renoir). Henceforth there is cinema. And the cinema is Nicholas Ray."
That cryptic writing on the wall is a short course in film history, based on the notion that these master directors encapsulated the achievement of entire art forms, leaving the imagination clear for the fresh splendor of movies. It's dotty and heady, and it's Godard in 1958, bursting to make his own feature debut and declaring the terms by which he wanted to be judged. And no one ever bothered to establish with Nick Ray himself (increasingly a European figure at that time) whether he agreed or was anywhere near understanding Godard's blazing, austere praise. Probably not, for as Ray drifted into unemployment, exile and illness, he was also staggering toward the state of living disaster that had always threatened. That specter had loomed in the mind of John Houseman, Ray's first producer in Hollywood, the man who helped him get "They Live by Night" done.
Ray was from Wisconsin, born in Galesville, near La Crosse, in 1911. But Nick Ray (his birth name was Raymond Nicholas Kienzle) was a wanderer and drifter and a slow developer. He had worked in theater, after studying architecture with Frank Lloyd Wright. He was also a tall, beautiful guy, ready to fall in love with anyone. As Houseman put it, in his autobiography: 
"Reared in Wisconsin in a household dominated by women, he was a potential homosexual with a deep, passionate and constant need for female love in his life. This made him attractive to women, for whom the chance to save him from his own self-destructive habits proved an irresistible attraction of which Nick took full advantage and for which he rarely forgave them. He left a trail of damaged lives behind him -- not as a seducer, but as a husband, lover and father."
Now, if you say, What has that got to do with art? -- go straight to the screen, and put away the life. Actually, Houseman's brief portrait is model criticism, for it gets at the self-pity that often smothers the burning beauty of Ray's imagery. It shows the cunning melancholy that harped on emotional rescue yet employed it as a trap, and ended up muttering about the fatal impossibility of everything. He was a manipulator, who worked first on himself -- because no one interested him as much.
Consider "Bitter Victory." The Modern has the fullest version of it that anyone will ever likely see (20 minutes longer than the version released in the United States in 1957). It's about two officers in the North African campaign in World War II -- Curt Jurgens and Richard Burton. Jurgens is married to a woman (Ruth Roman) who was once Burton's lover. Jurgens is cold, afraid, officious, calculating; Burton is dreamy, self-destructive, fatalistic. Only one of them comes back from their secret mission.
The film is black and white CinemaScope and vibrant and riveting: the terse action scenes are so economical; the desert is a lesson waiting for Antonioni and Bertolucci; the scene where Burton's character has to attend to the wounded, which ends with him saying, "I save the dead and kill the living," is unbearably moving.
Hardly a frame is lacking grace and danger. And yet -- Jurgens is miscast, Ruth Roman is hopeless, and Burton behaves like someone trying out for "Lawrence of Arabia." In the end, the contradictory impulses of the two men -- their struggle to identify real courage and honor -- is a wordy game, an evasion of the latent homosexuality. It's worth recalling that Ray wanted Burton and Montgomery Clift for the officers, in war yet in love. But in his mainstream Hollywood career, Ray, the troubled bisexual, never reached that point of true danger.
Nearly every film has some such riddle within it -- and all the outward signs of disaster in the production. Ray thought and spoke very slowly. Producers always mistrusted those secret plans he must be hatching. They made his life hard -- or they fell into his trap of becoming the bad cops who haunted him. The deviousness of the man -- the drugs, the gambling, seducing Natalie Wood (age 16) on "Rebel" when he was 43 -- all that stuff needs to be spelled out, along with the four marriages, the son from the first marrying the second wife (Gloria Grahame), and the ways Ray sabotaged his own career. Yet admirers from Godard onward have guarded the lofty paragon and wounded victim Ray dreamed of being.
Why urge the truth? Because so many of the films are so half-baked and adolescent -- as dramas, as stories, as material. And we need to know that having the eye and the urge to be a great picture-maker is wondrous, but not enough. So Nicholas Ray made a few great films, and several that are so marred that it's time to challenge his own credo, "If everything was in the script -- why make the movie?" That sounds fine, but if there's confusion in the script, or worse, then why trust imagery to clear it up?
American film needs what Ray lacked: a mind for difficult ideas and adult material and daring conclusions. Ravishing self-absorption is not enough.

Nicholas Ray: Writ Large
Gramercy Theater, 127 East 23rd Street.
Through April 12.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
It's All a Game, and Only He Knows the Rules

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WHITE; Michael White is a columnist for BBC Music Magazine and writes for The Sunday Telegraph in London.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
IN the 21st-century culture of oversupply and underdemand, it's small wonder that every second musician in the marketplace is sold by agents, impresarios and record companies as unique. It doesn't mean much.
 But just occasionally it does. And Mikhail Pletnev -- arguably the most distinctive and idiosyncratically remarkable of living pianists -- is a case in point. 
 Only in the last 10 years have Western audiences had the chance to come to terms with him, although he made his mark a quarter century ago, when -- at 21 -- he took first prize at the Tchaikovsky International Piano Competition in Moscow and immediately stacked up invitations for impressive world tours. 
Then the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan and, as he says, "the doors closed."
"Cultural relations stopped," he adds, when we meet here in a discreetly empty restaurant of his choice. "I couldn't do 'the career.' Concerts outside the Soviet territories, all canceled. So for years I played Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, East Germany. No further."
And how did he feel about that?
"Philosophical," he says. "I stayed at home and taught. And this was not bad for me. Many young artists make success, become stars, play everywhere. Then disappear. They don't have time to take in. They just give. Then they run out of ideas, of energy, of repertory. You could say I was spared."
Mr. Pletnev, who plays at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday, tells me this in a confiding tone, heavily Russian but half whispered, with long pauses during which he thinks, draws deeply on a cigarette (he chain-smokes) and insists on pouring me another vodka, which I make an ineffectual effort to decline. I've never liked the taste.
"In Russia," he says, filling the glass, "we do not drink vodka for taste. We drink for effect. For consequence."
And, no doubt, to assist the philosophical approach to life that Mr. Pletnev holds to on and off the stage. Like a Russian Buddha smiling quietly to himself, he comes across as self-contained, inscrutable: the guardian of some vouchsafed secret that he may or may not reveal.
It's all a game, played to a book of rules that only Mr. Pletnev knows. And though he's serious about his art -- about the piano, about conducting (roughly one-sixth of his dates these days are with a baton rather than a keyboard) and about composing (a lifelong sideline) -- a latent mischief infects the presentation. Usually encased in a veneer of gloom.
You see it when he walks onto the stage, slowly, like a pallbearer at a funeral. "I have a bad knee," he says laconically.
But even more, you hear it in the playing: in the teasing virtuosity of his Beethoven bagatelles disc for Deutsche Grammophon, in the outrageous license of his award-winning Scarlatti sonatas for Virgin Classics and in the way he milks the encores in his live Deutsche Grammophon recording from Carnegie Hall.
You also get it on a plate when he conducts. Last year he was in London with the Philharmonia Orchestra and what, in other hands, would have been a standard program of Tchaikovsky bonbons. But in Mr. Pletnev's hands, it raised the currency of easy-listening to exalted heights of style and substance.
And its special pleasure was its wit: immaculately wry and sharp but somehow lovingly extracted from the orchestra with an absurdly modest repertory of gestures. Just a shrug here or a lifting of the finger there. He hardly bothered to beat time: a curiously inverted kind of showmanship, and very Russian. (Yuri Temirkanov, the artistic director of the St. Petersburg Philharmonic, plays the same game.)
But playing games in concerts is dangerous. Especially when you're playing them with an orchestra.
"Let me tell you a story." says Mr. Pletnev, and it's an old one. "A conductor gives a concert, charges a million dollars and five cents, and barely moves a finger. One single gesture, no more. People say after, 'How do you justify your fee?' He says, 'Five cents is for the single gesture. The million dollars is for knowing when to make it. This" -- a deep drag on the cigarette -- "is conducting."
Mr. Pletnev's story comes with a mock-geriatric gravitas appropriate to the heavy, hooded, slightly swollen details of a face no longer that of the alluring young Slav in the 1978 Tchaikovsky competition. It takes some effort of will to remember that he's actually just 45: born in Archangel, the only child of parents who were both musicians. His mother, with whom he still lives on the outskirts of Moscow, is a pianist -- "a good one, a real example," he says -- and his father, now dead, played the bayan, the Russian accordion.
In the circumstances, his musical education started late: at 13, when he went to the Central School in Moscow, a famous forcing-ground for prodigies.
"But I wasn't forced," he says. "I had a happy childhood."
"I'm still happy," he adds, staring at me with the solemn features of a bloodhound. "Ecstatic. I praise God I'm not ill, not crippled, except for my knee and my finger" -- an injury that caused him to cancel concerts earlier this year -- "and still alive. What should I complain about?"
In fact he does complain -- a lot -- about contemporary Russia which, he says, is run by "rich persons with money but no culture." As a pianist he's emphatically old-school: a natural heir to Sviatoslav Richter, Emil Gilels and Sergei Rachmaninoff, concerned to make the piano sing, with plenty of color but emphatic stress on melody.
"Rather old-fashioned, of course," he says. "And it won't survive. Times are changing. Mobile phone, Internet -- national schools will go. There's no community among Russian pianists now. If there is, I'm not part of it. I met Evgeny Kissin, sure, for five minutes. Otherwise I see him only on TV. He plays his way, I play mine."
It sounds as though he's not interested in other pianists. "Not so much," he says. "In fact I'm not interested in piano music, whoever plays. I find it boring. It surprises me that other people don't find boring what I do. I can't say I don't enjoy it. It's a nice thing to play good piano in a nice hall. But listen to someone else? No."
This, presumably, is one of Mr. Pletnev's games. He's after a reaction. How could any credible musician be so insular? Or so incurious?
He shrugs his shoulders. As he does to criticism of his interventionist approach to music-making.
Mr. Pletnev's repertory is selective, rooted in Russia but with lifelines out to Chopin, Liszt, Scarlatti and the Austro-German classics. No Ravel, Debussy, nothing modern (other than his own scores). "I only play what I understand and feel I could compose myself," he says. "The rest I leave to others. They do it better."
But within those tight parameters he gives himself a wide interpretive freedom that wins friends (for its imagination) and occasionally enemies (for its distortion of the text). His art is truly recreative.
"And why not?" he says. "As a composer myself, I know a score can never say exactly what the composer wants. Even if he knows. They're like children, compositions. They have your name, you think they belong to you, but no. They have their own life."
So does he consciously set out to liberate the offspring of Tchaikovsky and Mussorgsky? Is he trying to be different?
"If it's like everyone else, why do it?" he asks. "The audience can always get a CD. But difference -- this is a result of how I play, not the reason why. A result of how I feel on the spot, in the concert hall."
Making up for lost time, Mr. Pletnev has been highly visible in American concert halls during the last decade. For one thing, the Russian National Orchestra, which he founded in the new economic freedom of 1989, is largely financed from the United States, courtesy of the oil magnate and musician Gordon Getty.
On its home ground the orchestra was, and remains, a controversial undertaking. The first nonstate orchestra in Russia since before the revolution, it began as a commercial challenge to the old-guard ensembles and made its presence felt by stealing their best players. This did not boost Mr. Pletnev's popularity among orchestra managements.
But no one could deny the Russian National's quality, which ranks beside that of Valery Gergiev's Kirov Orchestra, outclassing the venerable St. Petersburg Philharmonic. Having seen it through its first decade and then withdrawn for a break, Mr. Pletnev is now back in the driver's seat as artistic director -- complaining of the lack of support the orchestra gets in Russia (despite connections in high places) but proud of its achievements.
"To conduct this orchestra is not a job," he says. "It's a privilege. We have a budget 60 times less than the budget of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, but still, a privilege."
Another vodka, and another cigarette.
"Of course, I say this philosophically."

Mikhail Pletnev, pianist
Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Thursday at 8 p.m.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
Rites of Spring: Gambling? What Gambling?

BYLINE:  By LISA BELKIN 

 BODY:
I AM not really a gambler. I'll buy a lottery ticket once in a while, or put a few coins in a Las Vegas slot machine, but for the most part I keep my money in my pocket. I'd like to say this is because I am wise enough to fear the grasp of addiction; heaven knows I am already far too hooked on vices like reality TV and the Snood games my children have downloaded onto my laptop. But the real reason I don't gamble is I really hate to lose.
 That said, even I feel safe wagering this: that a lot of you will be placing a lot of bets over the next few days. And even I am feeling the tug of office pools that sprout, like signs of spring, at this time of year. 
 I didn't know anything about March Madness until after I graduated. My alma mater has a tradition of coming "close, but not quite" to the finals and even in its best years the team is usually eliminated early. So when I entered the work world I was completely unprepared for the way college basketball can take hold of people who are eons away from their days at school.
Not quite a decade ago I wrote a profile of Christine Todd Whitman, who was then the governor of New Jersey, for this newspaper's magazine. There was a budget crisis looming at the time, and rumors swirled that she would be tapped for the vice-presidential spot on the Republican ticket. But the chatter among her staff was all about who would get tickets to the N.C.A.A. finals, which were being held at the Meadowlands that year. There was also a bracket pool circulating in the office, but that was off the record. After all, these things are illegal.
And yet every office seems to have one. It's been estimated that 30 percent of all employees, or 40 million people, enter an office pool every year. I'd also wager that similar numbers of people would refuse to admit that to the newspaper. I called more than a dozen companies at random while writing this column, and not one was willing to describe their setup publicly. 
"The fact that it's taboo, at least technically, is part of the fun," said a manager for a company who this year will be turning to a Web site -- www.hoopsfrenzy.com -- which is designed specifically to coordinate the office pool. Run by digitalBANG Technologies in Cincinnati, the site received 1.2 million hits during March Madness last year and has ramped up for even more activity this time.
But even if no one is talking, their distraction can be statistically measured. The Xerox Corporation, for example, tracks the monthly print volume for the office copiers and printers that it services nationwide. Research over the last three years shows that the month with the heaviest copying volume is March.
"All those brackets being printed and copied," Kara K. Choquette, the manager of corporate public relations for Xerox, says of the familiar forms on which participants scribble their picks. "Of course, there are more business days in March what with the lack of holidays," she admits, (adding that her own office "might or might not" have its own pool), "but the March Madness theory is more fun."
The outplacement firm of Challenger, Gray & Christmas has taken this statistical approach one step further and has calculated the economic effects of all the hours spent wagering and copying. March Madness could cost the nation's employers as much as $1.4 billion over the 15 days of the tournament, they've concluded (with their tongue firmly in cheek.)
Specifically, every 10 minutes of basketball talk could cost an average of $2.56 a worker, concludes John Challenger, the firm's chief executive. Multiply that by a work force of 138,907,000, he says, and the loss for every 10 minutes of talk grows to $347,921,920.
Of course, not everyone spends even a minute on such talk, so Mr. Challenger then computed the loss if only college graduates were included. There are 36.6 million people in the workplace with college degrees, meaning that lost productivity would reach $93.8 million for every 10 minutes. Multiply that out over two weeks and that's far more change than you are likely to win in any office pool.
But losing millions of dollars is not necessarily a bad thing, Mr. Challenger added. It might, to the contrary, be just what an office needs.
"The anxiety over a possible war and more terrorist attacks, not to mention decreased job security, has sunk employee morale," says Mr. Challenger (who admits that his staff has held these pools "in the past.") "If filling in brackets for an office pool or simply chatting about one's favorite team at the water cooler provides some relief, then it seems worthwhile."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
In a Slow Time, Some Builders Try School Projects

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
WITH New Jersey's commercial real estate market remaining weak, many firms are particularly eager to do school work -- designing schools, building schools, repairing worn-out school buildings and developing commercial areas around schools and universities.
 "School construction is a major source of work for architects and contractors at this very sluggish time," said the architect Edward N. Rothe, whose firm in Edison recently merged with a larger firm that specializes in school design. 
 The state's schools are aging and, according to state Education Department statistics, 53 percent need at least one important repair. Sixty-nine percent of the schools in the state have at least one unsatisfactory environmental condition, according to the state figures. Because of overcrowding, about 12,000 New Jersey youngsters attend class in trailers. 
Last month, despite the $5 billion state budget deficit, Governor James E. McGreevey announced the state would allocate $111 million in the 2003-4 budget to finance 254 new school buildings and additions, all scheduled to open by 2005. A portion of the allocation is to be used to acquire 100 sites for future projects.
Many of the school projects are designated for 30 poor and urban districts -- including Newark, Elizabeth and Asbury Park -- that were part of the Abbott vs. Burke school-financing lawsuit decided by the state Supreme Court almost five years ago. The court ordered that all schools in those communities had to be brought up to code, and overcrowding eliminated.
In July 2000, Gov. Christie Whitman signed a law authorizing the sale of bonds to raise $8.6 billion for school construction -- about $6 billion for the districts in the Abbott decision and the rest for suburban towns beset by overcrowding. By the time Governor McGreevey took office last year, however, there had been only a single groundbreaking as a result of the court order.
Last July, Mr. McGreevey created the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation as a subsidiary of the Economic Development Authority, to speed up the process. The corporation is now using a multitasking approach to managing construction, said its chief executive, Alfred T. McNeill, so that necessary permits are obtained at the same time a school is being designed and put out to bid for construction. 
Mr. Rothe said his architecture, planning and design firm began efforts about two years ago to position itself to win more school construction contracts.
"We engaged a consultant to assist us in finding a firm that had special expertise in the K-12 marketplace," he said. Mr. Rothe, a co-founder of the company formerly known as Rothe-Johnson-Fantacone, announced two weeks ago that the company had joined Fletcher-Thompson Inc., a Connecticut architectural firm that specializes in school, health-care and technology buildings. The new company is called RJF Fletcher-Thompson Architecture. 
Mr. Rothe said the firm is employed as the construction manager for the new Belmont Runyon Performing Arts School in Newark, a $20 million project planned before the Abbott decision took effect.
"Also, we were recently selected to design a $30 million performing arts school in Elizabeth; to do work on an arts high school in Camden, and we're on the short list for two new high schools to be built in Newark," Mr. Rothe said. The firm designed the recently completed Middlesex County Academy for Science, Mathematics and Engineering Technology in Edison on the campus of Middlesex Community College. 
Like other contractors, Mr. Rothe noted that the increase in state financing is not the only catalyst for school building plans. "Some wealthy suburban towns have grown so rapidly that they are forced to build schools, on their own," he said.
When Governor McGreevey announced the school construction push, he held a press conference in Washington Township, where a $49.9 million high school is being built. The state is financing $16.5 million of the cost, and the remainder comes from local taxpayers in the Mercer County suburb, one of New Jersey's fastest-growing towns.
Mr. McNeill, the head of the Schools Construction Corporation, has said that most of the construction in the early part of the school-building program will take place in the suburbs -- even though conditions in some Abbott districts are "enough to break your heart." That is because suburban schools were ahead on planning before Abbott was decided, he said. By 2005, he said, the majority of spending will be for urban school construction. Also, Mr. McNeill said, the major priority right now for urban schools is completion of more than 400 health-and-safety repairs and additions to ease overcrowding in existing buildings.
Among renovation projects to be completed by the end of the year are additions to schools in Berkeley, the Central Regional District in Ocean County and the Toms River Regional District.
Mr. McNeill and various local officials pointed out that suitable large plots of land are hard to find or assemble in many urban areas -- and when they are assembled, they often require environmental cleanup. 
Some real estate-related companies are focusing on projects that involve reusing existing buildings for schools. These older building sites often need cleanup, too, said people in the field.
In Union, a 50-year-old industrial building that had been empty and abandoned for five years is to be retrofitted as the new home of the Deron School, a private nonprofit school for special-needs students that is "state approved," meaning it is eligible for some state financing. 
The 37,000-square-foot building on Commerce Street that will be Deron's new home was in terrible shape, said Matthew B. Jarmel, a principal with Jarmel Kizel Architects & Engineers, based in Livingston, which will transform the structure. "There was water pouring in through huge holes in the roof," he said. "It had been a shop where they made and repaired forklifts, so there was some oil and grease cleanup that had to be done before anything else."
But the building is near a Union public school and next to a new housing development in Union, and the site is ideal for Deron, which has been searching for adequate space for five years, according to school officials. The industrial building will be converted into a 17-classroom facility, including a gymnasium, cafeteria, music room, workshop and specialized speech rooms. Construction is set to begin by the end of the month. 
Meanwhile, the Aztec Corporation, which has also expanded its work on school buildings in the past few years, is working on retrofitting a manufacturing building at the intersection of Route 10 and Okner Parkway in Livingston -- originally built for NASA -- for the private Gibbs College, which will move from Montclair. 
AND the Staubach Company, which set up a new educational and municipal services group last summer, is working on a project that would redevelop land in a depressed area around a state college in Jersey City. New Jersey City University is working with planners to buy and remediate environmental conditions at contaminated properties in its neighborhood off Route 440, said Susan Bagley of Staubach. 
"They'd like to create a university village around the campus," she said, "containing a blend -- very mixed use -- some retail, dining and entertainment, along with maybe some academic buildings."
Ms. Bagley noted that her company had been instrumental in developing similar projects in other states, including New Town in Williamsburg, Va., a public and private joint venture to create a mixed-use community around the College of William and Mary, and in Cincinnati, where it assisted two neighborhood organizations in preparing a plan to revitalize the area around the University of Cincinnati campus.
"We know that public higher-ed institutions are not deep-pocket entities," said Ms. Bagley. "We do project management, helping them with the bidding process, overseeing cost and timing, and helping them arrange financing."
In addition to the fact that school-related projects are "paying jobs in a slow time," as Ms. Bagley put it, she and Mr. Rothe pointed to a more ethereal satisfaction that comes with working in this field.
"School construction programs make a generational impact," Mr. Rothe said, "developing the children and young adults of the communities. It's a wonderful thing to be part of."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
F. D. Rich Is Busy Again in Downtown Stamford

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
AFTER a hiatus of 14 years, the F. D. Rich Company is back as a developer of major real estate projects in downtown Stamford. 
 Since 1989, when the company completed four major office buildings that were part of its urban renewal contract with the city, nothing comparable apart from UBS Warburg's 673,901-square-foot headquarters, has been constructed in downtown Stamford. During the ensuing calamitous 90's, the Riches surrendered to banks about 80 percent of their $500 million real estate empire inStamford, Florida, Maryland and Puerto Rico. 
 Now, Thomas L. Rich, 44, the company's president, has several projects in the works for the development and management group founded by his grandfather. His father, Robert N. Rich, is vice chairman and chief executive, and his uncle, Frank D. Rich Jr., is chairman. 
Most advanced among the projects is the construction under way at the corner of Broad and Summer Streets of the $17.5 million Stamford Courtyard by Marriott. The 115-room hotel is expected to be completed in March of next year.
The company acquired control of the property two years ago on a 98-year ground lease from two local families. The company razed a 9,000-square-foot building that formerly occupied the site and was built by the Riches in the 50's, relocating six small businesses. "If the families had sold it, they would have had to pay substantial capital gains taxes," Thomas Rich said. "This was a good solution for them." 
"Ground leases are an excellent way to put together a deal with very little capital," said Rick Redniss, president of the Stamford land use consulting firm of Redniss & Mead. "You can finance the balance because of the value of the land. It's a smart way to do business in this economy." 
The eight-story hotel will have 3,500 square feet of ground floor restaurant space and a 6,000-square-foot lower level containing a health club, pool, two meeting rooms and a buffet-type breakfast restaurant. Two elevators will carry cars to and from the 118 valet parking spaces in the garage on the second and third floors. Harvey Kaufman of New Canaan is the architect, and the Haynes Construction Company of Seymour is the general contractor.
A construction loan from Union State Bank for $10 million and a permanent loan from the General Electric Business Asset Funding Corporation for another $10 million are to augmented by $7.5 million in cash. The company would put up $4 million. "We are attempting to raise $3.5 million of the $7.5 million because we have other projects we are working on," Mr. Rich said. "We are in the market for a financial partner."
Summer Hotel Partners L.L.C., the development company for this project, got a special exception to current zoning for the half-acre site, allowing it to increase the hotel size by one-third while reducing the number of parking spaces by one-third. The city exempted ground floor retail and basement space from floor area calculations because it preferred to have an attractive building without unsightly parking rather than the allowable alternatives, including 41 apartments or 40,000 square feet of offices and 300 parking spaces.
AS the holder of a Marriott franchise, Mr. Rich said, "our franchise fee is based on a percentage of gross revenues from room rents," which he projected to start at $6 million a year with rates escalating from $143 to $183 a night in four years. "In return we get the Marriott name recognition, access to their reservations system, national advertising, and frequent-travel programs," he said. 
Marriott and the Rich company are no strangers to each other. The full-service 505-room Stamford Marriott was built by F. D. Rich in 1977.
In addition to building the Courtyard, Thomas Rich has a $26 million, 150-suite Residence Inn by Marriott on the drawing board. It is planned for 40,000 square feet adjacent to the north side of the main post office on Atlantic Street. Construction is to start in September and the building is to have a pool, dining facilities, health club, meeting rooms and parking for 150 cars. An opening is scheduled in January 2005.
Mr. Rich acquired control of the site and an adjacent 35,000-square-foot site that runs to the corner of Atlantic and Tresser Boulevard on a 98-year ground lease from the St. John's Urban Development Corporation. St. John's is the nonprofit owner and operator of 360 units of moderate income rental housing that the Rich company built behind these parcels in the 60's. "We have the right to buy out the lease and own the land," said Mr. Rich, who would eventually lease the land to the hotel and a 150,000-square-foot $43 million office building he plans for the smaller site.
For the present, the office proposal is being marketed by Ken Nordstrom and Michael Siegel of Insignia/ESG. "It will not be built without preleasing 100,000 square feet," said Mr. Nordstrom. "We think it will appeal to local companies and to financial services companies in New York. The majority of tenants are not seeking large spaces today, and the developer will build to suit committed tenants." 
If the Rich plans are completed, there will be four Marriotts in Stamford. The strategy, said Roger Conner, spokesman for the hotel company, "is different brands meet different travel needs."
A low-priced Marriott Fairfield Inn on Harvard Avenue was built by the Rich company as contractors in 1975. "Courtyards," Mr. Conner said, "generally charge $20 to $30 less than a full-service Marriott. They have less meeting space, no lounges, bars, and sometimes no restaurant." Residence Inns, he said, are in the extended-stay category, with kitchenettes, living areas and separate bedrooms. They may be rented for one night, but their appeal is to people on jobs away from home for weeks or months. 
While this is a bad time to be running an existing hotel, Steven Rushmore, president of Hospitality Valuation Services of Mineola, N.Y., said, "it's a good time to start hotels." He added: "They take one to three years to begin operating, and most people think by then the war will be resolved and the economy will be back on track. For its size Stamford generates a lot more hotel demand than many cities around the country because of its concentration of high-end companies, its proximity to New York and access to I-95 and railroad lines, and the fact that its hotels cater primarily to business travelers."
Still, Diane Holliday, general manager of the Westin, which like the Marriott is one of the city's four full-service hotels, said, "Occupancy has been flat at 55 and 60 percent last year and this year, compared to 2000 when it was 75 to 80 percent." Referring to the new Marriotts, she said, "We're not happy to have this new inventory."
The office market is no better, according to Jeffrey Dunne, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, who is representing F. D. Rich in seeking a buyer for its six-building High Ridge Office Park, priced at $103 million. "If I were building an office building, I would certainly do that smaller size," he said, "but I'm not sure I would build one today -- maybe in two or three years." His company's latest figures show that office vacancies in Stamford reached 16.4 percent of the total 16.3 milion square feet of office space in the fourth quarter of 2002. 
One more major Rich venture is under way at 33 Broad Street, the company's 120,000-square-foot parcel opposite the Stamford branch of the University of Connecticut. It is being sold this month to Target Stores for $9.2 million. A mixed-use 180,000-square-foot building to be built by Target has been approved for the site by city boards and commissions. It will contain 16,000 square feet of ground floor retail space and three levels of parking for 550 cars that are exempt from floor area calculations; the top two levels of 82,000 square feet each to be occupied by a Target Super Store.
Mr. Rich has retained the right to buy back a 25,000 square foot corner parcel at Broad and Washington Boulevard, where Target will initially install a temporary park, and Rich has an option to buy the ground-floor retail space at Target's cost as a retail condominium unit. 
In 1996 Mr. Rich bought a one-acre site at 118 Summer Street at auction for $505,000, and soon sold a ground lease to Crown Theaters, which built and opened the 1,600-seat, six-screen Majestic Crown Theater on the site in 1998. Mr. Redniss, representing the Rich organization and the theater, struck a deal with the city to encourage more night-time activity by exempting downtown theaters from the expense of building on-site parking. A formula was devised whereby thousands of parking spaces that are unused at night are calculated into a per-seat fee paid by the theater and property owner. The Bell Street public garage, for example, was renovated using $400,000 from this fund. 
"Most of the major things that Tom is working on," said his father, Robert Rich, "still have to do with downtown Stamford. It's like glue; we never seem to get unstuck."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas L. Rich at the site of the $17.5 million Courtyard by Marriott, with Landmark Tower, built by his company in 1971, at right. (George Ruhe for The New York Times) Map of Connecticut highlighting Courtyard by Marriott and surrounding areas.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cortlandt Manor; 
Country Living With a Commuter Link

BYLINE:  By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
WHEN Michael and Anne Devine were buying their first home in 1998, they visited Cortlandt Manor, a section of the northern Westchester town of Cortlandt. "We loved the area," said Mr. Devine, a tax manager at PricewaterhouseCoopers, whose wife also commuted, to a job in the marketing group of Neuberger & Berman, "and the fact that it still had a main train line so we could commute into the city." But, he added, "We couldn't afford the kind of home we wanted."
 So they bought a home in Bergen County, N.J., but they did not forget Cortlandt Manor. When their finances allowed it, the Devines returned and bought a house. "Where else could I buy a four-bedroom, almost 3,000-square-foot colonial on a cul-de-sac in the $550,000 range and still be able to get into the city within an hour," he said. 
 As for his home's proximity to the Indian Point nuclear power plant in nearby Buchanan, which has been the subject of controversy over the adequacy of safety plans in the case of an accident or a terrorist attack, Mr. Devine said: "Indian Point doesn't bother me. It wasn't a large consideration or detriment for us." 
Carol Kope, president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said, "As I see it, there's been no effect of people buying and selling homes in Cortlandt Manor, near Indian Point since 9/11." 
She added: "The prices in neighboring Yorktown have always been slightly ahead of those in Cortlandt Manor. In 1998, the median housing prices between the two neighborhoods varied by as much as $50,000. But now they're only $20,000 apart. Not only has there not been a major bailout of home buyers in Cortlandt Manor, but the area is coming up in price."
In the last decade, many new subdivisions and new parks have been built on the hilly terrain of Cortlandt Manor. The main shopping area of the town, the Cortlandt Town Center, off Route 6 has recently been renovated and expanded.
But despite the recent changes, vestiges of the old and familiar remain in Cortlandt Manor. St. Peter's Church is a one-room Episcopal church where Gen. George Washington is said to have read morning prayers; it was used as a hospital for French troops during the American Revolution. It is on the National Register of Historic Places, as are the adjoining Van Cortlandtville Cemetery and the Little Red Schoolhouse, which operated until 1972.
Linda D. Puglisi, supervisor of Cortlandt, said the town's preservation efforts are not limited to historic buildings. "We've put a lot of time into preserving its open space," she said. "About a third of the land has yet to be developed and over the last few years we have been acquiring land that has been deeded to us." The open space that has been preserved has increased 65 percent, she said. The town is in its second year of a building moratorium as it re-evaluates its land use policies.
Housing demand in Cortlandt Manor is strong, real estate professionals say. "We're one of the first affordable stops in Westchester where people from the city can come to get that country feeling, a choice of two good school districts and a good commute at a good price," said Cynthia A. Lippolis, the principal broker at River Towns GMAC Real Estate in Croton-on-Hudson. "They can choose everything from a small starter or turn-of-the-century home to a big new home."
Mrs. Lippolis said the current inventory is low in Cortlandt Manor, which is made up of many tiny neighborhoods or subdivisions, and "if they're priced well, houses in Cortlandt Manor sell right away."
There are several 700- to 1,600-square-foot cottages, Capes and ranches on the market, listed from the mid-$200,000's to $300,000. "They make good starter homes that someone can build onto," Ms. Lippolis said. In the $300,000 to $400,000 range, buyers can expect to find three- and four-bedroom Capes and high ranches on roughly one-half acre.
Nancy Kennedy, an associate broker at Coldwell Banker Perry Kennedy, said that for $400,000 to $600,000 buyers can find 2,300-square foot colonials or contemporaries with four bedrooms and two-and-a-half baths built in the last 10 years. They can find larger farmhouse colonials in some of the area's newest subdivisions, like Brookview Estates and Cranberry Meadows.
From $600,000 to $1 million, she said, buyers can find 4,000 square-foot, five-bedroom, three-bath resales in such new subdivisions as Old Oaks and Cortlandt Chase.
Besides more than 10,000 single family homes in Cortlandt Manor, Ken Verschoor, the town deputy planning director, said, there are 247 condominium units. Ms. Kennedy said two-bedroom units range from $160,000 at Wild Birch Farms to $400,000 at Valeria, an 800-acre 80-unit condominium built of fieldstone on property that was once the estate of a New York City financier. It has a swimming pool, golf course, tennis courts and pond used by rowboats. 
A two-bedroom rental in a two-family house in Cortlandt Manor is $1,000 per month, Ms. Kennedy said.
CORTLANDT MANOR is divided between two school districts. Approximately one-third of its students attend the 2,835-student Hendrick Hudson School District, an economically diverse district that also serves Montrose and Verplanck and parts of Croton-on-Hudson and Peekskill. About 5 percent of the students qualify for free or reduced-price lunch based on federal guidelines.
"We have been working very hard over the past 10 years to improve our standards and assessments," said Joan Thompson, the superintendent. "Two of our elementary schools, Furnace Woods and Verplanck, have improved over 20 percentage points or more in assessment tests over the last four years, and we have been spending most of our efforts over the last three to five years in the high school, where we've done major construction and renovation."
Hendrick Hudson High School now offers 13 advanced placement courses. "Our district's goal is not just to offer advanced placement courses for the highest level students," Ms. Thompson said, "but to offer a wide variety of entry level college courses so that all students, if they choose, could have college opportunities."
Of last year's 154 graduating high school seniors, 65 percent went on to four-year colleges and 25 percent to two-year colleges. They averaged 535 in the verbal section of the SAT reasoning test and 546 in math, considerably above the statewide averages of 494 and 506.
The biggest challenge facing the district is that $17 million to $18 million of its tax revenues comes from the Indian Point power plant. If the plant were to close, as many critical of evacuation plans for the surrounding area have demanded, residences in Cortlandt Manor would face a 74 percent property tax increase, said Nancy Bocassi, the assistant superintendent for business.
"Without financial support from the state and federal government, this district could not, in the short term, three to five years, continue to exist," she said.
Two-thirds of the students living in Cortlandt Manor attend the 6,352-student Lakeland Central School District, Westchester's largest suburban district in both area and student population. It covers more than 40 square miles of northern Westchester and western Putnam Counties.
Barnett Sturm, the superintendent, said, "We have expanded services for both gifted and challenged students." The district has a 40-student alternative high school for students "who have not experienced success in the regular high school setting and need a smaller, individualized environment," Dr. Sturm said.
Last November voters approved a $22.8 million bond issue that authorized the district to, among other things, build classrooms and renovate others and expand the kindergarten program from a half day to a full day, beginning in September 2004.
In the last three years the district has doubled its advanced placement course offerings in the two high schools from 11 to 22. It also has a science research program, in which students in Grades 6 through 12 study with scientists from I.B.M. and Wheelabrator, and a senior internship program, in which a student can get academic credit for a semester of outside work in an area of particular interest. The combined debating team from Lakeland and Walter Panas High Schools has won more championships than any other school district in the state.
Of last year's 246 graduates from Panas, the school that Cortlandt Manor residents attend, 67 percent went on to four-year colleges and 24 percent to two-year colleges. Students there averaged 502 in the SAT verbal test and 514 in math.
St. Columbanus Roman Catholic Church has an elementary school covering preschool through eighth grade; tuition averages $2,000 a year for parishioners.
Cortlandt Manor offers an array of recreational facilities. The Steven Herbert Memorial Skate Park is a new skateboard park with quarter-pipes and rails. Residents can swim and play volleyball at the 22-acre Sprout Brook Park, which has a man-made lake, enjoy the scenic overlooks of the 350-acre Hudson Highways Gateway Park and swim in the Olympic pool at the 51-acre Charles J. Cook Recreation Center.
Cortlandt Manor residents can also use hundreds of acres of other facilities in the town of Cortlandt, including the new 30-acre Steamboat Riverfront Park in the hamlet of Verplanck, which includes a dock. The county-owned Blue Mountain Reservation has more than seven miles of trails.
In addition, there is Camp Smith, named for Gov. Alfred E. Smith, a military reservation used for weekend training of local, state and United States Army reservists.
The Hudson Valley Hospital Center, a 120-bed nonprofit hospital in Cortlandt Manor, claims to have the second busiest emergency room in the county.
The area traces its recorded history to 1677, when Stephanus Van Cortlandt, a merchant and the first American-born mayor of New York City, began purchasing land from the Croton River north and east to Connecticut from several tribes of Indians. Probably the first outside visitor to the area was Henry Hudson, who anchored his boat, the Half Moon, in 1609 off the shores of Verplanck in the river that would later bear his name, said Laura Lee Keating, the town historian for Cortlandt. The town was incorporated in 1788 but for years residents used Peekskill as their mailing address. But in 1947, Peekskill broke away from Cortlandt and incorporated as a city.
In the 1990's, she said, the northern part of Cortlandt, about a third of the town, got its own ZIP code and the name Cortlandt Manor to distinguish itself from the rest of the town and the upstate city of Cortland.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about living in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., misstated the price of a two-bedroom apartment in the Wild Birch Farms condominium. Recent prices have averaged $297,500, not $160,000.

In the book "Copland: Since 1943," written with Vivian Perlis, he wrote: "One look at the grounds with the Hudson in the distance, the gardens and woods, and the house with the separate studio, and I was sold. When I first saw the studio, I said that it looked like a room where a composer could write music." When Copland died in 1990, most of his assets, including the house, were left to the Copland Fund for Music, intended to help young composers. When the organization put the house on the market in 1993, it was acquired by local music lovers, and in 1995 it opened as a creative center, known as Copland House, to encourage the knowledge of American music, said Florence Stevens, its president. About a half dozen composers are chosen annually to spend a week or two in residency there, where they "can sleep in the same bedroom that Aaron Copland did," she said. HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Rebecca Rogers, Andrew Bates

 BODY:
Rebecca May Rogers, the daughter of Lynette and James Rogers of Ebenezer, Australia, was married yesterday to Andrew Jonathan Bates, a son of Ellen and John C. Bates Jr. of Tenants Harbor, Me. The Rev. 
David Ware performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel of the St. Albans School in Washington.
 Mrs. Bates, 28, is to begin a J.D. program in June at Marquette University Law School. She received a law degree from the University of Queensland in Brisbane, Australia, and a master's degree in bioethics from Monash University in Clayton, Australia. She also received a bachelor's degree in nursing from the University of Sydney. Her parents operate a contract mail business in Brisbane for the Australian postal service. 
 Mr. Bates, 35, is an associate at Kirkland & Ellis, the Chicago law firm. A graduate of Harvard, he received a master's degree in international relations from Georgetown and a law degree from the University of Michigan. His mother is a freelance editor of materials for a Department of Agriculture education program. His father, who retired as a partner in the Washington office of Foley & Lardner, a Milwaukee law firm, does consulting on international taxation and government matters for the Treasury Department and the United States Agency for International Development.
