HEADLINE: New Vitality Around Old Railroad Stations 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AFTER a career as a schoolteacher and administrator in New York City, Frances Fein moved to Maplewood, N.J., five and a half years ago to be closer to a daughter and grandchild. Last June, she rented an apartment in the newly opened Gaslight Commons in neighboring South Orange.
 Like many New Yorkers she had neither a car nor an inclination to own one, an anomaly, to say the least, in the auto-oriented suburbs. 
 In her new location, she can easily walk to the stores in "the village," South Orange's downtown area. Just as important, she is only a short distance from the New Jersey Transit railroad station, where Manhattan Direct service can take her to Pennsylvania Station in about 25 minutes. "I still love New York, so the train is really important," she said. "I take the train into the city two or three times a week." 
Gaslight Commons -- named for the town's retro street lights -- was developed by LCOR Inc., which is actively seeking to take advantage of improvements in mass transit and a change in public attitudes in creating both commercial and residential developments. LCOR has developed more than 20,000 residential units and 16 million square feet of commercial space nationally since 1978.
"Transit-oriented development will be to this century what suburban development was to the past," said Anthony L. Marchetta, a vice president of LCOR, which is based in the Philadelphia suburb of Berwyn, Pa. "People do not want to drive to the city anymore; they would rather take a train."
"We were suburban developers," said Peter T. Gilpatric, a senior vice president of LCOR. "We took cornfields and potato fields and built on them. But we are driven by barriers to entry, and the barriers to entry in the suburbs are driving us back to the cities."
Development linked to transit hubs is not limited to New Jersey, where the state government's policy is to preserve open space by directing development to urban areas with established mass transit and utilities. In New York, LCOR has begun leasing a recently completed development it is calling Bank Street Commons, a 500-unit apartment complex in White Plains, adjacent to a Metro-North Railroad station.
Another developer, Forest City Daly, has acquired 2.75 acres of land in Mamaroneck, N.Y., about one and a half blocks from the Larchmont train station. It is seeking government approvals to develop 185 rental apartments and town houses that will be marketed to commuters.
LCOR is also planning a 300,000-square-foot office building in downtown Jamaica, Queens, close to the Long Island Rail Road station and the AirTrain to Kennedy International Airport. Executives of the company said LCOR has developed a mixed-use project, including 1,400 units of housing, 200,000 square feet of retail space and 1.2 million square feet of office space, in the Washington suburb of Bethesda, but noted that the New York region, with its highly developed mass transit systems, presents numerous opportunities.
Indeed, Mr. Marchetta said, the Hudson River Gold Coast in Jersey City and Hoboken could be regarded as a transit-related development because of the PATH rail line and ferry links between the housing and offices there and Manhattan.
The increased attractiveness of railroads is attributable both to improvements in passenger rail service and to the realization that no more highways are likely to be built in crowded urban areas like metropolitan New York, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "Over the last 20 years, office growth in the suburbs has become an increasingly important part of the economy," he said. "But the problem is that sprawl has produced crawl and the crowding has spread to the periphery of the region."
He said the spread of office development in New Jersey followed the pattern of the Interstate highway system, which was largely complete by the 1970's. By the end of the 1990's, people began to notice -- as they sat in traffic jams -- that no highway capacity had been added in at least a decade. "The highway budget these days goes to repair existing bridges, not to add capacity," Dr. Hughes said.
Meanwhile, the state was improving its transit system. It added Manhattan Direct service, which takes passengers into New York City without having to change in Hoboken to the PATH lines. Meanwhile, the system plans to add to capacity by ordering double-decker passenger cars and more powerful locomotives to pull longer trains. 
In addition, a $450 million rail transfer station is nearing completion in the Meadowlands in Secaucus. It will allow riders on New Jersey Transit's Bergen County and Pascack Valley Lines to bypass Hoboken and the PATH as well. 
Rail-related developments are mainly marketed to those without school-age children, developers say. Apartments with easy access to New York City are attractive to young singles and childless couples not interested in the maintenance of a house and unconcerned about the quality of school systems. They are also attractive to older people whose families are grown and who, similarly, want to be connected with the city, if not actually live in it.
"The baby boom generation is now 39 to 57 years old, and there are plenty of empty nesters who are rattling around their McMansions," Dr. Hughes said. "The developers are going after this market by providing a suburban housing option that is more affordable than Manhattan."
Or put another way, a given number of dollars buys or rents more housing in the suburbs than it would in Manhattan. "For a person who still has a job in the city, living in White Plains means an extra room and a place to park the car," Mr. Marchetta said.
Developments of this type are attractive to towns that fear additional housing will bring in an influx of children whose presence will force expensive expansions of school systems. In South Orange, there are a total of three school-age children in Gaslight Commons, a development of 200 apartments, Mr. Marchetta said, and one is a high school senior about to depart for college.
The importance of the proximity to the railroad station can be found in the parking lots of the complex, which are nearly full on weekdays, the LCOR executive said, because most residents take the train to work and typically use their cars on weekends. 
Office workers like proximity to transportation as well, LCOR executives say. The company's proposed JFK Corporate Square development in Queens, a $30 million office building, is to be close to terminals for the Long Island Rail Road and the AirTrain to J.F.K. Airport. "It'san eight minute ride to the airport once service begins," said Mr. Gilpatric. The train had been scheduled to start running last year, but a fatal derailment has postponed service indefinitely.
In Connecticut, a $200 million commercial development approved for a 35-acre site next to the Metro-North tracks in the town of Fairfield includes construction of what would be the town's third train station. The zoning at the site, to be called Black Rock Park, allows for one million square feet of offices, a hotel, day care center and health club. An agreement to develop the property drawn up by the town, the Connecticut Department of Transportation and Black Rock Realty, a private developer, cites the creation of a station as essential to attracting tenants to the planned office buildings.
In Westchester, the short walk to the Larchmont station on Metro-North is what motivated Forest City Daly, a subsidiary of Cleveland-based Forest City Enterprises, to assemble a 2.75 acre site in Mamaroneck for a residential and retail development. "What drew us here was that it is a great neighborhood and it is close to the train station and downtown Mamaroneck," said George P. Kruse, the company's vice president for development.
He said the proposed development would include 185 market-rate apartments in a seven-story building with retail stores and parking in the base. "It is one and a half blocks to the train station and three blocks to one of the nicest downtowns in Westchester County," he said.
While officials in Westchester seem willing to accept transit-related developments only after long and careful planning, municipal leaders in New Jersey are counting on them to help revive down-at-the-heels neighborhoods that have stops on passenger lines.
Forest City Daly is developing plans to renew the downtown shopping area of Bloomfield Township, a blue collar Essex County suburb that was once a shopping destination, before the development of suburban malls. Plans call for 500 market-rate apartments, 170,000 square feet of retail space and a 900-space parking deck.
The development would transform a 13 acre site in the "Six Points" part of town that had been designated an area in need of redevelopment several years ago. Forest City Daly expects to be designated as the developer within weeks, Mr. Kruse said. If that happens, he said, demolition work would begin by fall. The $160 million project is expected to take five years to complete, starting with acquisition of the needed land.
Mr. Kruse said his company had been drawn to the project because the site surrounds a New Jersey Transit rail station that is benefiting from the opening of the Montclair Connection a mile or so away. The connection, which joined two rail lines, puts Bloomfield's station on the main line to New York rather than on a truncated branch as it was in the past.
"Midtown Direct train service is what drew us to the site," said Mr. Kruse. He said the expectation was that the easy access to New York and lower rentals than some nearby towns like Montclair would draw residents to the area. They, in turn, would establish a base of shoppers for the new retail development. The additional parking would be a lure for shoppers from other towns in the area, because parking is chronically scarce in an region that developed along train lines before automobiles were invented.
One possible drawback is that the station itself is not owned by New Jersey Transit, having been sold years ago, along with others in the area. Some stations have ended up as offices for real estate agents and lawyers,while today's commuters stand on cold platforms waiting for trains.
A far more ambitious plan linked to rail service has been proposed for Harrison, a former manufacturing center on the Passaic River to the east of Newark. There is a PATH train stop in Harrison; it provides a link to Pennsylvania Station in Newark, which has access to Northeast Corridor trains and a link to Newark Liberty International Airport.
Since much of the 235-acre site designated for redevelopment is currently covered with abandoned factory buildings, persuading people to move there will be a challenge, even those involved in development plans acknowledge.
"Urban development is not for the faint of heart," said Joseph Romano, a vice president of Advance Realty Group, which plans a mixed use development on 135 acres of the site. The plans include 3,500 apartment units, 2.5 million square feet of office space and 500,000 to 1 million square feet of retail space phased in over 10 years.
A key to the project will be building a stadium for the MetroStars professional soccer team. A 25,000 seat stadium would be ideal for the team, which regularly draws close to 20,000 people a game, but they are lost in Giants Stadium, with a capacity of more than 70,000, Mr. Romano said.
But public transportation remains at the core of the project, said David B. Barry, president of Applied Development, which plans to build housing on 30 acres near the PATH station. "The overwhelming thing driving Harrison is the train station," he said. "Without the PATH, it is a completely different redevelopment."
It would be foolish to ignore the fact the Interstate 280 runs through Harrison, providing easy access to the New Jersey Turnpike and other major roads in the area, said Jeffrey Babikien, a senior managing director with Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company. He said current plans include an improved two-way connection with the highway. "A project like this cannot survive on mass transit alone," he said. "You have to give people the opportunity to drive to work."
Conceding that there is little ambience in the area now, Mr. Barry said several projects needed to be developed at the same time to convince people that it is a suitable location for living, working and shopping. But he said today's Harrison is no more an eyesore than Jersey City was when its waterfront was littered with abandoned rail lines and decaying warehouses. The Lefrak Organization led the way in developing new housing and office towers in the city with its 600-acre Newport project. "Jersey City, prior to Lefrak, looked like Harrison does now," Mr. Barry said.
The coming of Manhattan Direct rail service has brightened up the downtowns in places like South Orange, where new retail stores have opened to cater to commuters and close-by residents, and in Morristown, where a development of 10 new town houses costing close to $1 million each has all but sold out, according to town officials.
AS a result, the state has designated the area around the train stations in some towns as "transit villages" which are eligible for assistance by a variety of state agencies. In Morristown, a 300-space surface parking lot adjacent to the train station is to be developed into a project with about 200 rental apartments, 8,000 square feet of retail space and a parking deck for 700 cars, according to Michael Fabrizio, executive director of the Morristown Partnership, a business-backed improvement group. The project has a budget of $35 million.
In South Orange, in addition to Gaslight Commons, several other residential projects are being planned, including one that would replace a closed supermarket.
Transit villages are areas within one-quarter to one-half mile from a train station that have been designated for mixed-use redevelopment, said Jack Lettiere, the commissioner of New Jersey's Department of Transportation. "There is a strong residential component and some focus on commercial development as well," he said. "The object is to reduce traffic congestion by making transportation less of a burden on people's lives."
A related objective is to help older downtown areas, which tend to be close to the railroad stations, flourish once again, he said. He said Gov. James E. McGreevey wants to double the number of designated transit villages by next year as part of a plan to curb sprawl in the outer suburbs.
Besides South Orange and Morristown, existing transit villages include Rahway, Riverside, Rutherford, South Amboy and Pleasantville, near Atlantic City. Metuchen was recently added to the list, with the state contributing $600,000 to build a pedestrian bridge, flashing signals at pedestrian crosswalks and other improvements.
Most of the towns being designated for redevelopment were originally settled as train lines stretched across the state in the mid-1800's. In Montclair, where the price of housing increased sharply with the completion of the Montclair Connection and the advent of Manhattan Direct service last year, started attracting commuters to New York in 1856, the year rail service began.
Because they developed in a pre-automobile era, the downtown areas tend to be compact and easy to walk around. (The corollary, of course, is that parking is a annoyance for those who have to drive.)
But government programs are not needed to persuade executives to pursue private sector opportunities at some sites close to passenger trains. "We are looking at a site in Bronxville," said Mr. Gilpatric of LCOR. "It could be a condo project with the sales prices at $1 million." He noted the success of the similarly priced project in Morristown.
Mr. Kruse of Forest City Daly said his company is looking at additional transit-related projects as well. "We are talking to officials in New Brunswick about a residential development," he said. "And, yes, it is close to the train station."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
A ToughTransition: Friend to Supervisor

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
WHEN Cheryl Kahn was promoted from sales manager to director of catering for the Glazier Group of restaurants in New York last April, she realized that things would never be the same with her former co-workers, now her subordinates.
 She would would miss the water-cooler gossip, the easy back-and-forth about life outside the office. Now she was management, and she could no longer shrug off an employee's chronic lateness or poor work habits. 
 Ms. Kahn had worked for 11 years at the Glazier Group, which owns the Monkey Bar and Restaurant, Michael Jordan's: The Steak House N.Y.C. and Bridgewaters, the downtown banquet hall, and adjusting to her new role was daunting. In fact, she pushed people too hard and managed to alienate just about everybody, she said. 
"At first I was like a bulldozer knocking everyone over, and that was not well received," she said. "I was saying, 'It's my way or the highway,' and was forgetting that my friends were also in transition."
It is a classic quandary for managers making their way up the corporate ladder: how to redefine their relationships with colleagues who were once their equals, or even their bosses, but who now report to them.
Allaying the jealousy and winning the trust of those left behind, while still asserting authority, requires a diplomacy and agility that many newly minted executives lack. But they must master those skills if they hope to get ahead, management consultants say.
In a corporate world shaken by scandals, layoffs, economic uncertainty and early retirements of seasoned executives, this balancing act is playing out in more workplaces.
"It's a tricky thing to handle," said S. Joanne Murray, director of the Center for Work and Service at Wellesley College and a management consultant. "If you're internally promoted, they assume you know the lay of the land. It's a big transition. You need to be patient and not attempt to change everything at once."
On the other hand, Ms. Murray said, the new manager should get out the message immediately that he or she will be evenhanded in dealing with subordinates. Thus, Ms. Murray urges clients to steer clear of lunches with former workplace buddies to avoid the impression of favoritism, and to repair any troubled relationships with former co-workers to let them know all is forgiven.
In any case, the new manager will probably encounter some resentment among old colleagues who think their new boss has become too big for his or her britches.
Rob Carstons, a technical manager at International Business Systems in Folsom, Calif., recalls the uncertainty he felt after being promoted to a manager from a junior programmer in 1997. "It was a little bit challenging to be suddenly giving directives to peers, when just the day before you were one of them," Mr. Carstons said. "You try to be careful not to offend anyone. It's strange walking into a room and the whole conversation changes. People don't want to be as open with you when you become the boss."
OR as nice. Linda McGee, the president of Medex Insurance Services, a unit of the Medex Global Group in Baltimore, who started as a customer service representative in 1989 and leapfrogged over colleagues in a series of promotions, remembers the occasional digs. "They would say, 'Oh, here comes the big cheese now,' " Ms. McGee said. "God only knows what they talked about behind my back."
As she rose through the ranks, she said, her former office mates didn't invite her out as often, and she became more guarded about what she discussed with them. Even so, she said, she probably was too lenient with some of them.
She remained close, however, with a former colleague, Deneen Detorie, and that raised prickly workplace issues. In 1986, Ms. Detorie, a sales representative, hired Ms. McGee, then a college senior, as an intern. By 1995, Ms. McGee had risen to vice president for sales and marketing at the Medex Assistance Corporation and had become supervisor to Ms. Detorie, who by then was in charge of account services. 
At work, the two refrained from talking about the family vacations they took together, though it was no secret thatthey were close friends. For Ms. Detorie, the connection was a mixed blessing.
She recalled a particularly insecure salesman who used her as a sounding board to rehearse conversations he wanted to have with Ms. McGee. "He seemed afraid of her," Ms. Detorie recalled. "He'd come to me to get clearance for things he wanted to say."
Other employees approached her to see if she was privy to confidential information or to gauge Ms. McGee's opinions.
The friendship also enabled Ms. Detorie to take liberties with her boss that other subordinates would be unlikely to try. The day Ms. McGee gave birth to her son in 1996, for example, Ms. Detorie called her to discuss a proposal that she was putting together to land an important corporate client. And when she was late in responding to an urgent "request for proposal" from a higher-up, the friendship helped avert what might have been a severe reprimand for a less well-connected employee, they said.
"The hardest thing is acting like a boss in front of friends," Ms. McGee said. "I think sometimes you temper your reactions. I remember with Deneen feeling a lot of anger when I found out the request for proposal didn't go out. But I controlled my anger, stepped in and helped fix it."
Ms. Kahn, the new catering chief at the Glazier Group, has also learned to control her emotions. Previously, her strength had been in managing corporate accounts. Managing people, she found required making unpopular decisions, like telling her sales staff that they could no longer give bottles of Grey Goose vodka to customers to help close a deal. "I needed some time to figure out how to handle my new role," she said. "I realized I needed to loosen up and enjoy it more."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
With Property Taxes, the Bill Isn't Always Certain

BYLINE:  By ALINA TUGEND 

 BODY:
ACROSS the country, many homeowners watched gleefully as their property values soared in the last few years. In some cases, however, they have found that their property taxes have also climbed. The weak economy is now adding to some homeowners' woes: many states have had to reduce local aid, forcing cities and counties to raise taxes to bridge budget gaps.
 Of course, you can't change the actual tax rate, which is set by state or local statutes, short of staging a voter revolt. But you can contest the house assessment value that local governments use in the formula to set property taxes. Now that home prices are stabilizing in many parts of the country, you may be able to build a case for an appeal. 
 The time for filing a challenge, though, is fast approaching in some areas: in New York City, for example, the so-called grievance day for most homeowners is tomorrow; for many counties in other parts of New York State, the appeal day is on the fourth Tuesday in May. 
Judging by interest from prospective clients, "we're going to see a lot more appeals," said Caryn S. Luntz, a property tax consultant in Westchester County. When the economy was stronger, and house prices were skyrocketing, she said, most people knew it was fruitless to try to lower their taxes. In Los Angeles County, for instance, there were only 14,000 assessment appeals in fiscal 2000, down from about 110,000 in fiscal 1996.
The National Taxpayers Union, based in Washington, estimates that as much as 60 percent of taxable property in the country is overassessed, but it says that only one in 50 taxpayers tries to lower it. About half who do mount a challenge win some kind of reduction, said Peter J. Sepp, a spokesman for the group. "All it really takes is an afternoon going to an assessor, a weekend preparing your own case and an evening rehearsing," Mr. Sepp said.
Many strategies can be pursued. You can try to prove, for example, that similar properties carry lower values than yours, or that errors were made -- four bedrooms were listed by the assessor when there are only three, or the dimensions of the property were wrong.
Not everyone feels comfortable braving the byzantine world of taxes. Specialists, including real estate lawyers and property tax consultants, can help, and most will charge clients only if cases are won, usually taking about half of the tax savings of the first year or two. Gabriel E. Khawly, 70, an accountant from Eastchester, N.Y., said he tried about 20 years ago to lower his property taxes on his own. It wasn't until two years ago, after hiring a property tax consultant who specializes in challenging assessments, that he was successful. He said the consultant saved him $648 a year in property taxes on his four-bedroom split-level ranch home, valued at $421,281.
Andrew J. Miller, a businessman from Pound Ridge, N.Y., hired a lawyer last year to challenge the assessment on his $1.4 million, 7,000-square-foot colonial home. "My feeling is that I would rather get people who deal with this on a regular basis," he said. His lawyer, he said, helped him get a decrease of about 12 percent on the assessment.
But James E. A. Lumley, author of "Challenge Your Taxes: Homeowner's Guide to Reducing Your Property Tax" (Wiley, 1998), says that most people can easily challenge their taxes on their own -- if they have clear grounds and follow the proper steps. "We're not talking about rocket science here; people shouldn't feel intimidated," Mr. Lumley said.
Challenging your assessment on your own may still require a certain amount of mathematical skill -- and knowledge of the tax bureaucracy. Determining property taxes involves a convoluted mixture of numbers -- usually including local, county and school taxes, along with the property assessment. In most counties, cities or towns, the tax assessor determines the market value of houses, usually by comparing them with the value of similar properties sold in the same area, and deducting for differences like the age of the property, the absence of certain luxuries, like fireplaces, or the presence of damage like dry rot. 
To keep current, many municipalities perform reassessments. In small towns, assessors may make physical reappraisals every year, although that may consist of simply peeking in a window or driving by. In large cities, they often rely on records of past assessments and new improvements. (In some states, like California, new assessments are made only when a house changes hands. California has a law capping property tax increases at 2 percent annually.)
"There's lots of technical ways assessing is done," Mr. Lumley said. "But whether you're talking a co-op in New York or a rural cabin in Vermont, it's still a matter of comparable value."
Sometimes, tax challenges are settled on the spot. If a homeowner convinces the tax assessor that a reduction should be made, "many assessors will be happy to reach an informal compromise, rather than have to defend their assessment of your property before an appeals agency," according to the guidebook of the National Taxpayers Union. If an assessor rejects the case, the next step is to go before an appeals board -- a process, again, that differs by locality. The hearings are usually short -- in New York City, for example, they are typically limited to 10 minutes.
Some local and national consumer tax groups supply guidelines on how to challenge an assessment. The Macomb County Taxpayers' Association in Michigan provides a 12-step process in its handbook, "How to Effectively Appeal a Property Tax Assessment," and since 1978 has been offering two-hour seminars. The National Taxpayers Union (www.ntu.org) offers for $6.95 its guidebook, "How to Fight Property Taxes." The New York State Office of Real Property Services offers a guide on filing for a review (www.orps.state.ny.us).
TOO often, said Michael Sessa, chairman of the Michigan association, property owners lose appeals after going to hearings unprepared. He suggests that taxpayers contemplating appeals select 15 to 20 nearby properties that are most similar to their own, then go to the assessor's office and check the properties' records. 
Mr. Sessa says people sometimes become emotional when arguing their cases before assessors. He says his seminars help to reduce the anger that many taxpayers may feel. "We explain what an assessor can do and what he can't do," Mr. Sessa said.
One seminar participant, Philis DeSaele, 59, of Sterling Heights, Mich., said she won a reduction in the assessment of a vacant lot she owned, worth thousands of dollars in tax savings, by showing that zoning restrictions prohibited her from building on the lot. She had tried appeals unsuccessfully several times before in the 1980's. "Before, I didn't thoroughly document what I was saying," Ms. DeSaele said. "I didn't know I could get documents at city hall that showed how they valued the property."
Of course, there is always the possibility that your assessment could be adjusted higher, though experts say that this rarely happens. Ms. Luntz said that it was a possibility in an informal process -- when a homeowner casually talks to an assessor, for example -- but that in some areas, like Westchester County, it cannot happen if a homeowner files a written grievance.
The best overall strategy for winning a case is to "be correct," Mr. Lumley said.
"Too many people are lazy, complain without substance and don't compare like to like," he said. "And remember, emotionality gets you nowhere."

Basic Rules for Making Appeals
 HERE are some steps that could help lower your property tax assessment, according to experts.
* Carefully review the assessment on file. Are the recorded descriptions and dimensions of the property correct? Make sure, too, that they take into account any defects that would tend to reduce the value of a home -- a cracked foundation, for example.
* Check out the neighbors. Make a list of similar properties in the area and compare their assessments with yours. Take notice of items like fireplaces, garages and backyard sizes. 
* Consider an independent appraisal. If you think your property is overassessed, you may want to hire a certified appraiser to provide an independent valuation that can be used to help make your case. Such a service doesn't come cheaply: appraisers typically charge $200 to $500.
* Meet with the tax assessor. This may be difficult in larger cities. But if presented with enough convincing evidence, an assessor may sometimes make a reduction on the spot.
* Seek a formal appeal. Homeowners can usually challenge tax assessments at any time, but many governments have scheduled specific days for formal appeals. In many parts of New York State it's the fourth Tuesday in May; in several California counties, it is Nov. 30.
* Be prepared at the appeal hearing. Before your appearance date, get a copy of the board's procedures, then gather the necessary evidence. That may include records of comparable property assessments and photographs of your home.
* Stay focused -- and calm. You may be angry about your taxes in general, or frustrated about the quality of government services, but the assessment appeals process is not the place to deal with them. The only job of the assessor and the appeals board is to estimate the value of your property.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Taming Roommate Chaos

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN 1994, my college friend James and I decided to share a 600-square-foot apartment in the West Village of Manhattan to help save money. We lived there for four years, sharing everything from kitchen appliances to CD's. Although we were clearly not romantically involved, we were a couple in many ways. We traveled together, did yoga together and befriended each other's friends, many of whom spent months crashing on our couch.
 Then he bought a duplex apartment, and I got the upstairs. I had a great deal -- $1,200 a month for a beautiful studio -- but our relationship became strained. Were we housemates, friends, or tenant and landlord? Could I traipse through his apartment if I forgot my keys? Should he have the right to ask me to leave my apartment when his family visited? The boundaries were murky; we had arguments over who had taken advantage of whom. 
 Our parting was not unlike a divorce. After all, we had been together for a few years and had had endless discussions about personal property: Who would get custody of the silverware, which we had bought together at Bloomingdale's? What about the Leonard Cohen CD that I swore was mine and he knew was his? (Forget about the iron, which our friend Lee gave to both of us and is still a sore spot.) Perhaps we should have had a written agreement -- a prenuptial without the nuptials.
Any type of relationship can benefit, including that of parents and their grown children who move in with them after college. Their agreements, for example, could outline house rules and responsibilities and include mandates about meal preparation, laundry, personal hygiene and other specifics. 
Some college students are already familiar with so-called roommate agreements, which many schools have them sign before they move into dormitories. The roommates often negotiate, in detailed language, everything from the preferred method of message-taking to the number of nights a guest is allowed to stay. 
"It helped a lot," said Jasen Lomnick, 18, a freshman at the Rochester Institute of Technology, who signed such an agreement. "My roommate and I have a lot of disputes and we look back on it every week -- like if he was studying and I had company over, or if I had the music too loud, we'd pull out the agreement and see what it says."
His roommate, Michael Howard, also 18, agreed, saying they would check the agreement "and compromise or change things as the semester went along."
But students -- and their parents -- aren't the only ones who can use agreements on living arrangements. 
"It makes sense for long-term roommates to have some kind of written agreement with each other in the event that one moves out," said Thomas F. Coleman, a lawyer and executive director of the American Association for Single People, in Glendale, Calif. "If you are living in a family-like environment -- you take vacations together, share some expenses -- you are potentially on the books for a lawsuit" if something goes wrong and you don't have an agreement. (Conversely, you could also be hit with a lawsuit if you violate the agreement; as in any business transaction, you have to adhere to the rules.)
Sheridan Falvo, 28, owns a two-bedroom, two-bathroom condominium in Union City, N.J., that she shares with her friend Marian Woodworth, 27, an editor at Heyman Associates, an executive search firm in New York City. Ms. Falvo's father, a real estate lawyer, suggested that she draft a written agreement before Ms. Woodworth moved in.
"In a lot of ways it is like a marriage," said Ms. Falvo, who works in human resources at Ruder Finn, a public relations firm in Manhattan. "I cook and she cleans, or if I'm home early I'll go to the dry cleaners and if she is she does. If one doesn't have money the other covers it and we work it out later."
It's hardly surprising that roommate agreements are gaining popularity, especially as the weak economy forces more people to double up to cut expenses. Frederick C. Hertz, a lawyer in Oakland, Calif., draws up agreements for roommates, unmarried couples who are homeowners, and people who live in communes. This work is about 80 percent of his practice, up from 1 percent in 1987. A third of these clients are under 35.
"Many young people lost a lot of money in the dot-com bust and can't afford to live alone, so they buy apartments with friends or take on roommates," he said. "When people who love and care about each other get into business situations they're afraid to deal with the issues -- 'Well, you earn more than me so you should contribute more,' or 'If I made the whole $100,000 down payment why should the profit be split 50-50?' Write it down."
Some households operate as informal communes. Consider the six college buddies who live at the "Half Street Community," as they call it -- actually just a three-bedroom house in Washington. Each contributes to a group account for rent and groceries, and each chipped in for a 1992 Plymouth Voyager. And each is responsible for cleaning a room in the house. They have even given titles to one another: the "Rockefeller" is in charge of finances while the "Swinger" leads all social events and the "Pooh-bah" runs the weekly meetings.
"WE'VE had six-hour meetings, but we make it a point to get to the same page," said Chris Lewis, 24, who is known as the "Professor." They have even drafted and signed a household constitution.
James and I, meanwhile, are slowly rebuilding our relationship; it's a lot easier now that we're not living together. But every so often I'll find something that belongs to him -- like a book about Picasso -- or I'll notice my glass bottles on his shelf. Those aren't big deals, of course. The iron, however, is still up for grabs.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
For Patients, Unpleasant Surprises in Arbitration

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds @nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE parents of Jesica Santillan, the 17-year-old girl who died last month after a bungled heart-lung transplant, have yet to decide whether to sue for medical malpractice, according to the family's lawyer, Kurt Dixon. But there is a chance that they won't be able to, anyway -- they may have signed an agreement with Duke University Hospital before the operation to settle any medical malpractice claims through binding arbitration. Mr. Dixon said last week that he was still awaiting medical records, so he's not sure if that was the case. 
 More and more health care providers are pushing for binding arbitration -- in which an arbitrator or panel of arbitrators unconnected to a case hears arguments from both sides and renders a decision -- to reduce their costs. 
 "We all have the impression that medical malpractice arbitration agreements are expanding, and expanding rapidly," said John Vail, senior litigation counsel at the Center for Constitutional Litigation in Washington. It advises the Association of Trial Lawyers of America on constitutional issues.
The Florida Medical Association held a series of well-attended seminars around the state in December and January to teach doctors how to put arbitration agreements in place. In Utah, the Legislature passed a bill recently that allows doctors and hospitals to turn away patients who will not sign arbitration agreements. (Emergency services are excluded.) Governor Michael O. Leavitt is expected to sign it this month.
"Insurance for some specialists and for ob-gyns is rising substantially," said State Senator Leonard Blackham, the bill's sponsor. "We're going to do this as a trial and see if premiums can't come down."
Patients who go through arbitration instead of a jury trial, however, may feel as if they have been hurt twice: first by their health care provider, then by the system that is supposed to resolve the problem. They generally have little choice in the way claims are handled. Gary and Sharon Rushford of San Jose, Calif., certainly didn't.
In 1998, Mr. Rushford, then 51 and the owner of a general contracting business, noticed pain and tingling in his foot when he worked out at the gym. He said that over three months, his doctor in the Kaiser Permanente H.M.O., who worked at its hospital in Santa Clara, Calif., never examined him and instead prescribed painkillers over the phone and referred him to a podiatrist and physical therapy. The pain became so bad that he went to the emergency room, where doctors diagnosed a blood clot in his leg. Doctors broke up the clot, but it kept coming back. The vascular surgeon then in charge of the case failed to prescribe enough blood-thinning medication, standard treatment in a case like his, Mr. Rushford said. The clot worsened in a few weeks, and despite three operations to try to re-establish blood flow to his foot, he said, his leg had to be amputated above the knee.
The Rushfords went to arbitration, as Kaiser requires for all malpractice claims. At first, they said, they could not find a lawyer to represent their case, despite several attempts. Many lawyers are hesitant to take these cases, because arbitration awards are often lower than jury trial awards and are perceived as being harder to win. The Rushfords eventually turned to Sharonrose Cannistraci, the lawyer who handled legal matters relating to their construction business.
Selection of arbitrators varies by health care provider and by state. In California, Kaiser arbitrators are chosen by an office overseen by a 13-member board composed of Kaiser stakeholders and members of the public. The parties in a case choose an arbitrator from a large pool assembled by the office, but if they cannot agree on one, the office chooses. The arbitrators are usually retired judges.
In the Rushfords' case, Kaiser said it had asked State Superior Court in San Mateo County to pick the arbitrator. The Rushfords were not comfortable participating in the selection early on because they had no lawyer, according to Ms. Cannistraci.
Their arbitrator was a retired judge who had dealt with 13 other disputes involving Kaiser; in four of them, Kaiser used the same lawyer it used in the Rushfords' case.
In December 2001, the arbitrator ruled in favor of Kaiser. In his decision, he said that although the surgeon had breached the standard of care by twice failing to give Mr. Rushford enough blood-thinning medication, the Rushfords didn't prove that failure to do so resulted in the loss of Mr. Rushford's leg.
Ms. Cannistraci said the couple is challenging the decision, based in part on their contention that Kaiser doctors had engaged in false testimony by saying they had done tests that had not been performed.
Ms. Cannistraci said she had no complaints about how the judge handled the case. "But there's an inherent conflict of interest," she said. "These retired judges are making their living based on arbitrations, and they do repeat arbitrations on Kaiser cases. That's their bread and butter."
A 2000 report on managed care arbitration, compiled by the California Research Bureau, a state-financed public policy research group, found that none of the few arbitrators who awarded patients more than $1 million from April 1999 to March 2000 were selected by health care providers to serve again during that time.
Kaiser declined to comment on the specifics of the Rushfords' case. Matthew Schiffgens, a company spokesman, said: "We feel the arbitration process we have is fair, fast and efficient for resolving member disputes. We stand by the decision of the independent arbitrators, be they for or against the health plan."
ARBITRATION isn't cheap. The two parties generally split the cost of the arbitrator's time, whose rates are often several hundred dollars an hour. Mrs. Rushford estimates that she and her husband spent more than $200,000 making their case, which included hiring medical experts.
Critics say one troubling aspect of arbitration is its secrecy. Proceedings are often confidential. There is no public airing of issues or acknowledgment of error, and no development of case law or establishment of precedent. "Part of the value of the Seventh Amendment right to a trial by jury is that the public sees the facts," said Jamie Court, executive director of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights. 
A hearing on the the Rushfords' challenge is scheduled for April 2 in the court in San Mateo. Under state law, if their petition is granted, the case would go to a different arbitrator, selected by the two parties. The Rushfords instead have asked for a jury trial, based on a previous case in which the California Supreme Court found that evidence of fraud during arbitration could constitute a waiver of the right to arbitrate.
The Rushfords say they won't give up. "It's something that Kaiser banks on, that you're not going to be able to afford to fight them," Mrs. Rushford said, adding that they are fortunate to have the financial means to pursue their fight. "Well, they picked the wrong person in this case."

HEADLINE: Trying to Sweeten a Bitter Pill By Getting More Severance Pay 

BYLINE:  By MARCI ALBOHER NUSBAUM 

 BODY:
YOUR company is cleaning house. Pink slips are flying like pollen in springtime, and you hear that one of them may be blowing your way. Is there anything you can do to extract added concessions when your supervisor delivers the bad news?
 In all likelihood, yes. As an employee, you may have more leverage than you think, even in this grim job market. Believe it or not, employers want to stay on your good side, because they know the time may be coming when they will want to have you back -- or at least, want you to speak well of them. 
 And believe it or not, the boss who is letting you go has feelings, too, and might even weaken if you come up with a compelling sob story. 
To be sure, the law does not generally require employers to give anything to people being let go unless there is an employment contract, says Philip M. Berkowitz, a partner at the law firm Seyfarth Shaw in New York who advises companies on employment matters. Typically, Mr. Berkowitz says, the legal obligation to pay severance or provide other benefits when employees are laid off comes from policies or procedures that an employer has voluntarily put into place.
Still, he says, an employer may respond to a situation of real need, like a medical condition for which you require extended health insurance coverage. "If you can show a particular hardship you could not have planned for, and if you're reasonable about it, most employers will at least consider whether there is a way to alleviate the problem," Mr. Berkowitz said. "The employer wants to have a trouble-free work force reduction. The more people who agree to go away quietly and sign releases the less the headache will be on everyone's part."
Vicky Oliver, a creative director who was laid off from the New York advertising agency DDB Needham three months before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, takes that advice one step further. Companies basically have a maximum dollar figure that they are willing to give in severance pay, she says. According to Ms. Oliver, if you negotiate hard, and make the case that your financial picture is dire, they are likely to let you have a bigger piece of the severance pie.
She recommends playing on your employer's heartstrings by describing the financial hardships you face, whether it is children to support, a life-threatening illness to treat or just the prospect of a long job search. Ms. Oliver, who has been doing research on workplace issues for a book she is writing about giving yourself a career makeover, says this approach really works.
You should do some research, too, she believes. Before she was laid off, she says, she took a look at the materials someone else in her company had received as part of an earlier downsizing. "I got a chance to see what the standard severance package was, and when it was delivered to me I went back and acted like I really needed more money, saying there were no jobs -- which turned out to be quite true," she said. "I even brought Kleenex with me. Tears work. In the end, I got more than the standard package."
Money is not the only thing on the table. Other benefits may be available, and according to experts, some things are easier for an employer to provide. Alexandra Duran, a New York-based career coach, says that outplacement services may be negotiable. "If you are offered the services of a large outplacement firm, you may be able to trade that benefit for the same amount of money applied to one-on-one counseling so that you don't get lost in the midst," she said.
She also suggests asking for a letter of reference, in writing, from a person in a position of authority. It is not enough for it to be beautifully written, she says; for maximum credibility, it should be filled with examples of your specific accomplishments. 
Richard Bayer, the chief operating officer of the Five O'Clock Club, an outplacement and career counseling firm in New York, says that even in the current economic environment, employees have some bargaining power. A company wants to maintain its good reputation, keep up morale, and most important, wants to be able to hire again when the market is good, he said, explaining that companies who mistreat employees on the way out risk losing all of those things, and can even suffer negative effects on their stock price.
His advice is to review your history with the company to see if you have done anything extraordinary, like relocating or contributing to a critical project. "You're looking for something that gives you a basis to say, 'I just want to be treated fairly,' " Mr. Bayer said.
The best way to survive a mass layoff is to avoid being on the dismissal list in the first place, of course, and there are strategies for that. Mr. Bayer suggests seeking assignments that make you more valuable to the company, for example.
The employees who tend to fare best in the face of a layoff are those who have planned for the possibility that their jobs will not last forever. Jonathan Levy, who was laid off in 2001 by Exodus Communications in Sunnyvale, Calif., an Internet data-center business, says the most important lesson he has learned is the value of having an employment contract with a negotiated severance provision. "If you don't have an agreement in place, you'll likely get the standard two weeks' notice and Cobra benefits," he said.
When Mr. Levy signed his contract, he said his primary responsibilities were to reorganize a department and to complete the construction of several Internet data sites which would help prepare the company for an eventual sale. Because of that, he says, it was important to him that the company would give him a choice of either receiving the remaining payments on his two-year contract or accelerating the vesting of his stock options in the event they terminated him at any time for reasons other than cause.
He says that the terms of such provisions should be carefully considered. For example, he says, a severance clause should be activated not only if you are terminated but if there is a change of control in the company that materially changes the nature of your job. He also suggests thinking of ways to get monetary value that are not connected to salary, like car payments, expenses for setting up a home office, or reimbursement for health care benefits.
While talking to a lawyer before beginning a job may be prudent, hiring one to put pressure on your employer on your way out may not be so wise.
"What a lot of employees do is come up with a claim that they've been a victim of discrimination because they feel they can put more pressure on an employer that way," said Mr. Berkowitz, the employment lawyer. "That's not what I'd recommend. If it's never been pursued before and comes out of left field, your employer won't want to establish the precedent of bowing to a frivolous claim."

HEADLINE: Mechanical Problem, Marketing Headache 

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN 

 BODY:
VOLKSWAGEN OF AMERICA is still struggling to mollify angry owners and nervous dealers over an ignition-coil problem that potentially affects more than half a million Volkswagen and Audi cars in the United States.
 The problem has been aggravated by Volkswagen's initial inability to replace all the coils on the cars instead of just the coils that failed. The affected cars have at least four coils, and some customers have had to return to their dealers three or four times -- sometimes waiting weeks for each coil replacement. The failure of a coil, which produces the high-voltage current that fires a spark plug, causes a loss of power. 
 As Volkswagen built up a supply of new coils, it changed the replacement policy, telling dealers to replace all coils on the second coil failure. Last week, the automaker told dealers they could replace all coils on the first coil failure, but only if the dealers had sufficient replacement coils in stock.
Dealers are receiving shipments of new coils weekly, said Steve Keyes, a spokesman for Volkswagen of America. If more coils fail than expected, dealers may not have enough new coils to replace all coils upon the first failure. If that happens, the customer could wait to bring in the car or could leave the car in the shop until the coils arrive, and the dealer will provide alternative transportation, Mr. Keyes said.
Ultimately, Volkswagen wants to replace all coils on potentially affected vehicles -- and may be able to do so by late May or early June, Mr. Keyes said. But the automaker must also keep enough coils for cars on the assembly line.
Based on the irate reactions of consumers to date, some dealers are expecting a decline in business.
"I think it hurts potential sales," said Fritz Hitchcock, owner of Puente Hills Volkswagen in City of Industry, Calif. "Repeat visits, even when they are paid for and handled properly, are not endearing."
Worried about the impact, Volkswagen's National Dealer Council asked the company to give current owners a $1,000 "loyalty coupon" for the future purchase of an Audi or Volkswagen. VW declined because of the cost.
"We are trying to take care of our customers by replacing their parts and making sure they have loaner cars," said Jennifer Cortez, a spokeswoman for Audi.
 EVEN without loyalty coupons, the price of replacing all the coils on the potentially affected cars in the United States could be $83 million, according to an analysis by Automotive News, an industry trade weekly.
Volkswagen and Audi have been consistently weak in customer satisfaction with dealer service, according to surveys by J. D. Power & Associates, a marketing research firm in Westlake Village, Calif.
Customers are complaining mainly about an inability to get quick service appointments, said Joe Ivers, executive director of J. D. Power's automotive quality and customer satisfaction research. He said the ignition-coil problem could make things worse. "The reason it matters, of course," Mr. Ivers said, "is that many customers will vote with their feet."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Opportunitiesfor the Steely of Heart

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
VENTURE capitalists are regarded as smart money -- wealthy professional investors who earn outsized returns by committing their capital and management experience to fledgling companies, mainly in fields like technology, communications and health care, before they are sold to the public.
 Though venture capital, a relatively obscure group of assets, has not been immune to the impact of the bear market of the last few years, its losses have generally been relatively mild. And its long-term returns remain high. 
 The United States receives more venture-capital investment than any other country, but small investors interested in stepping in have to travel a roundabout route to do so. The market is dominated by institutions and wealthy individuals who have an entree through private banks or other advisers; for the most part, American mutual fund managers have passed it by. 
But 20 venture capital funds, with track records of at least a year, are listed on the London Stock Exchange. They are available through brokers who trade on the exchange. Some are also listed in the pink sheets, the American over-the-counter market for small, infrequently traded securities.
The funds invest mainly in companies in the United States and Europe. 
When their returns are expressed in dollars, the funds listed in London lost 7.6 percent, on average, in the year through Thursday, according to Standard & Poor's, and 9.7 percent, annualized, over three years. They had an average annualized gain of 4.4 percent over five years, and 17.5 percent over 10 years.
Such performance suggests to venture-capital bulls that the period since the bursting of the technology bubble has been an aberration -- and that it has resulted in a buying opportunity.
"The whole global venture-capital industry went through a period of explosive growth in the late 1990's and 2000 on the back of expectations of a reworking of the world," said Jonathan Russell, global head of transactions at the 3i Group, the largest publicly traded venture capital fund. "People shouldn't confuse that short-term period of market excess with the long-term view of investing in venture capital."
The fund's portfolio contains a mix of technology businesses, including OmniGuide Communications, a Cambridge, Mass., company that is developing optical transmission systems; Top Layer Networks, based in Westboro, Mass., a maker of software for detecting attacks on computer systems; and SiGe Semiconductor, a company in Ottawa that supplies integrated circuits for optical and wireless communication systems.
Excesses of the technology bubble may have been purged, but if a buying opportunity is near, it will require buyers. And there are few of those. Investment in venture capital has declined practically every quarter since early 2000.
VENTURE capital investors focus as much on the amount of money flowing through the market as they do on price movements. Many transactions involving embryonic businesses are made privately, but in boom times like the late 1990's, stock offerings increase, allowing a graceful, and often very profitable, way out for venture capitalists. Until the number of deals picks up noticeably and new sources of capital enter the market, pessimists warn, prices are likely to remain depressed.
"There has been an increase in activity, but I wouldn't call that a turnaround," said Kamal Tabet, head of the European financial entrepreneurs group at Citigroup in London, which seeks investors for small companies. "The stock market would have to come back so that many of these people are going to feel good about exiting their investments and making additional ones. A key reason for people not moving is that they don't see the exit."
Doug Wurth, who is in charge of alternative investments, including venture capital and hedge funds, for Europe at the J. P. Morgan Private Bank, said the dearth of buyers had made prices more attractive for the few who can take the plunge.
"With investors likely reeling from losses in their public portfolios," he said, "this may be the exact right time to purchase private equity opportunities at what are relatively very good values."
In difficult market conditions, buyers in venture capital often have a lopsided advantage, said Bill Blevins, managing director of Blevins Franks International, a large firm of financial advisers in London that caters to wealthy individual investors. "The investor has to a larger extent than usual been able to carve out a better deal than would conventionally be the case," he said, "as the recipient has few other financial choices when the markets and the economy have been is such bad shape."
Blevins Franks does little venture capital investment, though it occasionally plays matchmaker, linking clients with small companies that are looking for financing. For investors with modest bank balances, it is best to stick with a fund that spreads money among many smaller businesses, Mr. Blevins said.
Small investors interested in venture capital could do worse than to enter the market through the funds listed in London, said Paul Locke, who follows British closed-end funds for HSBC.
"Some have done quite well; they certainly have their fans, and I'm one of them," Mr. Locke said. He finds opportunity in the fact that many people disagree. Share prices for the funds are typically far below the intrinsic values of their portfolios, in extreme cases close to 40 percent, after having traded at premiums two or three years ago. So it is possible to buy a fund that has beaten the stock market consistently and pay barely more than 60 cents on the dollar.
MR. LOCKE explained that some venture-capital funds, including 3i, Candover, Dunedin Enterprise Investment Trust , Graphite Enterprise Trust and JZ Equity Partners, build their own portfolios. Others, like Schroder Ventures International Investment Trust, Pantheon International Participations and Standard Life European Private Equity Trust, are funds of funds, in which the managers invest not directly in companies but in broad venture capital portfolios, providing an additional layer of diversification.
Among the first group, Mr. Locke says he especially likes JZ. A strong performer in the past, it has fallen on hard times, losing 10.3 percent in dollars in the year ended Feb. 21, though that reflects a widening in the discount to 32 percent, near its highest ever.
The 3i fund, which always finds market demand because it is included in the benchmark FTSE-100 index, recently carried a 22 percent discount, which Mr. Locke called "quite attractive." Another fund that he says has a wide and "slightly overdone" discount is Mercury Grosvenor Trust.
A good fund of funds for investors interested in global diversification is Schroder Ventures, he said. It has risen 40.1 percent in the last year, the best performance in the sector. The fund "always seems to do a good job," Mr. Locke said.
"It has the liquidity to sit out these bumps, the discount is fair, and it has had pretty good performance lately," he added.
He suggested that the bumps would give way to a smooth ride over the long haul. "The enterprise culture is still there, and there are always people with good ideas," he said. "These funds are out of vogue and will remain so for at least another year, but when risk appetite comes back, these funds are going to come good again."

HEADLINE: At School Auctions, Prestige Is the Prize 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
ON any other school night, Tuttle Hall -- as the gymnasium of Grace Church School in Manhattan is known -- would have been dark, the children long ago dismissed and the thumping of their sneakers on the parquet a forgotten echo.
 But on the March weeknight the school held its "Caribbean Jump Up" party and benefit auction, the gym rocked with the calypso music of a steel band. School parents, do-rags on their heads, sipped rum drinks and danced barefoot in the sand (trucked in for the evening) beneath potted palms. 
 And then they began to spend their money, on items up for bid that included a vacation in the Tuscan countryside, donated by two school parents; two tickets to the Vanity Fair Oscar party, donated by Graydon Carter, also a parent; artwork by Barbara Kruger, donated by Geraldine Ferraro, a Grace Church School grandparent; and a chance to be an extra on "Law & Order," donated by a parent who is a television producer.
As the auctioneer spurred the crowd on, a few dutiful husbands clutched their plastic glasses of rum punch and stood guard over the more coveted items in the accompanying silent auction, ready to alert their wives if anyone wrote in a higher bid for the Tod's weekend bag or the Temple St. Clair Carr ring. 
At the end of the night, Grace Church School, a private day school for boys and girls from prekindergarten through eighth grade, had cleared a good chunk of change. Although the tally was not quite complete at week's end, "we're hoping to net $300,000," said George P. Davison, the school head.
It's spring auction season at private schools from coast to coast, a staple of the annual fund-raising drive that has assumed even greater importance at a time when endowments are stalled by the stock market plunge. More than a fund-raising tool, the school auction, as thousands of parents know, is an exquisitely calculated social occasion replete with opportunities to flaunt one's good fortune, feel the sting of humiliation and swell with self-satisfaction at belonging to such a select community.
Part pep rally and part cocktail party, the school auction -- mostly held at private schools but sometimes at parochial and public schools -- is effective even in a down market, because parents are typically lubricated with cocktails and then pitched dizzily into a battlefield where egos and normally hidden agendas can clash in the open. The bidding can drive Type A parents into a frenzy.
"It is at the very tippy-tippy-top levels, when the bidding starts and it gets moving, that at the best schools there is always a core group that buys the big items," said Victoria Goldman, a co-author of "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools and Selective Public Schools" (Soho Press). "Of course, it is good for the school, but it's not exactly anonymous paddles. People look -- they know."
At past auctions at Grace Church School, parents have engaged in public bidding battles for items like a trip on the Orient Express.
"One year there were two very determined fathers battling over the class quilt," Mr. Davison said. "That can get sort of embarrassing."
And if parents can become aggressive participants in a "my wallet is bigger than yours" competition, the catalogs showing off the merchandise -- which are sent out in advance -- can also convey messages about status.
"The catalogs are meant to whet the appetite but also to showboat," said Sandra R. Bass, a private-school parent who is also the publisher of The Private School Insider, a newsletter. "Everybody sits and looks through the catalog and says: 'Oh my goodness, look what our parents have been able to put together. Look at how wonderful it is that we're at this school, with this group of very high-powered people.' "
Some parents construe the catalogs as not so subtle hints about other families' wealth or connections. In the list of items up for auction at Grace Church School, for instance, parents learned that one couple has houses on not one but two Greek islands, that another family has an art collection so vast and spectacular that it can afford to donate expensive pieces for auction and that yet another owns a famous restaurant.
The school auction, one Grace Church parent said, is a chance to feel . . . well, puny.
"You get to see where they have a country house, or whether they have a yacht, or whether they have access to famous people," said this parent, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "So of course you're going to feel like a jerk if you give something small."
Mr. Davison said that part of his school's dynamic is that it has students from every sector of the financial spectrum. No parent, he said, is meant to feel belittled by the size of his donation. "In order for a school to be economically diverse and an event to be successful at all levels," he said, "we need to have donations that go for $125 and for $12,000."
The fact that the only gifts listed as anonymous for the Grace Church School auction were the small ones -- things like "a pair of burgundy sheepskin slippers with gray curly lining in European size 27" and a bottle of Donna Karan Cashmere eau de cologne spray -- suggested to one parent that having one's name attached to such a donation was considered just too embarrassing. But a parent on the auction committee said that many items listed anonymously are actually examples of recycling -- "regifting," as she put it.
At the Calhoun School in Manhattan, which held its live auction on Wednesday, it was the reverse. The expensive items, like a trip to a private ski-resort chalet, were listed as having been given by "a Calhoun family." Smaller ticket items, like a tooth whitening by a "Calhoun parent/dentist," clearly stated the donor's name.
"Unfortunately, there is a lot of ego involved in who is giving this and who is giving that," said Jean C. Joachim, the author of "Beyond the Bake Sale: The Ultimate School Fund-Raising Book" (St. Martin's Press, 2003). Ms. Joachim, who ran an auction at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side for several years, said school auctions can be opportunities for embarrassment, especially among private-school parents -- "the Type AAA-plus personalities."
Listing donors' names alongside their gifts, she said, turns the auction into a competition that ultimately damages overall parental feelings of good will. Instead, she said, the catalog should separate the donors' names from their gifts, so that nothing is immediately associated with one family or one student.
"To be honest, I have never noticed any differentiation," Mr. Davison said. "Besides, I don't think that's the case."
For every parent who complains about feeling not rich enough and not cool enough, there is one who is positively, goofily exuberant.
At the City and Country School, a private school for prekindergarten through eighth grade students on West 13th Street, this year's auction, held last Sunday, raised about $120,000, said Becky Ann Baker, one of the parents on the organizing committee."It was a real bonding experience for the parents," she said. "To be honest, it was thrilling."
Erica Stearns, a parent who also worked on the City and Country auction, said the auction was fun, a social evening -- and she liked the 80's theme.
"After the live auction, we turned the music up, and it was like, whoa, 80's flashback!" she said. "I got dressed up -- Cyndi Lauper meets Madonna, fishnets and Doc Martens. We had a blast."
In the past decade private schools have been putting a lot of muscle into the benefit auctions. At the stratum of society from which they draw most of their students, there are more stay-at-home mothers with time to participate in the organizing drives, which take months. Parents are also concerned about showing their commitment to their children's schools at a time when some private kindergartens are turning hundreds of applicants away for each class.
But mostly, it's about the money.
Mr. Davison of Grace Church School said all the money raised by the auction goes to help financial-aid recipients. "We're not using this money to buy baseball uniforms, or fancy toys for our children," he said.
That is not the case at all schools. Generally, the bulk of the money raised is unrestricted, Ms. Bass said, "so they can do with it what they will."
Jamie Niven, the Sotheby's auctioneer, who has officiated at many private school auctions, said he has sold a Memorial Day weekend in a private home in Newport for about $4,000, Super Bowl tickets (several thousand dollars, he said) and dinner for four at Rao's ($2,800). Because the auctions are charitable, there are typically no reserve bids, or minimum prices that will be accepted.
Schools and parents especially like one-of-a-kind donations that have no measurable cash value, like a walk-on part in a television show, because of their favored tax treatment.
"The beauty of that is that if something has no cash value and you buy it at auction, everything you pay is tax-deductible," Mr. Davison said. So parents have an incentive to to bid high.
At the 92nd Street Y nursery school in Manhattan, celebrity parents like Michael J. Fox and Kevin Kline have in recent years donated such big-ticket items as a walk-on part in "Spin City" or a chance to have Mr. Kline recite postprandial sonnets to the winning bidder's dinner guests, a former 92nd Street Y parent said.
The Center for Early Education, a nursery and elementary school in West Hollywood, has auctioned off a meal for 16 cooked by Wolfgang Puck at the buyer's home and a round of golf with Michael Jordan. At the City and Country School, bidders could vie for a consultation with a Botox-dispensing dermatologist, the use of a villa in the Dominican Republic and tickets to a party held by Teen Vogue.
This year, perhaps the most talked-about item at any auction is one for the Riverdale Country School, which will hold its auction at Sotheby's in April: dinner with Alex Rodriguez, the star shortstop of the Texas Rangers, donated by Steven C. Witkoff, a real estate investor and parent.
Despite the pall over the economy, many school officials said they have not noticed that parents are any less willing to raise their auction paddles. Receipts are comparable with those in previous years.
But some describe a slight chill this season. One mother called it "the Grubman effect" -- a reference to Jack B. Grubman, the former Salomon Smith Barney analyst who boasted in e-mail messages that he had used his financial influence to get his children into the nursery school at the 92nd Street Y. She said that the example of Mr. Grubman, who has resigned from Salomon and has been barred from the securities industry for life, has become a cautionary tale among private-school parents, who see him as an Upper East Side Icarus whose ego outmatched his ambitions for his children.
This woman, whose daughter goes to the Nightingale-Bamford School in Manhattan, said she would attend this year's auction in May, but did not plan to hold up her paddle on any big-ticket items for fear of prompting other parents to think she was a financial braggart.
"We're definitely sitting on our hands during the auction," she said.
"It's not about not giving money this year. You have to do that. But it's about looking quieter about it."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH -- Robert W. Gadsden and Samuel A. Lieber; 
Alpine Realty Income and Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
BARGAIN real estate is the focus of the $77 million Alpine Realty Income and Growth fund, which owns shares of real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, and of companies in the industry.
 "We want to buy real estate on Wall Street for discounts to what people pay on Main Street," said Samuel A. Lieber, the chief investment officer of the fund, in Manhattan. 
 But how they define bargains depends on the turning of the economic cycle, added Robert W. Gadsden, the fund's manager. Right now, he said, "we're looking for companies that are niche leaders in a specialized aspect of the real estate business, either by property type or business model." 
The fund returned 19.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing in the top 3 percent of real estate funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. The group returned 13.6 percent, annualized, compared with a 14.4 percent loss in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The fund returned 4.4 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 3.2 percent for its group and 27.3 percent for the S.& P. 
Mr. Gadsden is also the senior real estate analyst at Alpine Management and Research, the fund's investment adviser, while Mr. Lieber is chief executive of that firm. Mr. Lieber was the fund's original manager, beginning in 1998; Mr. Gadsden joined him as co-manager in September 1999 and became manager at the end of 2000.
In January 2003, Alpine merged with Saxon Woods Advisors, owned by Mr. Lieber's father, Stephen, to create Alpine Woods Investments, now the parent of both firms.
To pick the fund's 60 or so issues, Mr. Gadsden and Mr. Lieber make an economic forecast for the next year and evaluate how various real estate sectors might perform. They expect economic growth to accelerate later this year, Mr. Lieber said, but he added that "we're not sure that it will be strong enough to absorb the existing supply for the next couple of years."
Next, they review supply and demand in property markets around the country, looking at variables like existing capacity and job formation. "New jobs create demand for office space and industrial space," Mr. Gadsden said, "and, ultimately, homes and shopping centers."
The fund has a 28 percent stake in the retail sector, including regional malls and suburban shopping centers, versus 22 percent for its benchmark, the Morgan Stanley REIT index. "Consumer spending appears more resilient than corporate spending," Mr. Lieber said.
The fund has 10 percent of its assets in residential apartments, versus 20 percent for the index. "Landlords have had very high occupancy rates and pricing power, but lower interest rates make homebuying a more attractive alternative," Mr. Gadsden said.
In researching individual companies, the fund seeks annual returns on equity of at least 12 percent, growing dividends and manageable debt. Because real estate is so cyclical, Mr. Lieber said, experienced management is important.
"People who are great deal makers may do well in the growth part of the cycle but flounder when the cycle turns," he said. "We like all-weather management."
The fund recently added shares of the Chelsea Property Group, a REIT in Roseland, N.J., that owns, develops and manages outlet malls like Woodbury Common Premium Outlets in Central Valley, N.Y.
Chelsea Property dominates the outlet-mall niche of the market, Mr. Gadsden said. The fund began buying shares in January 1999 and has paid $27.76, on average, adjusted for stock splits, for the entire position; the shares now trade at $36.50.
The fund has also added shares of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, a REIT based in Pasadena, Calif., and a specialist in laboratory space. "They rent to companies to use for research and development," Mr. Gadsden said, "so their assets are where these companies want to be" -- markets like Boston, Washington and the San Francisco Bay area. The company also has the technical expertise to develop the infrastructure these companies need, he added.
The fund first bought shares in September 2000, and its average cost for the entire position has been $39.46. The stock now trades at $41.52.
Another holding is iStar Financial, formerly Starwood Financial, in New York, which finances commercial real estate. The company has expertise in complex financial transactions that give it a bigger profit margin than competitors who write typical mortgages, Mr. Gadsden said.
The fund started buying shares in November 1999 and has paid $27.15 a share, on average, for its position. The stock closed on Friday at $28.50.
