HEADLINE: Lobstermen Look for Answers 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE NADEL 

 BODY:
EIGHT men sat back to back at two adjoining booths on the 7:30 a.m. ferry to Bridgeport on March 7, keeping to themselves, speaking quietly in deep voices, like guests at a funeral. These solid-looking men, with thick, calloused hands and heavy clothing made for outdoor work, plainly were not part of the usual crowd of commuters and casino day-trippers.
 They were lobstermen, and they were on their way to another scientific dissection of an event that has threatened their livelihoods: a still-mysterious Long Island Sound lobster die-off that began in 1999. 
 "Most of the guys haven't checked their gear for months -- there's nothing to check," said George Dahl, chairman of the New York Lobster Conservation Management Team and vice president of the Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association. 
John Davi, 39, a lobsterman from Port Jefferson, N.Y., said that between late September and the end of last year he lost money every time he took out his boat, at a cost of about $600 a day for bait, fuel and labor. "Things were good five years ago," he said. "We lost a lot of lobsters." 
So Mr. Dahl and his colleagues had plenty of time to go to Bridgeport for the third annual lobster health symposium, sponsored by the Sea Grant Projects of New York and Connecticut, to hear the scientists report on their latest attempts to find out why the Sound's lobsters have been dying.
Long Island Sound lobster landings, reported at 10.4 million pounds in 1998 by the New York Department of Environmental Conservation and the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, dropped to 3.6 million pounds in 2000. After a slight decline in 2001, last year's harvest plunged again, to an estimated 2.5 million pounds. 
"Until September of last year, we were having a fair year," said John German, 55, president of the Long Island Lobstermen's Association. "Then in September-October, there was a major die-off. This year, I'd predict a couple of hundred thousands pounds, if that. The lowest ever." 
Lobstermen are close-mouthed about their income, which makes it hard to get accurate estimates of their financial losses. But in 2002, there were 414 licensed lobstermen in Connecticut, down from 538 in 1998. In New York, there were 600 in 2001, the last year for which complete figures are available.
For the lobstermen, there is little love lost between them and the scientists.
"There are a lot of bean counters here, but the fishermen are suffering," said Nick Crismali, 52, of Guilford, president of the Connecticut Lobstermen's Association. "I'm just interested in knowing where your program is going now that the fishermen are disappearing." 
Carl LoBue of the New York D.E.C. responded, "We recognize that if it wasn't for fishermen, we wouldn't be in this room." But neither Mr. LoBue nor the four scientists who presented their findings on environmental stressors, physiological responses to stress, parasites and pesticides could predict when the situation would improve, and none had an explanation for the disaster that could satisfy the lobstermen. 
Alistair Dove, a senior research associate at the Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine who runs a shellfish pathology lab at Stony Brook University, identified a fatal disease called calcinosis in 20 lobsters analyzed between August and October of last year. Calcinosis, in which stony deposits form in the lobster's gills, causing respiratory failure, is caused by excess calcium. This is the first time this disease has shown up in Long Island Sound lobsters.
Dr. Dove also hypothesized that warm water temperatures during the summers of 2001 and 2002 stressed the lobsters' immune systems so that they were vulnerable to infection. Further, the warm water created favorable conditions for paramoebas and parasites. 
The most hotly debated topic pertaining to the die-off is whether pesticides sprayed against West Nile virus-bearing mosquitoes in 1999 were washed into the Sound a few days after Hurricane Floyd swept through the region, killing the lobsters. Jack Mattice, 61, director of the New York Sea Grant program in Riverhead, doubted the pesticides were to blame.
"The lobsters started dying before the first pesticides were sprayed in 1999," Mr. Mattice said.
The night before the conference in Bridgeport, fishermen learned that a lawsuit filed on their behalf against the pesticide manufacturer Cheminova was granted class certification status. The suit charges Cheminova with causing economic harm to the lobstermen after its pesticide Fyfanon, a malathion product, was sprayed in Nassau and Suffolk counties in 1999.
Cheminova's attorney, Christopher Kelly, did not respond to telephone calls seeking comment.
"Class certification is one step on a long road," said Gladstone Jones, a New Orleans environmental lawyer who is representing the lobstermen on both sides of the Sound. He predicted that the case would go before a jury in federal court in Islip, N.Y. this fall, at which time 300 to 500 lobstermen will be named as plaintiffs. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nick Crismali of Guilford, president of the Connecticut Lobstermen's Association, asking a question during the symposium. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wages at Issue for Building Owners and Service Workers 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Facing a contract deadline of April 21, owners of New York City apartment buildings and the union representing 28,000 doormen, janitors and other building service workers, agree that negotiations are going to be tough because of hard times for the city's economy and its real estate industry.
 The current three-year contract covers building service employees at 3,000 buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens with a smattering on Staten Island and in Nassau County. It expires at 12:01 a.m. April 21, the day after Easter and four days after the start of Passover. 
 The union and the building owners and managers agree that wages are likely to be the biggest obstacle. Management officials say they want a wage freeze of one year or more with lump sum payments instead of raises; the union is seeking raises of at least several percent a year to keep up with inflation. 
"I think the toughest issue is going to be wages," said James F. Berg, president of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which handles negotiations for many owners and managers of large buildings. "We're going to try to work out a deal that is probably a little sparser than usual because of the tough economic times we're having."
But Michael Fishman, president of the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, said the proposed wage freeze would be a big problem for workers covered by the contract, who include elevator operators, superintendents and people who make repairs.
"We're looking for a wage increase in all three years," he said, but would not be more specific. "We're saying we want a fair wage increase every year. The cost of daily living is continuing to go up."
Every three years before the building workers' contract comes up for renewal, raising the specter of a strike, building owners and managers warn apartment residents about possible disruptions and delays in sorting mail, making repairs and cleaning common areas.
Mr. Fishman said that he would not rule out a strike, but that he wanted to avoid one.
"I would hope there doesn't have to be a strike," he said.
"Both of us are coming to the table understanding we're facing a time when it doesn't serve the union's interests, the industry's interests, the public's or the city's to have a strike."
The union is urging management to agree to far-reaching safety training, which would include teaching workers how to handle suspicious packages and coordinate emergencies with police officers and firefighters.
"Our members are put in harm's way," Mr. Fishman said. "We're on the front line. We're asked to check out a lot of things in the building. We want our members to be safe."
The union argues that management can easily afford significant raises, noting that co-op and condominium prices as well as apartment rents are higher than in 1999. But real estate officials note that co-op and condo prices and apartment rents have generally been softer since the terrorist attack a year and a half ago.
"With the property tax increases and the increases in the price of oil and increased costs for insurance," Mr. Berg said, "a tremendous burden has been put on the buildings in terms of operating costs."
Under the existing contract, most porters and janitors earn $34,350 a year, while repair workers earn $37,840. That contract allowed for annual wage and benefit increases of 3.3 percent, 3.2 percent and 3.9 percent, which industry officials noted was higher than the inflation rate.
The union has called on management to increase its annual contributions for health insurance and pensions and to end its practice of paying new building service workers 20 percent less than other workers during their first 30 months on the job.

HEADLINE: War, or Peace, in Iraq? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leadership is more than simply making up one's mind and proceeding on a course of action, heedless of the consequences. 
Yet that is what the Bush administration has done with regard to Iraq (front page, March 14).
 In the name of goals it has neither clarified nor successfully defended, the Bush administration has squandered decades of international cooperation, increased the likelihood that fundamentalist terrorists will attack us, spent untold sums on an ill-advised military buildup and endangered the health of our economy. 
 At this point, the question for Americans to ponder is how the administration might extricate itself from the box in which it has seemingly trapped itself.

DAVID D. PLATT
Yarmouth, Me., March 14, 2003

HEADLINE: McGreevey To Give Back Arts Funds 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
FACING a highly organized and unrelenting swell of criticism throughout the state over plans to eliminate all financial support for cultural institutions, Governor McGreevey will now press for the restoration of at least half of the funds that had been earmarked for the arts, according to high-ranking administration officials.
 "A decision has been made to find the means to provide funding for arts communities across the state," said James P. Fox, Governor McGreevey's chief of staff. 
 While sources in the governor's office said it was "not fully realistic" for the New Jersey State Council on the Arts to expect to have its entire $18 million budget restored, about 50 percent of that amount -- which the arts community had been pleading for since the governor announced the cuts last month -- would not be unreasonable.
"We will be working with the Legislature to do it," Eric Shuffler, counselor to Governor McGreevey said. "It's a very fluid process. We might have some ideas where the money can come from and the legislators might have other ideas. But it starts with a determination, and that's where we are now." 
The concession on the arts issue marks the first gambit in what is certain to be a drawn-out budget battle between the governor's office, the Legislature and constituent groups. Nearly six weeks after going public with his budget proposal, Mr. McGreevey and his staff recognized it was time to "enter a different phase," as one administration official put it.
With theater audiences in the state being bombarded nightly with anti-McGreevey messages and a postcard and letter-writing campaign in full swing, administration officials concede that they might have underestimated the power of the arts community, while overplaying their hand in slashing the arts funds in an effort to chip away at the state's $5 billion budget shortfall.
"This was a particularly difficult decision for the governor to make," a source close to Mr. McGreevey said. "If we had to do it all over again, I don't think we'd cut it to zero."
The proposed cuts were expected to affect about 700 arts organizations and projects in the state, 150 of which receive grants directly from the New Jersey Council on the Arts, with the remaining 550 groups being financed by state dollars that are funneled through county arts agencies. The $18 million that the council received for the current fiscal year was down $2 million from the previous year, although most of that was made up last fall through other grants. 
Restoration of the financing for the arts will still require legislative approval, and the specific amount to be allocated may not be known until the process is completed in early summer. Since announcing a number of draconian measures last month in an effort to reduce the budget, the governor has had some general discussions with legislators, though he has not informed them of his intention to restore funds for the arts, according to Mr. Shuffler. 
He declined to speculate on what other programs might have to be cut to come up with the money for the arts, but he emphasized that the funds would have to found within the existing budget, reiterating the governor's vow not to increase taxes. 
For now, the governor's office is trying to piece together a second, more immediate source of funds for the arts, tourism and cultural organizations by tapping into the resources of the state's economic development authorities. This could siphon off as much as $5 million to $10 million from such agencies as the New Jersey Economic Development Authority and the Delaware River Port Authority, Mr. Shuffler said. 
"We're looking at using the power of the economic development authorities to support the arts and tourism because these are economic development engines," Mr. Shuffler said, noting that this source of money could be available in as little as two months.
"Our goal is to keep these arts groups sustained until we can increase state funding," the governor's counselor said. "What we'll be looking to offer is not going to be something trivial. But at the same time, they have to respect the fact that spending is down everywhere and they'll have to do some belt-tightening of their own."
Restoring funds for the arts became the governor's first priority for both personal and political reasons, a high-ranking aide to the governor said. Of all the stringent measures Governor McGreevey proposed in his 2004 budget -- including the elimination of 109 grant programs, a 12 percent cut in state funds for higher education, a $76 million reduction in the state's Family Care Program that helps insure children of the working poor and increases in hotel and casino gaming taxes -- the cuts in arts spending created the greatest furor, even though it represents only one-tenth of 1 percent of the budget.
While playing down the political motivation behind the decision to restore money for the arts, one official conceded that the battle had become very heated.
"We understand the process is now changing," the official said. "It is O.K .to let people know that we're not automatons, marching ahead in lock step, not listening to anyone."
In his budget address before both houses of the Legislature on Feb. 4, Governor McGreevey did not mince words about his plans for the arts. "We have made unprecedented cuts in culture and the arts," he said, "eliminating entirely all Arts Council grants, the Cultural Trust, the Historical Commission and the Historic Site Management Program." 
On a subsequent whistle-stop tour of diners throughout the state just days later, he continued to emphasize the drastic measures necessary for grappling with the state's budget shortfall because of the sharp drop in income tax revenue and escalating costs of state programs. 
While the budgets of most departments in the state were reduced by 10 or 15 percent, the Department of State, which oversees the Arts Council, had its financing slashed by close to 90 percent, with the Arts Council having the distinction of being the only agency whose funds were entirely eliminated.
It did not take long for the arts community to complain bitterly. For one thing, some of the state's wealthiest and most influential individuals sit on the boards of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the New Jersey Symphony, the McCarter Theater and other prominent arts institutions. And the venues themselves quickly organized and put out the message to patrons that the governor had made a mistake.

Bombing Every Night
Night after night throughout the state, performances and concerts have been delayed for a few minutes as theater officials fill audiences in on Governor McGreevey's plan to eliminate funds for the arts and urge them to call on their elected officials. 
In addition, ArtsPride New Jersey initiated a letter-writing campaign, with 250,000 postcards being handed out to patrons of theaters, museums and historic sites throughout the state to be filled out and delivered to the Legislature this spring.
At a gathering in Westfield last week that was organized by State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., about 100 representatives from various arts and cultural organizations arrived at a decision to start scheduling appointments with their state legislators. And high school and college students have been organizing petition drives.
Through these tactics, elected officials and the public have been made more aware of the proposed arts cuts than perhaps any other aspect of the governor's budget.
"These are wealthy, educated, sophisticated groups who have done a very good job," Mr. Shuffler said. "They've gotten their point across."
As Lawrence Goldman, executive director of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, said recently, "This has unleashed sources even greater than the governor thought were out there in support of the arts."
Each night at the Performing Arts Center, curtain speeches have been greeted by a round of boos for the governor. "It's been very encouraging to see that the people of New Jersey at all levels, from the neighborhood to the schools to the philanthropists really give a damn about the arts," Mr. G0ldman said.
Arts programs have historically been targeted when fiscal constraints require government belt-tightening. Twelve years ago, financing for arts was cut in half by Gov. James Florio.
With 46 states now struggling with severe budget crises because of losses in federal aid and a struggling economy, New Jersey is not the only state taking a hard look at its arts programs. The governor of Missouri has also recommended eliminating that state's arts council, while a legislative committee in Arizona is debating a similar measure. 
If New Jersey -- or either of these other two states -- succeeded in eliminating financing for the arts, that would place it in the rare position of being the only state to have no mechanism in place for supporting the arts, or for serving as a matching recipient of national arts funds. 
Despite its recent emphasis on homeland security and military spending, even the federal government managed to find additional funds for the arts, increasing the National Endowment for the Arts budget by $10 million, to $126 million, for fiscal year 2003. Without a state arts agency, New Jersey would risk losing its share of funds from the endowment, which last year amounted to more than $2 million. 
In its effort to lobby Trenton, the arts community has argued not only for the intrinsic value of arts and culture for New Jersey's citizenry, but also for the fiscal benefits derived from hundreds cultural and historical sites throughout the state.
In a 2000 study by Rutgers University's Graduate School of Education, arts and cultural organizations were credited with generating $27 million in state taxes, and contributing $1 billion to the state's economy, including everything from ticket sales to ancillary tourism spending.

Hearing a Mixed Message
One aspect the arts community has found most frustrating in the budget debate has been the mixed messages delivered by the governor. In a speech last July before hundreds of representatives of the arts community, Governor McGreevey acknowledged what he called a "lack of predictability with the state government", and went on to offer a "fiscal commitment between the State of New Jersey and the arts community so that over the next three-and-a-half years there is a high degree of predictability and consistency within the arts community."
In defending the state's decision to turn its back on the arts, members of the McGreevey administration said they could not predict at that time the size of the deficit the state would be facing this year, which would require drastic cuts across the board. The argument also became one of priorities. 
"We have 70,000 people losing health insurance," said Mr. Shuffler. "It's harder to justify spending on items such as the arts when you are cutting health insurance for the poorest of the poor." 
In addition to restoring funds for the arts, he said the governor would also like to find a way to restore some funds for higher education and health care. But with the arts budget representing only a small fraction of the budget, the official said that it was easier to replenish those funds.
"It's easier to make an impact by restoring 50 percent of the arts funding than it is to restore 50 percent of some of the other cuts," Mr. Shuffler said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In his budget address, Governor McGreevey, left, declared: "We have made unprecedented cuts in culture and the arts." Criticism followed, leading Lawrence Goldman of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, far left, to say that "sources even greater than the governor thought were out there in support of the arts." (Keith Meyers/The New York Times, and, above, Annie McCormick for The New York Times)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: What's Killing the Lobsters? 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE NADEL 

DATELINE: PORT JEFFERSON 

 BODY:
EIGHT men sat back to back at two adjoining booths on the 7:30 a.m. ferry to Bridgeport on March 7, keeping to themselves, speaking quietly in deep voices, like guests at a funeral. These weather-beaten, solid-looking men, with thick, calloused hands and heavy clothing made for outdoor work, plainly were not part of the crowd of commuters and casino day-trippers.
 They were lobstermen, and they were on their way to another scientific dissection of an event that has threatened their livelihoods: the still-mysterious die-off of lobsers in Long Island Sound that began in 1999. 
 "Most of the guys haven't checked their gear for months -- there's nothing to check," said George Dahl, chairman of the New York Lobster Conservation Management Team and vice president of the Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association. The cold winter had covered many harbors with ice, he said, making it impossible for many lobstermen to get to their traps. 
 John Davi, 39, a lobsterman from Port Jefferson who sails out of Mount Sinai, said that between late September and the end of last year he lost money every time he took out his boat, at a cost of $600 a day for bait, fuel and labor. "Things were good five years ago," he said. "We lost a lot of lobsters." 
Mr. Dahl, a 57-year-old Northport resident, said that when he last checked 400 of his 2,000 traps in December, his catch was a mere 25 lobsters. "How much money can you afford to lose before you stop?" he asked.
So Mr. Dahl and his colleagues had plenty of time to go to Bridgeport for the third annual lobster health symposium, sponsored by the Sea Grant Projects of New York and Connecticut, to hear the scientists report on their latest attempts to find out why the Sound's lobsters have been dying. 
For centuries, lobstering was a profitable occupation in the Sound. Local lobstermen grew up working as mates on family-owned boats before becoming captains of their own vessels. That traditional way of life suffered a shock in the fall of 1999 when, almost overnight, more than 90 percent of the lobsters hauled up in the western Sound were dead.
"It was the strangest thing," said Joe Finke, president of the Western Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association. "They looked perfectly healthy when we hauled them up, but a lot of them were dead."
Mr. Finke, 47, who lives in Bayville and sails out of Glen Cove, recalled packing the few healthy lobsters for market, only to receive a call from the wholesaler in Point Lookout saying all of the shipment was dead on arrival. 
Lobster landings in the Sound, reported at 10.4 million pounds in 1998 by the New York Department of Environmental Conservation and the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, dropped to 3.6 million pounds in 2000. After a slight decline in 2001, last year's harvest plunged again, to an estimated 2.5 million pounds. 
"Until September of last year, we were having a fair year," said John German, 55, president of the Long Island Lobstermen's Association. "Then in September-October, there was a major die-off. This year, I'd predict a couple of hundred thousands pounds, if that. The lowest ever." 
"If the lobsters don't show up by May, a lot of guys will pack it in," said Mr. German, who sails out of Mount Sinai and lives in Brookhaven. "Next year's figures will really tell the tale." 
The die-off has already proved fatal to many lobstermen's livelihoods. "We've had three years to adjust, but the loss is never going to pass," said Mr. Finke, who now charters his boat to scientists from the New York Sea Grant Project to haul traps for lab research.
Lobstering, a cash business, is part of the underground economy. Lobstermen are close-mouthed about their income, which makes it hard to get accurate estimates of their financial losses. But in 1997 there were 888 licensed lobstermen in New York State. By 2001, the last year for which complete figures are available, the number had dropped to 600. In Connecticut, the 1998 total was 538, and in 2002 it was 414.
As the ferry docked in Bridgeport, the lobstermen looked as if they were being forced to spend Thanksgiving with relatives they didn't like. "These meetings are useless," said Mr. Dahl, for whom a satisfying day's work used to mean standing on the pitching steel deck of his boat and hauling in several hundred wire traps filled with mud-covered sea life that might or might not include lobsters. On a good day, Mr. Dahl would bring home as much as 700 pounds of the Sound's most profitable shellfish. 
For the lobstermen, there is little love lost between them and the scientists. The prevalent view is that the academics depend on the lobster die-off for their research funds and are in no rush to restore the resource. Mr. Dahl contends that none of the money spent on experiments is helping the lobstermen or bringing back the lobsters.
"In 2001, at the first forum, the scientists said they had to use us in their research because we had knowledge of the resource," he said. "They got their money, and then they wanted nothing to do with us."
Nick Crismali, president of the Connecticut Lobstermen's Association, expressed a similar point of view. "There are a lot of bean counters here, but the fishermen are suffering," said a Mr. Crismali, 52, of Guilford. "I'm just interested in knowing where your program is going now that the fishermen are disappearing." 
Carl LoBue of the New York D.E.C. responded, "We recognize that if it wasn't for fishermen, we wouldn't be in this room." But neither Mr. LoBue nor the four scientists who presented findings on environmental stresses, physiological responses to stress, parasites and pesticides could predict when the situation would improve, and none had an explanation for the disaster that satisfied the lobstermen. For example, all Carmela Cuomo, a geology professor at Yale, could say was that "something funky is going on in September and October." 
Alistair Dove, a senior research associate at the Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine who runs a shellfish pathology lab at Stony Brook University, reported on a fatal disease called calcinosis found in 20 lobsters analyzed from August to October last year. Calcinosis, in which stony deposits form in the lobster's gills, causing respiratory failure, is caused by excess calcium. This was the first time this disease has shown up in Long Island Sound lobsters.
Dr. Dove, a 29-year-old Coram resident, hypothesized that warm water temperatures during the summers of 2001 and 2002 stressed the lobsters' immune systems so that they were vulnerable to infection. Further, the warm water created favorable conditions for paramoebas and parasites. 
Whether they are just a natural variation or a sign of global warming, higher water temperatures are beyond the control of those who live near the Sound or make a living on it. But Dr. Dove was not ready to discount pollution as a factor. "Paramoebae and parasites can have a role," he said. "Pesticides could be a factor. It can easily be a multifactorial problem."
The most hotly debated topic pertaining to the die-off is whether it was caused by pesticides sprayed against mosquitoes in 1999, then washed into the Sound a few days after Hurricane Floyd swept through.
Jack Mattice, 61, director of the New York Sea Grant program in Riverhead, doubts that pesticides were to blame. "The lobsters started dying before the first pesticides were sprayed in 1999," Mr. Mattice said.
He also argued that the pattern of the die-off did not fit the pesticide theory. "I would have expected that we would see the initial effects in the small bays and backwaters where the washout would first have occurred, not going out to the middle of the Sound almost immediately," he said. 
Mr. Mattice's opinions did not go over well with the lobstermen. Many of them say a variety of factors may be in play -- several lobstermen and scientists believe a part of the problem is the recent rebound in striped bass, a major predator of lobsters. But bass or paramoebae cannot be required to pay damages.
The night before the conference in Bridgeport, the lobstermen learned that a lawsuit filed on their behalf against the pesticide manufacturer Cheminova had been certified as a class action. The suit accuses Cheminova of causing economic harm to the lobstermen after its pesticide Fyfanon, a malathion product, was sprayed in Nassau and Suffolk in 1999.
During the pretrial discovery phase of the case, the lobstermen's lawyer, Gladstone Jones, established that in 1999 Cheminova failed to label barrels of Fyfanon with a warning mandated by the Environmental Protection Agency. Exhibit A in Mr. Jones's filing, submitted to Judge E. Thomas Boyle of Federal District Court in Central Islip last August, is the warning that the E.P.A. ordered Cheminova to use. It begins: "Application may not be made around bodies of water where fish or shellfish are grown and/or harvested commercially."
In a May 2002 letter to Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. director, Mr. Jones said that Cheminova stored Fyfanon in warehouses and storage tanks where the temperature reached at least 115 degrees, causing leaks and converting malathion to isomalathion, "a significantly more toxic chemical." 
Cheminova's lawyer, Christopher Kelly, did not respond to telephone calls seeking comment.
"Class certification is one step on a long road," said Mr. Jones, a New Orleans environmental lawyer who is representing lobstermen on both sides of the Sound. "We still have major hurdles, but we can bundle all the lobstermen together." He predicted that the case would go to trial this fall, at which time 300 to 500 lobstermen will be named as plaintiffs. 
At the symposium, the pesticide argument received a boost when Sylvan de Guise, a veterinary pathologist at the University of Connecticut, reported that his experiments proved that lobsters were sensitive to malathion. He said lobsters die when exposed to 33 parts per billion of malathion, a level that James O'Donald, a marine scientist at the University of Connecticut, calculated would have been present as far as 10 miles out into the western Sound after Hurricane Floyd.
The storm on Sept. 17, 1999, after stepped-up aerial spraying of pesticide that summer, when the West Nile virus made its first appearance. "It takes half as much malathion to kill a lobster than to kill a walleye," Dr. de Guise said. "Walleyes are considered sensitive to malathion."
But he was not ready to declare a eureka moment. "What does it mean?" he asked. "We're not quite sure. We would have to follow the lobsters in real life before exposure and follow them afterward. This is very difficult to do retrospectively. We cannot rule out effects we have not measured." 
The lobstermen filed onto the 4:45 ferry for the ride home looking exhausted and agreeing that they had not learned anything new. "None of this will bring the lobsters back," Mr. German said. "Every year there are less lobstermen and less lobstermen -- and more scientists."

HEADLINE: Schools That Try To Keep Students Out 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
FROM inside an unmarked car, Nick Luciano trained his video camera on the house where his suspect supposedly lived and waited for her to come out. It was just after sunrise.
 About an hour into the stakeout, she emerged and got into a taxicab. With that on tape, he had what he needed.
 Mr. Luciano is a retired New York City police detective who has dealt with his share of low-lifes and criminals. But his quarry last week was a junior high school student in the Valley Stream Central High School District. 
Someone had phoned in a tip that she came to school in a cab, which raised suspicions that she might not actually live in the district but was coming from across the border in Queens. As it turned out, she does live in the district and just happens to take cabs to school.
"That's not the norm for Valley Stream," Mr. Luciano said. "But she came out of the house and it is what it is." Case closed.
But there are many other cases where Mr. Luciano has staked out a home, made unannounced visits or used other investigative techniques to prove that a child did not live in the Valley Stream district. He said that since he started working as the district's first full-time residency investigator last summer, he has prevented more than 130 students living in New York City or elsewhere from going to school in Valley Stream.
Nassau school districts on the Queens border have grappled with the problem of nonresidents trying to sneak into their schools for years. But with rising property taxes and the recent threatened loss of state education funding, school officials and homeowners in these districts say now more than ever they need to make sure that only those who are entitled to an education in their districts get to stay in their schools.
At least seven Nassau school districts bordering on Queens hire investigators to spy on suspected nonresidents. The number of students expelled as a result ranges from a handful in the Great Neck district to about 20 students a year at the Lawrence public schools and more than 100 a year in Valley Stream and in the Sewanhaka Central High School District, which encompasses Elmont, Floral Park, Franklin Square and part of New Hyde Park. While the vast majority of nonresidents in border districts come from Queens, school officials said they have discovered interlopers from as far away as Staten Island and Farmingdale.
The cost to the school districts ranges from the uncalculated expense of the time that school officials divert from other duties to investigate residency to the $350,000 a year that Sewanhaka pays detectives and lawyers to weed out nonresidents. School officials say the money, whatever the amount, is well spent since every nonresident child that is kept out saves the district $10,000 a year. 
"We have to balance the rights of our taxpayers and our responsibilities to them with our concern for the students," said Ronald D. Valenti, superintendent of the Valley Stream Central High School District, which has 4,600 students in grades 7 through 12. "We want to educate every child to the fullest who is truly a resident of Valley Stream, but we can't extend that benefit to those who are not residents. We can't just simply open our doors and say, 'Come one, come all."'
The district expelled as many as 30 nonresident students a year in the past using a part-time investigator, but Dr. Valenti said that complaints from taxpayers prompted the district to tackle the problem more aggressively. "This has probably been a problem from time immemorial, but the number of families wanting to take advantage of an attractive school district that's only a walk or a bus ride from Queens had been growing in recent years," he said. "And people have become much more sophisticated about gaming the system."
Interlopers use a host of methods, including fabricated leases and rent receipts, phony drivers' licenses, friends or relatives who will claim them as tenants, and rented mailboxes or addresses. School officials said nonresidents have been known to pay homeowners or real estate brokers a fee of, say, $20 a month for the right to receive mail at an address in the district and to have it forwarded to their homes outside.
In addition to using detectives, school districts also use simpler tools like telephone tip lines and letters stamped with "Do Not Forward" to try to catch nonresidents.
Valley Stream redesigned its registration process to try to keep up. Rather than have each of the district's four schools handle its own new students, every application now goes to Mr. Luciano for scrutiny. The requirements for proving residency were also heightened. Homeowners must provide at least three documents that show ownership, no photocopies allowed. Renters must provide a lease, a utility bill, a notarized affidavit from the owner of the house stating that the child lives in the rented home, and a copy of the owner's deed, mortgage statement or tax bill.
Each registration form includes a warning that any false statement is "punishable as a class A misdemeanor" and that the district "reserves the right to investigate any student's residency by any legal means available, including but not limited to public records, site visits and other lawful methods of investigation."
Linda Wain, the executive director of the Long Island Advocacy Center, a nonprofit legal aid center that has represented scores of families in school residency cases, said some school districts have been too aggressive. The actions of detectives who follow and videotape children or make unannounced home visits can sometimes "border on harassment," Ms. Wain said. "The things they do sometimes intimidate families and we want to avoid that."
Curtis Thomas is an Elmont homeowner who went head to head with the Elmont school district two years ago when school officials determined that his 6-year-old granddaughter was not an official Elmont resident. At the time, Mr. Thomas said, his granddaughter lived with him during the week but with her father on weekends. School officials argued that she was living with Mr. Thomas just to attend their schools, disqualifying her. Mr. Thomas then obtained legal custody of the child, but she is now back in Queens with her father.
"I resented that they thought I was trying to do something slick," Mr. Thomas said. "I was responsible for her, but I chose to let her stay with her father. I didn't want to sever their ties."
He also said he didn't like the fact that detectives followed his granddaughter around. "I couldn't believe they would have people stalking you outside your school," he said. "I thought it was foolish to pay somebody to sit out there and do that, when most people would probably tell you the truth if you just asked."
Ms. Wain said many of the families that come to the advocacy center live in illegal multiple dwellings, may be illegal immigrants or have complicated family situations that involve children living with relatives other than their parents. She said the center's main purpose in helping these families is "to see that the children go to school, because there often are long delays and they wind up sitting at home while the districts demand documentation." 
Vilma Mejias's 5-year-old son, Daniel, spent February at home because the West Hempstead school district was not satisfied with the family's housing documents.
The Mejias family moved from Bay Shore to the second-floor apartment of the home of relatives in West Hempstead at the end of January. But because the relatives did not own the house, their affidavit was deemed insufficient. "We had the car registration with this address, my husband's pay stubs and other bills, but they said it wasn't enough," Mrs. Mejias said. So the family wrote to the owner, who lives in Texas, and asked for a signed and notarized affidavit and a copy of a property tax bill. It was early March before they finally got all the documentation the district demanded. 
Part of the impetus for such stiff requirements comes from the concerns that many homeowners across Long Island have about the growing number of illegal apartments. "All these families in illegal apartments mean more kids in school, higher school budgets and more crowded classrooms," said Roy Mezzapelle, president of the Elmont Quality of Life Committee, a civic group that focuses on illegal housing. They are an unfair burden on homeowners who pay an average of $4,000 a year in school property taxes, he added, because the owners of the illegal apartments pay taxes at the single-family-home rate even though their buildings may house as many as five families. "If you have three families in a house, you should be paying taxes accordingly," he said.
Lois Colletta, the assistant superintendent who handles residency issues for the Valley Stream district, said that about half of the 200 residents at a recent public meeting on residency came to complain about children living in illegal apartments. "But even though those children may be living in illegal situations, they're still residents in the district and that means we are obligated to educate them," she said.
Dr. Colletta and officials in other border districts agreed that the problem is more significant at the junior high and high school levels than in the elementary schools. "I think that's partly because young children just aren't as good at lying as older kids, but also because a lot of parents from the city are more concerned about security at the older levels," she said. Rather than have their children go through metal detectors every morning to get to their first-period classes, parents want their children in schools where safety is not a worry, she said.
The Sewanhaka district has been dealing with nonresidents for nearly 20 years and easily has the most elaborate system for dealing with them. The district conducts what they call "massive sweeps" at the beginning of the school year, where teams of detective cars lie in wait at the city line on Hempstead and Jericho Turnpikes and follow every car carrying a child into the district to see whether they go to a district school. The detectives will follow the child into the school, never approaching a child directly, but will learn the child's name from the homeroom teacher.
The district also runs a computer search for children with different surnames at the same address. In many cases, the different names are explained by the existence of illegal apartments in the house. But when there are as many as four to six different surnames at one address, school officials said, they often find that at least one of those children is a nonresident.
"I'm an educator, but I have to sit here and play detective," said George Goldstein, Sewanhaka's superintendent. "It's like we're playing a game of chess here, and the pawns are the children and the horses are my detectives running around like buffoons to try to catch them."
He said that while his district's system is extensive and expensive, the return is worth it. The district has expelled more than 1,440 children in the last 15 years, he said, and at an estimated cost of $10,000 a year and six years of education for each child, the savings to the district is more than $86 million. 
Sewanhaka is also the only district to have instituted a formal appeals process, where families of students who have been kicked out of the district can appeal to an administrative law judge, who is hired and paid by the school district. The district holds about 50 such hearings a year. The judge upholds roughly 30 of those explusions and reverses about 10 of them; the remaining 10 cases are appealed to the state commissioner of education.
At one such administrative hearing late last month, a father from Cambria Heights, Queens, pleaded with the judge to let his 18-year-old daughter stay at Elmont Memorial High School. He brought in her honor roll certificates and explained that they had lived in the district when he registered his daughter but could no longer afford to stay there.
"I would like to maintain her here, because every time I go by the school near us I see fights and I don't want her there," said the father, who asked that he not be identified. The city school, Martin Van Buren High School, has a 9 percent dropout rate and only 30 percent of its students graduate with Regents diplomas. The Sewanhaka district has a dropout rate of less than half of one percent and 65 percent of its students graduate with Regents diplomas.
The father told the judge that his daughter stayed with a relative during the week to maintain her residency, but also said that he was still responsible for her financially. The judge upheld the dismissal.
"I feel for these parents," Dr. Goldstein said. "I would do anything for my child too. But we have to do what we have to do. We have no obligation to teach other people's children."
Carl Friedman, who handles residency issues for the state Department of Education, said that residency became a major issue in the state about 20 years ago. "The economy of it all has caused people to have to guarantee that they're not wasting money and only putting efforts into those students that are entitled to an education in their district," he said.
Mr. Friedman also said that over time there has been an increase in the number of children living with adults other than their parents. Many people do not understand what the law allows in those situations, he said.
A guardian does not have to have legal custody of a child, he said, "but they have to show that they're in charge of everything in the child's life, that they're paying all the costs associated with raising the child, that the arrangement is permanent for the foreseeable future, and they can be doing it for any reason in the world except that they're shopping for a better school district."
School district officials from across Long Island said that residency cases that deal with custody issues are often the most complex ones they face.
Donato Gonzalez, who has two sons and a nephew in the Brentwood school district, said Brentwood officials were confrontational and unhelpful when they tried to remove his 12-year-old nephew, Eric Rodriguez, earlier this month.
What kicked off their residency investigation was a class discussion on parents and careers. Eric said he had never known his father and was not living with his mother, so he wasn't sure what she did.
Mr. Gonzalez said Eric's mother lived with them until recently, but had moved to Florida to care for her ailing mother. "I didn't know I had to tell them about that," Mr. Gonzalez said.
The Long Island Advocacy Center explained their rights to Mr. Gonzalez and his wife, who chose to seek legal custody of Eric and have submitted those forms to the school district. "I'm a taxpayer in Brentwood and I understand what had to be done," he said. "But they made what should have been a simple process very nerve-racking and difficult."
Les Black, the Brentwood schools superintendent, did not address Mr. Gonzalez's case but said: "The question is whether the parent has really given up custody. It has to do with our legal responsibilities too. If a child gets hurt, we need to know who's responsible."
Aubrey Phillips, a school board member for the Sewanhaka and Elmont school districts, said school districts generally needed to be "more sensitive to different social dynamics within their community and not assume that the social dynamics of traditional families in the United States fit the needs of everyone."
Mr. Phillips is an immigrant from Guyana, and he said many Guyanese and Haitian families have large extended families with informal arrangements where aunts and uncles and grandparents care for children while their parents are elsewhere. "Very formal and legal methods of proving someone belongs to someone else just aren't the norm in these communities," he said. "It's something we need to understand and try to work with."
Mr. Luciano, Valley Stream's residency investigator, said he often has mixed feelings when he catches people lying about their circumstances. He said the situations were more cut and dried when he investigated the residency of police recruits as a New York City police detective.
"There, people would lie and yell at you because you weren't giving them a job and you could feel glad that you weren't giving them a gun," he said. "Here, you feel bad, because there's no malicious intent. They're just looking for something better for their children."

HEADLINE: BRIEFINGS: UNEMPLOYMENT; 
FEARS FOR JOBLESS FUND

BYLINE:  By George James 

 BODY:
 The state fund that provides benefits to unemployed workers has lost $1 billion in the last 14 months, prompting calls by business and labor leaders for Governor McGreevey to abandon his plan to divert $325 million from the fund to help offset a projected $5 billion budget deficit. 
The loss occurred as a result of rising unemployment claims and after the governor diverted $650 million to balance the budget last year. In trying to allay fears that employers would have to pay more into the fund, state officials said it had ample money to cover claims for another year. George James

HEADLINE: Remember the British In Cutting Funds for Arts 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A statement by Governor McGreevey's spokeswoman, Ellen Mellody -- "It's hard to justify hanging a picture on the wall when you can't put food on the table" (Feb. 23) -- shows a shocking lack of understanding of how the arts community affects the lives of New Jersey citizens. 
The arts generate $1 billion in economic impact each year. Cut this and people throughout the state will not be able to put food on the table. 
 Times are difficult, but perhaps New Jersey needs to take a page from the British during World War II. Despite threats of bombings and invasion, the British Museum in London remained open. Priceless artifacts were hidden in bunkers and replaced with reproductions on the walls. The British government and the museum administrators understood that faced with obstacles to everyday living, people needed the reassurance that culture and a sense of history provide. With American society and culture under threat from without, it is disheartening to think that they are also under threat from within.

Bonnie-Lynn Nadzeika
Mount Arlington

The writer is director of the Morris County Historical Society.

HEADLINE: It's Getting Easier To Be Green 

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, Robert and Deborah Fischman paid Con Ed $1,000 a month during the winter to heat their four-bedroom colonial in South Salem.
 By last month, the familys utility bill had dropped to $400. What changed? Worried about both the environment and his budget, Mr. Fischman, a civil engineer, decided four years ago to convert his 3,000-square-foot house to a "green" building. He replaced the homes all-electric heating system with a geothermal pump, which draws heat from the earth in winter and sheds it into the ground in summer through a system of buried plastic pipes called a ground heat exchanger. 
 Not only have Mr. and Mrs. Fischman and their three children been basking in the cost-effective warmth of geothermal heat ever since, but they have also gained new respect in their neighborhood. These days when guests stop by, the conversation invariably turns to the unassuming box in the basement, where a furnace would usually be found. The new system is a winner on two counts, the Fischmans explain: it keeps their home at 70 degrees Fahrenheit winter and summer, and it eliminates emissions from the site that traditional fossil fuel heating systems give off. 
 Mr. Fischman, who works for Andron Construction Corporation in Goldens Bridge, predicts that in time, homes like his will become less of a curiosity and more mainstream. "Especially as peoples values focus increasingly on conserving our environment," he said, "well see a lot more of them."
 In Westchester recently, as in the rest of the country, interest in green construction has grown sharply. Adding to concerns about rolling power failures, soaring fuel costs and dependence on foreign oil is another worry specific to Westchester: if the Nuclear Regulatory Commission closes down the Indian Point nuclear power plant, which provides between 18 and 38 percent of the energy for New York City and the lower Hudson Valley, how will that that energy be replaced?
 Environmentalists, citizen groups and public officials, including the Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, have called for the closing of the two nuclear power plants at Indian Point in Buchanan run by Entergy, in large part because of the threat to Westchester if they were to become the focus of a terrorist attack.
 Westchester itself is stepping up efforts to find alternatives to traditional energy sources. It already has a solar system at work at its Yonkers Joint Wastewater Treatment Plant. The solar panels, called photovoltaic tiles, which are on the roof of the plants administration building, produce about 100 kilowatts of power at any given time and save about $10,000 a year, said Adam J. Zabinski, deputy commissioner for the countys Department of Environmental Facilities. Also, the sludge processing produces 1.2 million cubic feet of methane gas daily, which in turn is used to fire boilers at the treatment plant. Estimated savings by using the gas byproduct is about $75,000 a year, Mr. Zabinski said.
 The goal of green construction is to make buildings more energy efficient by minimizing environmental impact and reducing energy use, often according to standards set by the United States Green Building Council, a national coalition of leaders from the building industry and environmental organizations.
 A green approach to energy is not new, of course. During the 1970's, strategies to conserve fuel included driving smaller cars, turning down thermostats and wearing more sweaters, following the example set by President Jimmy Carter. Americans also began recycling trash, using low-flow shower heads to reduce water consumption, installing Thermopane windows and adopting other energy-saving strategies. Strategies like recycling had staying power, but others did not, observed Alexander Roberts, president of Roberts Geo Systems, an energy management consulting concern in Pleasantville. The most notable example of Americans discarding conservation efforts, Mr. Roberts said, has been their love affair with S.U.V.'s and other large vehicles with low gas mileage.
 The question now is whether the new zeal for energy conservation will prevail this time around.
 "The crucial difference between then and now," said Mr. Roberts, "was that then conserving energy meant doing without or with less, whereas today many of the new green technologies like geothermal heating and compact fluorescent light bulbs actually improve comfort and work better. Even better, they also offer a clear economic benefit that people can see in pocketbooks, which is a powerful motivator."

Relying on Light And Local Materials
 Geothermal heat pumps and solar energy are both used in green construction. Often such construction depends on daylight for illumination and uses lights that automatically dim depending on the natural light available. A green building is designed to insulate efficiently and has either Thermopane or specially glazed windows. Such buildings also use construction materials like wood from renewable forests, steel with a high content of recycled materials, locally quarried stone, nontoxic paints and carpets, and ceramic tiles made with recycled glass.
 Builders, homeowners and commercial property owners are embracing green construction and predicting that it will soon gain wide acceptance. "We call it green construction now, but it wont be long before we take it for granted and dont refer to it as something special," said Bill Balter, a coowner of Wilder Balter Partners, builders in Elmsford. "Even in less than a decade, it will probably be the norm."
 Some materials, like low-emission insulating glass, are already commonly used by builders. Geothermal heat pumps have proved to be highly reliable but are not common. Still there are some high-profile customers: President Bush had one installed in his ranch home in Crawford, Tex., and Vice President Dick Cheney's official home, the Naval Observatory in Washington, uses geothermal heat pumps. Mr. Balter has installed a geothermal heat pump as a test case in one of 15 luxury homes he is building at Arrowcrest Estates at Hunterbrook in Yorktown. "Eventually well be doing it in more developments," he said. "For now, were trying it out here and working out the kinks."
 The mechanics of such a system are simple: using the constant temperature of the earth below the frost line, a pump forces water through piping connected to a buildings heating and cooling system. During the summer, excess heat from the building is shed into the ground through the system for cooling, and during the winter, heat is drawn from the ground.
 The typical cost for such a system is about $7,500, according to the United States Department of Energy. The investment can often be recouped within 2 to 10 years in utility bill savings, studies from the energy department show. The underground piping used comes with a 25- to 50-year warranty, and the pumps themselves typically last 20 years or longer. Also, the state offers tax incentives and rebates for installing geothermal systems.

Savings at a Country Club And a High School
 Gov. George E. Pataki has been New Yorks major champion of new energy technologies and green construction. He has ordered the state to buy at least 20 percent of its energy from geothermal and other renewable sources by 2010. Incentives are available for installing geothermal systems, solar-electric and wind-generation systems. In 2000, the state passed the countrys first Green Building Tax Credit, a $25 million income tax credit program for owners and tenants of buildings that meet certain energy, indoor air quality, materials, water conservation, appliance and size criteria. The state has distributed money to more than 600,000 individuals and other businesses from the beginning of its public benefit program in 1998.The program is financed at $150 million a year.
 Rebates and savings can be substantial. On a Croton-on-Hudson home that was used last year to educate the public about solar heat, photovoltaic panels were installed for $25,000, with state rebates and tax advantages amounting to $14,000, according to Federated Conservationists of Westchester, an umbrella organization of environmental groups.
The Westchester Country Club in Rye recently installed a geothermal system as part of a $7 million project to reduce energy consumption by 775,000 kilowatt hours, saving $130,000 annually on energy costs and reducing fossil fuel emissions linked to smog, acid rain, global climate changes and respiratory ailments.
The geothermal system at the country club was installed by R. J. Dooley & Associates, a seven-year-old Poughkeepsie engineering and construction firm that is also installing the geothermal unit at Wilder Balter's Arrowcrest Estates at Hunterbrook. The company's owner, Robert Dooley, is converting a 60,000-square-foot former brewery and hotel built in the mid-1800's on the Hudson River waterfront in Poughkeepsie to offices and a restaurant and has installed a geothermal unit there, too.
 To encourage more green construction of schools, the state Energy Research and Development Authority has awarded $20,000 grants to 50 public and private schools, including Somers High School in Westchester. School Power Naturally, as the program is called, is designed to raise students' awareness of the importance and promise of solar energy. Schools chosen for the project are also getting weather stations to aid them in collecting and analyzing their data.
 Somers High is installing a solar collector on the south wall of its gymnasium, which will provide the school with two kilowatts of electricity per month, said Brian Hugick, a science teacher at the school. As a point of comparison, the teacher said, the average home uses about four kilowatts a month; the school uses between 228 and 378 kilowatts a month.
 Even though two kilowatts is a relatively small savings, "it will help us get off the grid," Mr. Hugick explained. The teacher is showing lab students in his Contemporary Issues in Science course how solar energy can be used to power pollution-free model cars and cooking equipment.
 Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers is going green on a bigger scale, spending $25 million to build a 60,000-square-foot center for the visual arts using recycled and renewable materials including the rock removed from the ground during construction. The design focuses on minimizing water and energy use and includes a geothermal system. The building is expected to open in the fall of 2004.

Counting Kilowatts At the Power Authority
 The New York Power Authority installed new energy-efficiency technologies at the Clarence D. Rappleyea Building, the authoritys headquarters in White Plains. It began the $3.8 million project to address the governors "Green and Clean State Buildings" order, requiring state-owned buildings to achieve reductions in energy use of at least 35 percent by 2010, based on 1990 consumption levels. Along with anticipated energy savings of 50 percent, the White Plains office improvements are expected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 4,100 tons a year.
 At the Kenneth S. Warren Institute, a medical research center in Yorktown, major renovations are under way to make the building into an oil-free building, said Learned J. Hand, the institutes executive director. Situated on the grounds of Yorktowns 15-acre Kitchawan Preserve near the Croton Reservoir, the 15,000-square-foot building is heated primarily with a geothermal heat pump system.
 "Our eventual goal is to be totally oil free," Mr. Hand said. "But no matter how green a building is, when its 5 degrees outside, you want some backup oil."
 Chuck Lowden, the institutes chief engineer, said the nonprofit group was also considering the installation of solar panels and a propane-powered generator to serve as a backup source of power in case of a power failure. "Especially in a rural area, you dont want to put all your eggs in one basket," he said.

Electric Cars And Building Regulations
 Municipalities, too, have accepted the charge to become more green. White Plains, for example, has installed variable frequency motors at its water pumping facilities and at its public library, said Joseph Nicoletti Jr., commissioner of Public Works and the city engineer. The motors slow down or speed up in response to changing conditions instead of continually running at full speed. The city also retrofitted 4,400 streetlights with high-pressure sodium bulbs, which have a long life and high output. A new parking garage has been designed with light sensors so that outside rows are artificially lighted only when there is inadequate daylight.
 The city's fleet of vehicles has also become more environmentally friendly, including cars powered by electricity, natural gas and alcohol. "The maintenance on these vehicles is considerably less, the cost of refueling an electric car is almost nil, and complaints about noise during night street sweeping are considerably reduced", Mr. Nicoletti said. "In addition, the environmental hazards and constant monitoring and testing required of underground fuel storage facilities is eliminated for those vehicles."
 The town of Greenburgh passed a new law about a year ago mandating energy-efficient construction of all new homes. The law says no building permit can be issued for a new one- or two-family home or a dwelling of three stories or fewer unless the applicant certifies that the building will meet New York Energy Star Labeled Home guidelines. The guidelines stipulate improved insulation, windows designed to improve thermal performance, high efficiency heating and cooling systems that are properly sized for the home, and reduced air infiltration, among other things.
 Steven Winter, chairman of the United States Green Building Council and president of Steven Winter Associates, an architectural firm in Norwalk that designs green projects nationwide, said that however laudable the ideas of green construction are, it could take as much as a generation for the principles and practices of it to become mainstream.
 There is the natural disinclination of some people to make the effort to change, he observed: "Sometimes they're selfish, lazy or just indifferent and not willing to take time to recycle or institute other energy-saving measures. Their attitude is, 'The heck with it.' " 
 There are also some business concerns oil companies, for example, he said that would prefer consumers to maintain their dependence on fossil fuels. "Any time theres a change," Mr. Winter said, "there are status quo interests that resist it."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Amtrak Hangs On, Hopeful Once More

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AMTRAK is far from healthy, but after its near-death experience last summer, top management is newly hopeful. It has won a federal subsidy for the current fiscal year that is more than 95 percent of the $1.2 billion it asked for -- including some money for long-deferred capital items.
 But there are strings attached. The first problem is that the money will go through the Transportation Department, which is supposed to provide it to the railroad as grants. David L. Gunn, Amtrak's president, was asked at a recent briefing on the budget whether this created new hoops for the beleaguered railroad to jump through. "Well, at least we've got a hoop," he replied. "We've never had a hoop before." 
 The grant system, cobbled together by Congress, might give the Transportation Department the authority to cut individual trains, although officials at both Amtrak and the department said they were uncertain about the department's authority and its intentions.
Still, it is a step up from last summer, when the railroad was saved from collapse by an emergency appropriation of $205 million from Congress and a $100 million loan from the Transportation Department. Even now Amtrak has only a few weeks' worth of cash on hand. But the railroad's extreme poverty may protect it, Mr. Gunn suggested. It has so little money that any delays in providing more could cause a collapse.
The new budget is for the period from last Oct. 1 to Sept. 30; like nearly all of the federal budget, it was not approved by Congress until February. In addition to $1.05 billion of the $1.2 billion it had asked for, Amtrak won deferral of the $100 million loan. The final budget was a compromise with the House. It provides $522 million for operations, $295 million for capital improvements in the Northeast Corridor, where the track needs billions of dollars in improvements, and $233 million for capital improvements elsewhere. The money for the Northeast includes initial financing for replacement of three bridges on the Connecticut shoreline, two movable and a third that "will move if we don't fix it," Mr. Gunn said. Some of the money will go to replace locomotives that are 50 years old, he said.
Amtrak expects its revenues to continue to decline as part of a recession hitting the whole travel industry, its executives say. But it hopes to cut costs substantially; it has eliminated 600 jobs and streamlined its management. It is getting out of the express package business, and says it will cut back on carrying mail because some contracts are not profitable. The railroad also refused to bid on a contract to run a commuter rail line in Boston and its suburbs and will scrutinize its other commuter contracts.
But it faces tough times. One problem is that for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, it plans to ask for lots more -- $1.8 billion --while the Bush administration says that subsidies are too high and has proposed half that amount. The railroad has also called for fundamental reform without specifying what that would be. Critics have proposed privatizing sections of the national rail system as a reform option, but the administration has not submitted a plan to do so.
The second problem is that the administration has taken aim at six trains that the Office of Management and Budget said lost unreasonable sums. One is the Pennsylvania, which ran from Philadelphia to Chicago. Amtrak has already cut the Pittsburgh-to-Chicago portion of that train, as part of its retreat from theexpress-package business. A second is the Kentucky Cardinal, which runs from Louisville to Chicago; Amtrak plans to drop that in July. Also singled out are the Sunset Limited, between Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla.; the Texas Eagle, between San Antonio and Chicago; the Three Rivers, between New York and Chicago; and the Southwest Chief, between Chicago and Los Angeles. In theory, the department could withhold money to run them.
The administration says the Sunset Limited lost $347 per rider in 2001, and the others more than $200 per rider. Mr. Gunn argued that the losses per mile were not much different from those on many commuter lines, but that the Amtrak trips cover more miles. Besides, he said, the whole railroad loses money; the relevant question, as he sees it, is the marginal cost, or how much would be saved if a route were to be cut, rather than the total cost of the route. For example, Amtrak's station in New Orleans is now used by three trains a day. If Amtrak cut out one of them, the expense of running the station would shift to the other two. And overhead costs like management salaries would not change.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Grading Bush On Prosperity And Pain

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
AFTER a recent report by the Labor Department suggested that the economy was still losing jobs like sand from a sieve, Democrats blasted the Bush administration for failing to shore up the economy. But how much of the credit or blame do President Bush and his team deserve, just two years into his term?
 The experts have spoken, and the answer is . . . a modest amount. 
 An informal survey of economists, which I conducted last week by e-mail, asked, "To what degree is the Bush administration responsible (in the sense of bearing credit or blame) for the current state of the economy?" 
Answers were sought from 20 well-known Wall Street economists from different companies and 125 academics specializing in macroeconomics. The academic group included R. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, and his nominated successor, N. Gregory Mankiw of Harvard. Neither responded. Among those who did was Martin S. Feldstein, a Harvard professor who held the post in the early 1980's.
The economists were encouraged to pick from a five-point scale, ranging from "not at all" to "completely," and to offer additional comments. The academics, of whom 57 responded, averaged 2.3 -- between "a little bit" and "a fair amount." The average from the 11 Wall Street economists who wrote back was lower, at 1.9.
Several economists who chose the most popular response, "a little bit," wrote that the White House's actions could not have much effect on the economy in the short run.
"As much as I dislike the Bush administration, and as much as I believe that its current policies may affect the future of the U.S. economy, what's happening right now has little to do with what the Bush economic team has done," wrote Eduardo M. Engel, a professor at Yale.
Those who differed -- and many did -- mostly emphasized the link between foreign policy and the economy. They wrote that uncertainty over Iraq and fears of terrorism as a side effect of war were having as big an effect as any economic policy.
"Whether the Bush administration is right or wrong in its strategy toward Iraq is largely a question of international diplomacy," wrote James H. Stock, a Harvard professor, "but its implication is that domestic investment and, to a lesser degree, consumption decisions are postponed, restraining growth."
And, as some academics wrote, the White House may have more latitude in its foreign policy than in its economic policy. "Even the most ardent Bush supporter would concede that the Iraq push was a choice," wrote Anil K. Kashyap, a professor at the University of Chicago, "and since that is hanging over the economy Bush has some responsibility."
Professor Stock added that the administration could also have taken a stronger stance against the corporate scandals that have dogged the stock market. The complaint thatMr. Bush's tax cuts have damaged the nation's long-term fiscal outlook enough to push up interest rates also received some support among the academics, but not among the Wall Street economists.
One of the president's defenders on that front was James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, who wrote that the Bush administration was "not at all" responsible for the state of the economy.
"Most of us believe the slowdown/moderate recession was the result of a perfect storm back in 2000," he wrote. In the history of such crises, he continued, "we have never seen as quick and forceful a response from the Fed, from the administration and from Congress than that of the last two years."
Mr. Glassman's second point suggests (notwithstanding his "not at all" choice) that the administration deserves some credit, not blame, for the state of the economy. Without its actions, things might have been much worse than they are today. 
But it is worth remembering that in September 2000, before the presidential election, top academics polled by The Economist magazine mostly gave Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, credit for the boom of the 1990's -- a boom now seen as ending in an unsustainable bubble.
That bubble, wrote Vincenzo Quadrini, an assistant professor at New York University who also answered "not at all" in the informal survey, was the true culprit. "The current economic difficulties are the unavoidable consequences of the asset price bubble that started to burst in the first half of 2000," he said. But, potentially in Mr. Greenspan's defense, Mr. Quadrini added that he found it " difficult to identify a policy that could have caused or prevented this."
