HEADLINE: PLACES; 
How Green Is Their Valley?

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: GREEN VALLEY, Ariz. 

 BODY:
ROBERT BEZANSON has the leathery look of a durable hippie, with tumbling white locks and gold-rimmed glasses. Raised in Massachusetts, he moved to Montana and lived wherever his business, laying underground pipe, took him. Never married, he retired in 1990 to a condominium in sunny Green Valley.
 Mr. Bezanson had made a plan. He would play golf every day on the courses here and carouse in their taprooms. He would spend all of his Social Security checks, and over a decade, exhaust his long-nurtured nest egg in government bonds. "I would have an adequate amount for an adequate lifestyle for 10 years," he said. By then he would be 75, fulfilled and gone. 
 Instead, Mr. Bezanson is 78 and indisputably afoot. Gripping his gin and soda at the bar of the par-71 San Ignacio Golf Club, he said he was still shooting his usual 88 to 98. "The biggest problem I have is that I'm living too long," he said without a glimmer of gratitude. His investments, though depleted, have stretched because he has never needed doctors or prescriptions. "I have an H.M.O.," he said, "but what I have mainly is health." 
Gin, genes and golf might explain the vitality of a community where the median age in the 2000 census was 72, one of the oldest in the nation. Only 3 percent of the population of 17,283 was younger than 25. With no ice to slip on and a hot, dry climate hostile to viruses and bugs, with 30-minute access to Tucson's wealth of geriatric care and an hour from cheap medication in Nogales, Mexico, Green Valley's location is surely a factor, too. 
But the means to live long is colliding with longer lives and harder times, most starkly in retirement communities like these in Arizona, Florida and California, which bloomed with the rise of the elderly affluence that began in the 1960's. Many of Green Valley's mostly middle-income settlers spent 40-year careers with government or blue-chip industrial employers that now pay them predictable pensions. But the three-year rout of the investment markets has hammered many settlers' stock and bond portfolios, annuities and 401(k)'s. 
"There are coupon clippers," said Paul Wilson, 60, a Coldwell Banker real estate agent here. "We have a nucleus of people living very marginally, and a wealthy class." Helen Patton, 88 and a widow, said she had put almost $30,000 in a variable annuity fund. "I used to get $262 out of it a month, and now I'm getting $120." She has had enough. "I'm from Michigan," she said. "I'm going back to the cold country. I've got to have my daughter take care of me."
At 65, retirees qualify for Medicare, but premiums and deductibles for the insurance to cover prescriptions and the care that Medicare does not cover are rising, too. Social Security checks still rise with inflation, but poverty among older people, driven from the highest of all age groups to the lowest since the 60's, has been creeping up again. One of Green Valley's busiest commercial enterprises is the White Elephant Thrift Shop.
Some residents have been here for 30 years, but turnover is high because of death, disease and economic reversals. A real estate agent was showing a $179,900, nine-year-old house one afternoon. "It was foreclosed," he said. A neighbor explained that the man who lived there had run out of money by caring for his wife, who had Alzheimer's disease. A son took them home to Idaho.
As they go about their seven-Saturday weeks, many younger, healthier retirees seem inured to the squeeze. Limber and sinewy as a point guard, the visible toll of aging no further advanced than the gray invading his stubbly beard, Gregg Zeller, 69, completes his afternoon workout at a fitness center. His wife, Nancy, 63, robust as he, is a volunteer fitness instructor. 
The Zellers, who have two grown children, moved here five years ago from River Forest, Ill., near Chicago. She was a legal secretary and he processed claims for an insurance company. To prepare for retirement, they converted their 401(k) and I.R.A. accounts into variable annuities, which assured them a check as long as they lived. Their monthly checks have dropped by $1,000 to $4,000, but the Zellers have been spending less than they had expected. 
"We're actually banking some money," he said -- $20,000 that they have put into a stock and bond mutual fund. For health care, Mr. Zeller relies on the Veterans Administration hospital in Tucson. Mrs. Zeller has a Blue Cross plan and will soon be eligible for Medicare. Neither covers the cost of prescriptions, however, and she takes Premarin, an estrogen replacement drug. 
"It runs about $75 for 90 pills in the U.S.," she said. So she takes her prescription down Interstate 19 to Nogales. "I park on our side and walk across," she said. "I can get generic in Mexico for $17 for 100 pills."
Green Valley is an unincorporated community, 12 miles long, 3 miles wide, with views of the Santa Rita Mountains to the east and barren, copper-stripped hills that stretch like a fat sleeping snake to the west. Most of the community is as flat as the sea, in spite of its name, and no more verdant than its saguaro and elephant ear cactus. 
The residents have shed the titles, big cars, suits and designer labels that stratified them at home to form a monochromatic sneaker and cotton class. Muriel Anderson, a saleswoman at a jewelry store, said that newcomers often traded in their jewelry. "In a retirement community, their lifestyles have changed," she said. "Where are they going to wear their jewelry?"
Still, distinctions are made. "There are cliques," Eva Olsen, 89, said. "They all look to find their niches. There's a lot of booze, a lot of bridge, a lot of bragging. This is no area for single people. It is for retirees who have brought money from other states." 
The median family income, nearly all fixed, is $43,000 a year, close to the national median. Homes, typically one story, two bedrooms, two baths, a garage and a patch of desert, sell for an average of $126,000, about the national median. Residents must be at least 55 in most of Green Valley, a restriction that conforms with a federal law allowing that kind of age discrimination in communities that provide certain levels of services, like recreation and transportation, for the elderly. Property taxes on most homes are $1,000 to $2,000. Tidy garages and yards are devoid of the spontaneous jetsam of young families' playthings and gear. 
People gather in the four shopping centers, the nine golf courses, the 28 churches, the thrift shop and the 12 nonprofit Green Valley Recreation centers, where for an initial fee of $1,823 for each home and dues of $351 a year, residents meet, swim, work out, play games, go to the theater and pursue hobbies in workshops. 
A memorial gathering for a colleague who died at 94 was breaking up at a center's woodworking shop one Saturday afternoon. With high ceilings, concrete walls and floors and islands of benches and top-of-the-line machinery, this is no whittle-away-the-sunsets place. Fifteen men -- no women -- were single-mindedly milling an unblemished board of poplar, clamping newly glued layers of walnut and cherry to make bowls, turning a post of white oak for a pedestal table. 
Most of the men grew up during the Depression, landed good jobs, saved and retired with pensions and health insurance. "I've got guys in here who are millionaires and don't spend $40,000 a year," said Warren Williams, 74, a volunteer supervisor at the shop who retired at age 59 from the Dow Chemical Company, where he was the mining industry manager; at 65, he retired from a consulting business he had operated in Denver. 
Mr. Williams and his wife, Mary, 71, are meeting their needs on his $2,000 monthly pension and their Social Security and are still breaking away for summer RV trips when temperatures exceed 100 degrees. But their investment portfolio has dropped with the market, and their pension, not adjusted for inflation, pays for less and less. Mr. Williams's monthly payment for health insurance has climbed to $105 from $35, the amount when he first retired. 
OTHERS have been hit harder. "We have a food bank here in town," Mr. Williams said (where Mrs. Williams volunteers). "We've got a few guys going back to work part time. A lot become realtors. We have a man who spent his entire career at General Electric." When he retired, he took a buyout instead of a monthly pension. "He invested it," Mr. Williams said, "and I'm sure he's struggling."
This is a staged-retirement community of young-old and old-old, where over the span of 20 and 30 years, people move from houses and condos to independent living homes to rooms in assisted living facilities and eventually nursing homes. As they age and lose spouses, their incomes decline. They outlive the recreational attractions that brought them here and become Green Valley's sequestered old. 
Some have moved to the 98-unit Del Coronado Apartments. Two stories, pink stucco, with sliding windows and balconies overlooking mountains and desert scrub, Del Coronado's apartments have a bedroom, sitting room, kitchen and large bathroom. 
Government-subsidized, they are restricted to people 62 and older who have incomes of less than $20,640 for individuals and $23,640 for a couple. Rents, based on income, range from $85 to $336 a month. Utilities and laundry machines are free; other services, including 12 meals a week, weekly housekeeping and van rides to shops, cost $355 a month. 
Ms. Olsen was living in Rhode Island with her husband in the early 60's. "I got rid of him," she said, still pleased with herself. A nursing graduate from Yale, she headed west, finding work in Tucson as a mental-health nurse and turning her attentions to her daughter in California, pet dogs and a bird, a blue-gray cockatiel. 
"The bird is 40 years old," Ms. Olsen said. Uncaged most of the day, it screeches and darts about her second-floor apartment at the Del Coronado. Gregarious and agile, Ms. Olsen gestures like a conductor and bounds up stairs like a teenager. "I've got my own car," she said.
She lives on a monthly Social Security check of $945 and pays $203 a month for rent and the $355 for services. That leaves little else for things like the nine other meals a week she must find for herself. "It's very expensive here," she said. "If you go to the Safeway, everything is about 10 cents more than in Tucson."

HEADLINE: SAVING; 
Arguing Against Equities

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
THE stock bubble has burst, and then some. But even amid the wreckage, the conventional mantra has continued: stocks are still the long-haul key to preparing for financial security in retirement.
 But what, actually, if they're not? 
 Quietly,in obscure financial journals and actuarial conferences, some alternatives are being debated. So far, the ideas have received little public attention. But the concepts that the pension professionals are wrangling over may ultimately hold answers for America's savers -- people who know they need to plan for retirement but can't imagine where to start. 
The debate is broken down into two main camps. By far the larger of the two clings to the traditional faith in stock-market investing. The other camp, smaller but gaining advocates, especially in academia, is challenging what it terms the cult of equities, calling instead for a return to extremely conservative bond investments.
Retirement savers who are using these investments may no longer dream of riches, but at least they won't lose their shirts. If this camp sees a place for stocks in a pension fund, it is only if they are hedged with derivative securities -- financial instruments that help protect against adverse price movements.
Not surprisingly, the first group includes most members of the financial establishment, corporate financial officers, asset managers, actuaries and others who are responsible for figuring out how much today's older workers will cost when they retire, how much money to set aside for them now and how to invest the money so that it grows enough to pay their benefits.
These professionals are well aware that the funds entrusted in their care have shriveled alarmingly in the last three years. Yet they still subscribe to the belief that if an investor's time horizon is long -- as a pension beneficiary's generally is -- history shows the investor will do best with a well- diversified portfolio, larded with stocks.
"These are long-term investors with a very long-term view," said Judy Schub, head of the Committee on Investment of Employee Benefit Assets, a Washington group that represents corporate pension officials. "These are not people who say, 'Oops!' and drop everything and change their strategy based on what's happening short-term in the markets."
If the opposing camp had a name, it might be something like "duration matching bond strategists," or "decumulation specialists." Off-putting terms, but behind them lies a body of thought that ought to be interesting to anyone fearful of having to park cars or flip burgers at age 87. 
The duration matchers' first piece of advice is to stop chasing the average 10.7 percent a year that seemingly everyone says stocks have returned since 1926. That strategy, based on a statistical illusion, they say, is doomed to land those who pursue it on the shores of negative mortality, the grim term actuaries use to describe outliving one's resources.
It's not that stocks have not really returned an average 10.7 percent a year for much of the last century. That number is right, duration matchers say, but it's the wrong number for retirement savers to focus on.
Infinitely more important is "the time path of returns," said Zvi Bodie, a Boston University finance professor and an outspoken proponent of duration-matching theories, both for pension funds and individuals. 
"Even if the average rate of return is high, one can run out of money long before one expires," said Professor Bodie, a co-author, with Michael J. Clowes, of "Worry-Free Investing," a book to be published this year that applies duration matching bond strategies to individual retirement planning. (Mr. Clowes is the editor of "Pensions and Investments," a trade publication.) 
Instead of stocks, the authors propose an ultraconservative fixed-income portfolio composed of inflation-protected Treasury bonds. To avoid getting locked in at a single low interest rate, they also advocate buying bonds of different durations, with the maturities staggered in what is called a ladder. 
If building a laddered bond portfolio sounds too boring after the casinolike thrill of the stock market, it's possible to add derivative-based bells and whistles to improve gains, much like professional fund managers do. But that's probably more complexity than individual savers want. 
There may come a time when individual savers can buy packaged laddered bond portfolios, with the derivative hedges built in. It's possible even today to find prototypes of investment vehicles with some of these features. But you have to go looking for them.
"It's slightly premature right now," said Shane A. Chalke, a Middlebury, Va., actuary and annuity expert who operates AnnuityNet.com, a Web site offering services to fee-based financial planners.
Mr. Chalke thinks it's a chicken-and-egg problem. The public doesn't know about the duration matching bond concept so it doesn't demand these investments; financial-services companies don't offer them because there is no demand.
One reason for the lack of demand is that individual investors have had it pounded into their heads that stocks will eventually yield 10.7 percent, if people hold them for a long enough time period. 
Mr. Chalke came by his opinion the hard way. In 2001, he devised an investment instrument called the Inflation Proofer, which would offer buyers a monthly pension check for life, indexed for inflation. He did it because the Bush administration was studying a Social Security overhaul then. He thought that if he created a retirement income plan that looked like Social Security and kept gun-shy people out of the stock market, the world would beat a path to his door.
His pitch line was, "If you like Social Security, here's where you can buy more of it."
Mr. Chalke located an insurance company, the Lincoln National Group, to underwrite the Inflation Proofer, but before they could start a marketing blitz, the stock market collapsed and plans to "privatize" Social Security were dead. Without legions of older Americans frightened of gambling their Social Security benefits on stocks, there was no market for the Inflation Proofer.
"On this site," he said of AnnuityNet.com, "we generally sell a couple hundred million dollars a year of annuities. But I don't think we've yet sold our first million of Inflation Proofer. The number is so small I don't monitor it." The Inflation Proofer is still available, through fee-based financial planners.
So far, there is only one big corporate pension fund showing the way for those who want to turn their backs on the cult of equities. In October 2001, Boots, a large British drugstore chain, announced that it had dismissed its pension manager, thrown out its equity-based asset-allocation plan and moved 100 percent into bonds. 
Boots may be unknown to most Americans, but to pension managers it has earned a place in history. By selling its equities when it did -- over 15 months in 2000 and 2001 -- Boots generated enough proceeds to create a surplus in its pension fund. It then locked in the surplus by buying high-grade corporate bonds, carefully matching the durations to the maturity of Boots's obligations to its retirees. A sizable share of the bonds are inflation protected.
WHILE all this was going on at Boots, virtually every other large pension fund in Britain and America was holding onto equities and riding the bear market down. 
Today, many of these companies are pumping large cash infusions into their pension funds. Boots, by contrast, has reduced its annual pension contributions by half. And because its bond portfolio is held passively, the drugstore chain has chopped its money-management costs from about $16 million to a thrifty $484,000 a year. 
Despite all this evidence, most pension professionals still question whether the Boots model can be universally applied. They say that American accounting rules are different, that stock prices are too low to permit selling now, and that it is simply "not efficient" to invest in bonds. 
Translated, that last argument means that as long as companies can argue they will earn 10.7 percent a year on stocks, they can save money by paying less cash into their pension funds than they would have if they had invested in bonds and measured their liabilities realistically. It's an appealing line of reasoning as long as it works -- but the failed pension promises of Bethlehem Steel and US Airways reveal what happens when it doesn't.
Mr. Bodie and Mr. Chalke have also been devising a successor to the Inflation Proofer -- a bond-based instrument that would offer not only a guaranteed, inflation-indexed monthly payout, but also an equity "kicker" that would use stock-index options to offer some of the market's opportunity without much of its risk. 
The financial tools for such a product are well established, Mr. Chalke said. What is missing is a sense of the need.
"The public need hasn't reached a critical mass yet," he said. "We almost need to go through that cycle, where people will be retiring without pensions, and you'll have case studies of people running out of money. It's going to take some people running out of money for the demand to emerge." 

Building a Ladder: TIPS and I Bonds
THE first step to rebalance a portfolio is for a retirement saver to sell some stock and put the proceeds into bonds. Professor Zvi Bodie, a finance professor at Boston University, said that Treasury securities were better for retirement savers because Treasuries eliminated the risk of default. He and Shane A. Chalke, an expert on annuities, favor two types of inflation-protected Treasury securities that were created in 1997, TIPS and I bonds. 
"If you're going to be in retirement for 30 years, even 2 percent inflation means serious erosion," Mr. Chalke said. "You're going to lose 45 percent of your purchasing power."
Like other bonds, TIPS of different maturities can be put together in a ladder, staggered to mature in the years the saver expects to need the principle. For people who aren't sure when they'll need the money, there are mutual funds that offer TIPS investments, but their prices fall when interest rates rise; to avoid this, savers can buy TIPS directly from the Treasury and hold them to maturity.
Though yields from these bonds may seem small, TIPS pay a bonus for each year that they yield less than the Consumer Price Index. Because this income is taxable the year it is paid, investors are advised to hold TIPS in a tax-deferred saving account, like an I.R.A. 
I bonds work much the same way, offering interest income that is indexed to keep pace with inflation. But because their interest can be tax deferred for up to 30 years, I bonds do not have to be held in an I.R.A. 
Another difference: I bonds are not traded on a market, like TIPS, but are redeemable at any time for the value they have accrued by the date of redemption. The accrual rate is predetermined, meaning that people can buy 30-year I bonds and get a ladderlike effect by simply redeeming them in the years they need the money. Taxes are owed on the interest that is earned at redemption.
Savers accustomed to the stock market's lure of double-digit returns, though, may wince when they go to the Treasury Web site (www .savingsbonds.gov) and discover that I bonds are currently paying interest of 1.6 percent. MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in the special Retirement section on Tuesday about alternatives to investing in stocks gave an incomplete description of I-bonds, which are inflation-protected Treasury bonds on which taxes may be deferred. While the fixed interest rate on I-bonds now stands at 1.6 percent, the bonds also pay an inflation-protection premium that is adjusted every six months. The current total return is 4.08 percent.

HEADLINE: THE UNRETIRED; 
As Layoffs Rise, So Do Age-Discrimination Charges

BYLINE:  By SHAIFALI PURI 

 BODY:
ONE thing has gone up since the economy has gone down: charges of age discrimination.
 Over the last two fiscal years, age-discrimination complaints filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have risen more than 24 percent, reaching levels not seen since the early 1990's. 
 The sharp increase, labor experts say, is largely attributable to the convergence of a weak economy and an aging work force -- nearly 50 percent of the labor pool is made up of baby boomers, and the percentage of workers over 65 has increased from the last decade. There are now more older workers for employers to discriminate against, and more economic incentives to do so. 
"The knee-jerk reaction of employers is often that they need to cut costs, and since older workers are perceived as costing more, they become targets of layoffs," said Laurie McCann, a senior lawyer at AARP. 
When companies are forced to reorganize, older employees are often perceived as being unable to keep up with new technologies. And because federal courts are often persuaded by arguments that reductions based on economic needs and business strategies do not constitute age discrimination, employers are emboldened to use such rationales as a cover to purge older workers, said John Clifford, a labor lawyer in Washington. 
Such tendencies are compounded in sectors of the economy that say youth is essential to innovation and progress, like technology. Because technology has been hit particularly hard in the downturn, Ms. McCann said, the stereotypes about the inability of older workers to keep pace and adapt, or that they represent higher costs, have an especially pernicious effect.
William S. Payson can speak personally about the industry's suspicious attitude toward older people. When he moved to Northern California in 1987 as a retired chief executive of a business-to-business marketing firm, he had such difficulty finding employment that he organized a brigade of his similarly challenged peers to wear buttons that read "hire the retired" around Silicon Valley. Today, Mr. Payson, now 79, is the chief executive of SeniorTechs.com, an employment database for older information technology workers. 
He said that the relentless quest for youth had always permeated the culture of technology, and that the dot-com boom made matters worse. These days, the "senior" tech workers that Mr. Payson's Web site serves are 35 and older. "It's amazing to think that in the technology industry today, 35 is over the hill," Mr. Payson said. 
Frederic Clancy, 71, and James Hurd, 60, would agree. They filed age-bias charges with the E.E.O.C. and a suit in federal court after being laid off from their sales jobs with Tektronix in 2000, an electronic equipment company. 
According to the complaint, they and a co-worker were abruptly transferred out of their telephone and cable sales group to form a new unit to sell an older, less desirable line. The three men were the oldest members of the sales force. (The third was planning on retiring in a year, and did.) Mr. Clancy and Mr. Hurd, each with about two decades at Tektronix, were told that their sales experience was needed in the new unit, Mr. Clancy said. 
What they say in the complaint is that, unbeknown to them, Tektronix was planning to sell their new unit. Four months after they were transferred, it was sold and Mr. Clancy and Mr. Hurd were notified that they would be terminated. "Prior to being transferred to the new unit, I was the top sales producer in my group and made the most money for the group that year," said Mr. Clancy, who had received dozens of sales awards. "It was inconceivable to me that I would be let go."
For Mr. Hurd, the disbelief was compounded when he tried to find another position within the company, something he said that was promised to him. When a sales position previously held by Mr. Hurd opened up, he saw it as a stroke of luck. "I had trained the guy leaving," Mr. Hurd said, "so there was no question of being qualified."
Instead, he was told that he was not right for the position. Upon being terminated, Mr. Hurd spent more than a year looking for work. 
Mr. Clancy and Mr. Hurd ultimately settled their case. Tektronix officials declined to comment, citing a confidentiality clause in the settlement agreement. 
Ms. McCann of AARP says that problems of proof hamper age-bias cases, especially when the question is failure to hire. "A lot of the discrimination in the technology industry is at the hiring end, and since you're not usually given a reason why you're not hired, it is difficult to prove," she said.
D. Jan Duffy, a San Francisco employment practices consultant and lawyer, said that many older employees were reluctant to litigate. "Plaintiffs' lawyers used to lament three years ago that they could not get clients to bring suits challenging egregious discrimination because the clients could so easily find other work, so it wasn't worth it to litigate," she said. "Today, while the effects of discrimination are so much worse, since it is so hard to find work, many of the people over 50 I have seen are just giving up and leaving the industry altogether, rather than asserting their claims." 
Mr. Payson argues that older workers need to take an entrepreneurial approach to seeking employment. He points to the demands for contract work in older computer languages, which mostly older technology workers are skilled to program. 
But for 58-year-old Marilyn Langenberg, such contract work was not a salvation. As a contract software programmer in Silicon Valley, she has been out of that line of work for 22 months and is now employed as a flower arrangement designer. 
Ms. Langenberg said that contract work was a last resort that she turned to when she could no longer avoid the age problem. She said she was repeatedly told she was overqualified. 
Ms. Langenberg has not had health insurance for three years. Still, she said, the thought of filing an age-discrimination suit has never crossed her mind. "I have always been far more interested in finding a job," she said.

HEADLINE: THE UNRETIRED; 
Nobody's Waiting To Take Their Places

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
JIM WEBER, who is 64, isn't interested in retiring, and he knows that he can keep working as long as he wants to. Here's the secret to his job security: what he does is so out-of-date, nobody wants to learn how to do it.
 Mr. Weber, a radio technician, calls himself a specialist in "trailing-edge technologies." That means repairing and refurbishing analog radio systems that are 10 to 30 years old and that the military wants to keep available as backups in case newer digital systems fail. 
 "Most things have a shelf life of five years or so, but the military likes to be cautious, which has kept me working," said Mr. Weber, who lives in Haddonfield, N.J.
Mr. Weber has counterparts around the country who work in fields as diverse as farming and nuclear engineering. What their industries have in common is dwindling work forces that are growing grayer by the year. When workers like Mr. Weber finally leave their job, there's an added twist: it may be the end of a particular line of work. 
"I've had engineers as assistants the last few years, but they all leave because, being young guys, they want to be on the cutting edge," Mr. Weber said. "What makes it creative is that sometimes the parts no longer exist, so I have to either create them or do some redesign. 
"It really is important work, but I can't get anyone but lab assistants to help me out. So this is about as secure a job as I can imagine. But when I go, I'm afraid the whole thing will go with me."
Doug Werstler knows that the day he retires he will be turning out the lights on a long tradition that has been undermined by economic, not technological, forces. 
Back in 1965, when Goodyear hired Mr. Werstler, the city of Akron, Ohio, was the world's tire-making capital. He estimates that there were about 13,000 factory workers for Goodyear and about as many across town at Firestone. Now, as president of Goodyear's union local, Mr. Werstler, 59, represents about 600 hourly workers. 
Most of those are headed for retirement in the not too distant future. "Our work force is older," he said. "Not many people see a long-term future in Akron in tires."
Tire manufacturing has long since moved overseas. In fact, the only tires produced in Akron are the big ones used in Nascar races. 
Mr. Werstler said the Nascar contract had three years to go, so he thinks he is safe for now, but he feels a sense of loss that goes beyond a job. "There used to be an American tire on an American car, and those days are behind us," he said. 
Mark McCarthy is part of a work force that is aging because of stability, not change. Mr. McCarthy, 50, is a nuclear power plant control-room operator at Seabrook Station in Seabrook, N.H.
He describes people in the nuclear plant work force as settled and generally satisfied -- unlike the disgruntled cartoon character Homer Simpson, who has a similar job. "It has taken a lot of training, but, yes, most of the people here are in their 40's and 50's," he said. "We like our jobs and are staying around, so I don't know that there will be a lot for young people right now."
Mr. McCarthy said that in the days after the Three Mile Island near meltdown in 1979, the federal government required more supervising engineers for checks and counterchecks at nuclear plants. In the last decade, though, that was considered superfluous, so engineering jobs like his at Seabrook and other facilities decreased slightly. In addition, most nuclear plants have consolidated among fewer owners because of deregulation, so some jobs were consolidated as well.
"I don't call my job exciting, but it takes expertise, so I think I will keep it to retirement," Mr. McCarthy said. "I guess you wouldn't really want it to be exciting, though, would you? That would probably mean something not so good."
Theodore Nesmith, 61, plans never to retire. He says he will work "as long as the Lord allows it," which is a good thing because he has no idea who would come after him. One of Mr. Nesmith's many sidelines is persuading young people to follow him into farming, a profession whose ranks are thinning.
Mr. Nesmith was not young when he began to farm -- and as a late-in-life black farmer, he is even more unusual. For 27 years, he ran an auto-body business in New York, but realized there was a hole in his life.
"I didn't love it and I especially couldn't put up with New York anymore," he said. In 1987, he moved back to Nesmith, S.C., his hometown, to farm land that the Nesmith family had lived on for more than 300 years. He raises organic vegetables on a 35-acre plot "because what you eat is what you are," he said.
But his children, like so many other farmers' children, are choosing a different route: his son is a lawyer and his daughter is studying to be a physical therapist. 
"Some people want to wear a white shirt and a tie and sit in air- conditioning and make their $50,000," he said. "But if there weren't any farmers, none of them would be eating."
A few years ago, Mr. Nesmith noticed there were no young people becoming farmers in his area, which is about 80 miles north of Charleston, so he started going to schools to chat up farming, and is trying to set up 4-H clubs.
He also works with the Federation of Southern Cooperatives, an African-American farming group based in Atlanta that is trying to keep the tradition of black-owned farms alive.
Last month, Mr. Nesmith began the cooperative's course in beekeeping. "Seems like another good thing to get involved in," he said.

HEADLINE: WELL-BEING; 
Prescription Drugs: A Guide to Options That Can Cut Costs

BYLINE:  By JULIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
IF you are retired, you have undoubtedly been discovering just how expensive it is to get a drug prescription filled. You feel the sticker shock not only because you are at that age when you start to need more medications, but also because your insurance is picking up less of the cost.
 Unfortunately, neither your medicine nor your health insurance coverage for prescription drugs will get cheaper any time soon. Last year, the drug industry raised prices by an average of 4 percent, twice the rate of inflation. Meanwhile, premiums for individual health insurance are rising 15 to 20 percent at renewal time. 
 Retirees with employer-sponsored health coverage are feeling the jolt less because almost all these plans include prescription drugs. But only 37 percent of those retirees ages 55 to 64 have an employer plan, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington. And Watson Wyatt Worldwide, an employee benefits consulting company, reports that only 3 in 10 Medicare beneficiaries have additional coverage from their employers. 
Moreover, profit-strapped employers are cutting back on retiree benefits, leaving substantial numbers of older people hunting down affordable prescription drug coverage. The Bush administration wants to include drug coverage as part of Medicare, but the executive and legislative branches of the government are a long way from agreeing on what form this should take. 
For retirees who are not covered by employer plans, there are options that can trim the cost of medications. But -- let's get the bad news over with -- they range between more and less unsatisfactory. Early retirees between 55 and 65 who want their prescription drugs covered will have to explore the expensive market for individual health insurance where price comparisons are difficult and applicants can be denied a policy based on pre-existing conditions.
The situation is slightly better for retirees who are 65 and over because they can choose between Medigap, which is supplemental coverage for Medicare, and Medicare+Choice, which are H.M.O.'s and may cover prescription drugs. There are also state pharmacy assistance programs for people whose incomes are too high to qualify for Medicaid but too low to handle out-of-pocket drug costs. In the last two years, those costs have risen nearly 50 percent, to an average of $996 from $644, according to the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a philanthropy that focuses on health care.
Retirees can also investigate ways to buy discounted prescription drugs, although 15 percent to 30 percent off the retail price on expensive medications will seldom equal the saving that is available through an insurance plan with a 20 percent co-payment. 

Eligible for Medicare?
Of the 10 Medigap plans, the last three, H through J, offer a prescription drug benefit. Plan J is the most comprehensive, covering 50 percent of drug costs up to $3,000. (The other two cover 50 percent up to $1,250.) If you want to buy a Medigap policy, be sure to sign up for it when you enroll in Medicare. If you wait until you are over 65, you will be "subject to underwriting" -- the tactful term the insurance industry uses to explain that you may not be eligible for coverage because of a pre-existing condition.
Even though Medigap policies are standard, premiums range widely, soit is advisable to shop around. Weiss Ratings, an agency that rates the solvency of insurers, sells the "Shopper's Guide to Medicare Supplement Insurance," which lists Medigap underwriters by region, a description of their policies and the premiums. (Go to www.weissratings.com; $45.) 
About 11 percent of elderly people who are eligible for Medicare are enrolled in Medicare H.M.O.'s through Medicare+Choice. You cannot be turned down for these plans for any reason, although insurers are cutting back on benefits because costs are outrunning federal subsidies. An exception is Aetna, which recently began adding back coverage for prescription generic drugs for some of its Medicare H.M.O.'s on the East Coast and in parts of Southern California.
Many insurers are getting out of their Medicare H.M.O.'s, forcing beneficiaries to find alternative coverage on short notice. Between 1998 and this year, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the number of Medicare+Choice plans declined to 155 from 346; over that period, according to Weiss Ratings, 2.4 million elderly people lost their coverage. If you are dropped from a Medicare H.M.O., you have a three-month open enrollment window to join a Medigap plan. Miss it and you are back in the "subject to underwriting" pool.
Lower-income older people who are not eligible for drug coverage through Medicaid can pursue state pharmacy assistance programs, which are available in 34 states. New York State's Elderly Pharmaceutical Insurance Coverage, known as EPIC, for example, is available to residents 65 and over with incomes of $35,000 or less if they are single, and $50,000 or less if married. Depending on income, those in the program pay either a fee or a deductible and then a co-payment of $3 to $20, depending on the drug's price.
Prescription drug cards from pharmaceutical companies are another saving alternative for Medicare-enrolled older people who have no drug coverage and meet certain income limits. The Together Rx card, sponsored by seven drug companies, offers saving of 20 percent to 40 percent on more than 150 medications for single people with incomes of $28,000 or less, and for couples with $38,000 or less. (Go to www .togetherrx.com.) The Pfizer for Living Share Card allows older people with incomes of $18,000 or less for singles, and $24,000 or less for couples, to buy a 30-day supply of any Pfizer drug for $15 at 51,000 drugstores nationwide. (Visit the site www .pfizerforliving.com.)

Options at Any Age
Another resource is the Internet, where retirees can research options and buy drugs. Georgetown University's Institute for Health Care Research and Policy, www.healthinsuranceinfo.net, offers a guide customized by state. Retirees can learn at www.benefitscheckup.org what benefits they qualify for by reading the section on drug coverage.
Discounted prescription drugs are available online. Cigna Tel-Drug, a unit of the health insurer Cigna, maintains an online pharmacy at www.cigna.com, where anyone 18 and older can buy a 90-day supply of medications and save an average of 35 percent off the retail price. 
Discount cards issued by pharmacies, insurance companies and AARP offer a percentage off a drug's retail price. The discounts vary and some cards may require fees. AARP offers a free card to anyone who buy its health insurance, and charges an annual fee of $15 to nonsubscribers. Fortis Health, an insurance company in Milwaukee, issues a card for $7.95 a month that covers a household and includes discounts on vision and hearing products and nutritional supplements. If you enroll in many plans, one card can cover what another might not. 
Drugs can also be bought, often at significant saving, from Canada and Mexico online or in person, although the legality of doing so is murky. The Food and Drug Administration is threatening to take action against insurers who encourage the practice. But the F.D.A. has indicated that it is not pursuing individuals who are buying small amounts of medications for personal use. "We're going after the commercial operation, not the individual who is buying drugs on a Web site," an agency spokesman said.
The F.D.A. has also raised questions about the safety of medicine bought in foreign countries, but the difference in prices can be so startling that many older Americans are willing to take the risk. 
The Maine Council of Senior Citizens in Augusta sponsors bus trips to Calais, Me., which is next to St. Stephen in Canada. In Calais, a doctor licensed both in the United States and in Canada examines the travelers and writes prescriptions that are then filled in St. Stephen. The council's director, Neena Quirion, said one participant who was paying $1,600 a year in the United States for the cancer drug tamoxifen now pays $85 a year for it in Canada.

HEADLINE: SAVING; 
Learning Painful Lessons of the 401(k)

BYLINE:  By FRAN HAWTHORNE 

 BODY:
TUAN Q. TRAN embodied the American dream -- until three years ago. 
 A boat person from Vietnam, he arrived in America in 1984 at age 11 with his family, virtually penniless. He worked his way through Virginia Polytechnic Institute as a waiter and a busboy to earn a bachelor of science degree in mechanical engineering. As an engineer at PRE Holding, a medical-equipment manufacturer in Midlothian, Va., since 1998, he faithfully put 15 percent of his paycheck into his 401(k) plan every year. Before he was 27, he had squirreled away more than $30,000 in the 401(k) and other investments. 
 But the dream -- Mr. Tran's and America's -- has faded. During the three years of the bear market, Mr. Tran, now 29, has lost $9,000, or about a third of his 401(k), and more in other accounts. In January, he cut back his paycheck contribution to 5 percent, figuring that "the market's not really picking up any time soon," he said. He doesn't even look at his account statements. 
"I'm not depressed," Mr. Tran said. "It's been an education for me." But he acknowledged that "it's been painful for me to save so much and lose."
About 40 million other Americans have been sharing that education with Mr. Tran, as they open their 401(k) statements every quarter. For the first two years of the weak market, people toughed it out as their accounts lost, on average, more than $8,000, or 18 percent, according to the Boston consultant Cerulli Associates.
Nor did worsening recession and higher unemployment seem to shake these investors. "You could argue that the investment community has gotten across the message that they should take the long-term view," said Kathryn Hopkins, an executive vice president at the Fidelity Institutional Retirement Services Company. "Or you could argue that it's a fair amount of inertia." 
Now, however, more 401(k) participants seem to have decided that they can't wait any longer for the market or the economy to improve. (Employees at a number of companies that have announced they will either reduce or halt their contributions to 401(k)'s have even further incentive.) Instead, they are shifting to more conservative investments, reducing the amount of money they put in or not joining plans at all. Some are taking cash from their 401(k)'s to tide themselves over until the economy improves. By the scores, they are flooding their benefits offices with nervous questions.
While the numbers are small, there are signs that this anxious activity has increased in the last 6 to 12 months. "Five years ago, if you talked to people, their crown jewel was the 401(k)," said Richard Koski, a principal at Buck Consultants, a human resources consulting firm. "Now they don't want to talk about it. They put their money in, but they see the red ink keeps growing." 
It's a feeling, Mr. Koski said, that he sometimes shares: his own six-figure retirement account has lost more than 20 percent of its value.
For many people, the instinctive reaction to a drop in the stock market is to pull money out of stocks and park it in safer investments like money market funds. Virtually every survey of 401(k) asset allocation shows at least a slight shift from equities, maybe 3 to 12 percent of the assets each year. 
Part of that shift is a result of falling stock values, which automatically lower the value of an investor's stock holdings compared with other investments. Still, there are 401(k) participants who have clearly gotten cold feet about stocks. In a survey of about 1,400 savers commissioned by the Principal Financial Group and conducted by Harris Interactive in December 2002, the latest quarterly "well-being" poll by the pair, 34 percent of the respondents said they had moved "from volatile investments to more stable investments" in their retirement savings because of "the current stock market and economic conditions." That is up from 22 percent a year earlier. 
Hedging their bets, investors often reallocate only part of their holdings. For instance, Ann Michelson, 43, an assistant vice president at GuideOne Insurance in West Des Moines, Iowa, still keeps four-fifths of her "low six-figure" 401(k) portfolio in aggressive stock and international funds. Last fall, though, she decided to become more cautious with her company's 3 percent matching contribution, dividing it equally between moderate and aggressive options. 
"I'm in there for the long term, but I realize I have to pull back from the aggressive approach I have traditionally taken," she said. 
Donn Hess, vice president of participant services at J. P. Morgan/ American Century Retirement Plan Services, said that by changing only new contributions, 401(k) investors "avoid turning a paper loss in the existing portfolio into a hard-dollar loss, but they also avoid future losses."
But that doesn't help people who need cash now. One solution is to reduce the 401(k) contribution or stop contributing altogether. Surveys by Principal, Fidelity, the Vanguard Group, Hewitt Associates and others show mixed trends on the reductions but a slide in participation rates -- the percentage of eligible employees who contribute to a plan -- to about 75 percent in 2001 and 2002, down from around 80 percent in 1999. 
The most common explanation is that people who lose their jobs and get a new one are not joining the new company's plan, possibly because they have taken a pay cut. In other cases, employees' spouses may have been laid off, so they have less money to save. Or new employees are scared to get into the market.
To pick up an even bigger infusion of cash, participants can take a loan against their 401(k) or a hardship withdrawal. Most retirement experts say they have not seen much change in these activities, but among Principal's 45,000 small- and midsize-plan clients, loan volume for the last three months of 2002 jumped 11 percent over the same period in 2001. 
Another way to get quick money from the 401(k) is to cash out all or part of its assets when leaving a job. Increasingly, departing employees with less than $5,000 in their portfolio are doing that, rather than rolling the distribution (as it's called) into their new job's plan or an Individual Retirement Account, even though the 2001 tax law makes such rollovers easier. Last year, 22.5 percent of 401(k) distributions were cashed out, up from 20.2 percent in 2000, according to Fidelity.
"These are people who are at the margin," said Ms. Hopkins of Fidelity. "If the economy has gotten tighter, $5,000 in your pocket probably seems better than $5,000 in your I.R.A." 
The biggest increase has been the inquiries flooding call centers and benefits offices. They run the gamut from panicky to sophisticated, from bitter to confused.
At the Brookshire Grocery Company, a chain based in Tyler, Tex., employees have been shifting their 401(k)investments out of the most aggressive of the company's five options and into the most conservative. As a result of that, plus market returns, the most aggressive has lost about 41 percent of its assets in the bear market, while the most conservative has gained 27 percent. "We try to explain that this is one of the cycles that we go through," said Marvin Massey, the chief financial officer. "But still, their emotions get in the way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: SHRINKING -- His 401(k) has lost a third of its value, but Tuan Tran says he's not depressed. He just no longer looks at his account statements. (Joe Mahoney for The New York Times) Graph tracks average 401(k) and total 401(k) Assets (in billions) since 1995.

HEADLINE: DECISIONS; 
Do You Want Your Money All at Once or Bit by Bit Forever?

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE MENCIMER 

 BODY:
LUMP SUM or monthly check?
 More and more pension plans are now offering workers the choice of how they want to receive their benefits: as the traditional annuity, in which they receive a certain income each month for life, or as a lump sum representing an estimate of the annuity's value. 
 This important choice -- which often catches workers unprepared -- is complicated, involving calculations that could make an actuary's head spin. And it has led to a certain amount of regret among some recent retirees who chose the lump sum, which looked like the better bet during the stock market's boom. 
Susan Jarvis faced that kind of choice when the stock market was at its peak. In 2000, Ms. Jarvis retired after 33 years as a faculty member and research librarian at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, where she had managed the gaming library. 
Advisers at TIAA-CREF, the nonprofit financial services provider that primarily serves employees in higher education and was handling her retirement plan, suggested that she put half her retirement money into an annuity, which would have given her a guaranteed income, with periodic increases for inflation. 
Ms. Jarvis was about to take the advice when friends she consulted asked, "Why are you doing that?" With the stock market still going great guns, they thought the annuity was a mistake. Feeling pressured, Ms. Jarvis wavered, unsure what to do. Finally, she chose to take the entire amount as a lump-sum payment after a financial adviser who was recommended by a colleague told her that he could get her a better return on her money, and pointed out that the annuity would not leave anything for her son when she died. 
Shortly after her retirement, the stock market crashed. Suddenly, the prospect of a guaranteed income sounded better. Ms. Jarvis said that while her investments had not fared as badly as some because they were highly diversified, she is still not sure she did the right thing. "I could have asked more questions," she said.
Her decision to take a one-time distribution puts her in an emerging majority of retirees, according to the Department of Labor's Employee Benefits Security Administration.
Today, about half of the Fortune 100 companies offer their employees a traditional pension with the sole option of lifetime monthly payments, compared with almost 90 percent of such companies in 1985, according to a recent study by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, an employment benefits consulting firm. Of the remaining half, about 30 percent offer defined-benefit plans that let employees choose between lifetime monthly payments and a lump-sum payment. (Some companies allow retirees to take part of the pension as a lump sum and the rest in reduced monthly payments.)
Given the choice, most employees will turn down an annuity in favor of managing their own funds, say the experts. This is partly due to widespread misunderstanding about the annuity as a financial instrument, according to David Certner, the federal affairs director for AARP. He said that when people chose a lump sum over an annuity, "Most are not even sure of the value of what they're choosing between." 
That was certainly the case with Ms. Jarvis. She said that when she chose the one-time payment, she was under the impression that if she died in 20 years, she would still have had a "significant amount of money" left in the annuity that her son would have to forfeit. In fact, if she lives to 85, as half of all women who reach 65 can expect to, the annuity would have paid out more than twice the lump-sum total. Also, she could have chosen an annuity that paid slightly less but refunds the balance of the investment to a beneficiary if the annuity's owner dies within a specified time period -- say, 10 or 20 years. In addition, all annuities offer "survivor" options for partners.
Annuities like the one Ms. Jarvis considered are known as immediate annuities because the payments begin right away and continue for life. Those offered through traditional pension plans usually save people significant fees, because the plans tend to have lower administrative costs than companies that sell annuities on the open market. And traditional defined-benefit pension plans are insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.
That is why actuaries do not consider these kinds of annuities investments but insurance against outliving your money. Still, many people think that annuities are risky because they think that if they die earlier than expected, they will "lose" their investment, according to Shaun O'Brien, the assistant director for public policy at the AFL-CIO. "There is this great fear that the day after they retire, they're going to get hit by a bus," Mr. O'Brien said. 
Until recently, Americans have generally been optimistic about their ability to invest better on their own than company pension funds can.
In addition, a quirk in the law has made lump sums slightly better deals. Congress has required companies to calculate how large a lump sum should be to match a given annuity schedule, on the assumption that the entire lump sum is invested in long-term government bonds. Because the interest rates of such bonds are at historic lows, the lump sums have to be higher to compensate. Many big companies have complained that, as a result, they end up overpaying on lump sums -- and that their pension funds are being drained.
Even so, advocates for the elderly worry that Americans do not fully appreciate what they are giving up by forgoing annuities. 
Lump-sum payments shift all the risk to the individual. Sometimes, people choose the lump sum unaware that their companies may subsidize the annuities of people who retire early, or that their retirement health benefits depend on their participating in a traditional pension plan. Ron Gebhardtsbauer, the senior pension fellow at the American Academy of Actuaries, said that a few years after choosing a lump-sum payment over an annuity, "A lot of people wish they hadn't done it." 
When making these decisions, it is a good idea to seek the advice of an expert who is neither your friend nor a financial adviser whose compensation will be affected by your choice, said Jack L. VanDerhei, a professor at the Fox School of Business and Management at Temple University in Philadelphia and an expert in risk management. Usually, he said, when people figure out the minimum amount of money they want to get every month for the rest of their lives, "most will see that they'll want an annuity."

HEADLINE: A Bounty at the Fair, Despite Expectations 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, March 17 

 BODY:
Between the likelihood of war and the depressed world financial markets, dealers at this year's European Fine Art Fair came here prepared for the worst. Many said openly that they arrived with scaled-down expectations and offerings. Yet visitors are still able to see a vast selection of what the market has to offer in nearly every collecting category from classical antiquities and old master paintings to contemporary art textiles, Oriental ceramics and 18th-century furniture. And there are a few spectacular items on view: a $15 million Bernini sculpture, a 19th-century diamond crown and a collection of imperial Mandarin hat buttons. 
 Still, there are far fewer blockbusters than in recent years. Not only are great works of art getting harder to find, but often when dealers do have something extraordinary, they tend to hide it away during bad economic times, afraid that if it doesn't sell, it will become overexposed and therefore less desirable. 
 "Dealers definitely seemed to be holding back this year," said Ian Kennedy, the curator of European painting and sculpture at the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo. "A few years ago they came with only the best, but now they are afraid of getting burned if they don't sell." 
Traditionally this small Dutch city has been an annual mecca for serious collectors from all over the world. But officials here report that attendance at this, the world's largest art fair, will be down about 10 percent from last year. By the time the fair ends on Sunday, they estimate 68,000 people will have visited the Maastricht Exhibition and Congress Center. Noticeably absent are the large number of Americans who would have come in years past but are probably too afraid to travel right now. 
No threat of war or depressed stock market, though, could keep the truly serious collector and art lover away from Maastricht. "I came here feeling very pessimistic," said Jean-Luc Baroni, the London dealer specializing in old master paintings. "But so far things have been surprisingly good." Charles Beddington, another London old master dealer, said he was "expecting to read a newspaper for 10 days." Instead, he said, he has not had a moment to sit down because of the barrage of inquiries about paintings. But so far he has made no sales. 
Browsing among the paintings and objects was Steven Cohen, the Manhattan hedge fund manager who has been a big art buyer in recent years. Also spotted was Mark Fisch, a real estate developer from New Jersey who collects old master paintings. Martha Stewart came, too. 
"I'm looking at furniture designs to get inspiration for my own furniture line," said Ms. Stewart. Allegations of insider trading with the founder and former chairman of ImClone Systems, Samuel D. Waksal, has not seemed to diminish her appetite for art or antiques. "Many of my friends told me they weren't coming," Ms. Stewart said. "But life has to go on." 
This year it seemed many dealers brought works that relate to recent blockbuster museum exhibitions. On the entrance to the Marlborough Gallery's stand, for example, is a 1993 abstract painting by Gerhard Richter, whose retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in New York last year piqued interest in his work. Nearby, at Waddington Galleries, there is a photograph by Thomas Struth, who is the subject of an exhibition that opened last month at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Also at Waddington are several other artists who are the subjects of Paris shows. There is a painting by Nicholas de Stael, whose paintings are being exhibited at the Pompidou Center; a work by Magritte, who is having a retrospective at the Jeu de Paume; and two paintings by Picabia, whose work can be seen at the Museum of Modern Art there.
Julian Agnew, the London old master dealer, was thinking of the popular "Manet/Velazquez" exhibition that opened earlier this month at the Met when he chose what to bring to the fair. Prominently displayed in his booth is a portrait of the "Buffoon Juan Calabazas, After Velazquez, 1879." James Roundell, a director of Dickinson Roundell, whose galleries are in New York and London, has proclaimed this "the year of Vuillard." He is referring to the exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Mr. Roundell has four Vuillards for sale. One of the best, "Interior at Night, the Hessels in their Dressing Room, Rue de Rivoli" from 1903, shows one of Vuillard's dealers, Jos Hessel, posed in a doorway while his wife, Lucy, is sewing. 
One area of the art market that has been especially popular recently is sculpture. Two terra cottas are standouts. Behind red ropes at the booth of Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, from Manhattan, is Bernini's model for the Fountain of the Moor, which is at the southern end of the Piazza Navona in Rome. It was bought at Sotheby's in London in July for $3.2 million. Without a signature, the auction house had said the sculpture, which depicts a river god with Moorish features struggling to hold a fish, had been attributed to Bernini. But now, with new scholarship, the asking price is $15 million. 
"It is the unanimous opinion of the Bernini scholars that it is by the artist," said Andrew Butterfield, a senior vice president of Salander-O'Reilly, who said that technical examinations had also indicated that the work was by the artist. Called the largest known Bernini terra cotta, it was made in 1653 as a presentation model for Pope Innocent X. 
Another terra cotta that is also getting a lot of attention is a bust of Voltaire from 1778 by Houdon. Made the year Voltaire died, the crisp details show him with a creased brow and just the trace of a smile. 
Old masters have always been one of the strongest areas in this fair. Among the best this year is a watercolor, "Crouching Cat," by Hans Hoffmann, at Hall & Knight. This circa 1578 work depicts a fierce-looking cat that looks as if it were about to leap out of its frame.
Mr. Baroni, meanwhile, is showing "Cleopatra" by the late-Renaissance master Il Cavalier d'Arpino; experts say it is one of the finest Italian pictures at the fair. 
One section of the fair that is constantly changing and strengthening is contemporary art. This season Sperone Westwater, the Chelsea gallery, is exhibiting for the first time. "We're pleased to be able to show newer work to this audience," said Angela Westwater, one of the gallery's owners. In addition to a wall of paintings by Lucio Fontana, this dealer also brought a selection of works by Richard Tuttle, Bruce Nauman and Susan Rothenberg.
In addition to the expected, people always come to Maastricht to find the unusual and the unexpected. This year, encased in glass showcase at S. J. Phillips, the London jeweler, visitors can see a diamond crown circa 1860 from an unidentified European princely family. At Ben Janssens Oriental Art, also from London, there are two exceptional Tang Dynasty sculptures: a limestone torso of a bodhisattva and a pottery figure of a girl seated on a stool. 
A wall of Italian 17th-century coral at Kunstkammer Georg Laue, a Munich dealer, has been so popular, Mr. Laue said, that he sold nearly half of them in the first two days of the show. And Linda Wrigglesworth, a London antique dealer specializing in Chinese textiles, is showing a collection of 19th-century Mandarin hat buttons.
"They represent the different ranks of the imperial court," Ms. Wrigglesworth said. "I have people who try to collect all the ranks. I've even got a client who puts them at her dinner table. She and her husband get the first rank, then she places the others depending on how she feels about each guest. It's a little cheeky, but it's their secret."

GRAPHIC: Photo: On sale for $15 million at the European Fine Art Fair: model, now confirmed to be by Bernini, for the Fountain of the Moor in Rome. (Salander-O'Reilly Galleries)

HEADLINE: 'Lost City' Yielding Its Secrets 

BYLINE:  By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
Working with new evidence and a trove of re-examined relics, many of them recovered from the basement of a Yale museum here, archaeologists have revised their thinking about the significance of Machu Picchu, the most famous "lost city" of the Incas.
 The new interpretation comes more than 90 years after the explorer Hiram Bingham III bushwhacked his way to a high ridge in the Andes of Peru and beheld a dreamscape out of the pre-Columbian past. 
 There, set against looming peaks cloaked in snow and wreathed in cloud, was Machu Picchu. Before his eyes, rising from the green undergrowth of neglect, were the imperial stones that have entranced and mystified visitors and scholars alike.
The expression "lost city," popularized by Bingham, was the magical elixir for rundown imaginations. The words evoked the romanticism of exploration and archaeology at the time, in the summer of 1911. And the lanky and vigorous Bingham seemed to personify the spirit that was driving discoveries of a forgotten past, the curiosity and courage to go seeking in remote places, as well as the hardihood to succeed. 
But finding Machu Picchu proved to be easier than solving the mystery of its place in the Inca empire, arguably the richest and most powerful in the New World when Europeans arrived. The imposing architecture attested to the skill and audacity of the Incas. But who had lived at this isolated site and for what purpose?
Bingham, a historian at Yale, advanced three hypotheses -- all of them dead wrong. A revival in research in recent years, experts say, has solved the mystery and, to a large degree, demystified Machu Picchu.
The spectacular site was not, as Bingham supposed, the traditional birthplace of the Inca people or the final stronghold of the Incas in their losing struggle against Spanish conquest in the 16th century. Nor was it a sacred spiritual center occupied by chosen women, the "virgins of the sun," and presided over by priests who worshiped the sun god.
Instead, Machu Picchu was one of many private estates of the emperor and, in particular, the favored country retreat for the royal family and Inca nobility. It was, archaeologists say, the Inca equivalent of Camp David, albeit on a much grander scale.
This interpretation and other new research inform a major exhibition at the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale. The show, "Machu Picchu: Unveiling the Mystery of the Incas," will be here until May 3. Then it is to travel to Los Angeles, Pittsburgh, Denver, Houston and Chicago.
Dr. Richard L. Burger, the director of the Peabody and a specialist in Inca archaeology, said the show, the largest on the Incas ever assembled in the United States, would "change the way people see Machu Picchu." Dr. Burger and Dr. Lucy C. Salazar, also an archaeologist, are co-curators of the exhibit.
"Bingham's work was very important in putting Inca archaeology on the map," said Dr. Burger, who is married to Dr. Salazar. "But we can now set aside all his ideas about the meaning of the Machu Picchu site."
The new interpretation, generally supported by other experts, is based largely on a study of 16th-century Spanish legal documents and a more detailed analysis of pottery, copper and bronze jewelry, tools, dwellings, skeletal remains and other material found in the ruins.
Many of the artifacts were themselves a forgotten treasure. Shipped back by Bingham, they were stashed in the museum basement, where they remained, still in their original boxes and wrapped in pages of The New York Times from the 1920's, until renewed interest in the Incas led scientists to poke into the stash. 
Until recently, there had not been much scholarly interest in Machu Picchu. Although the site has long been Peru's most popular tourist draw and a mecca for seekers of mystical and spiritual experiences, the haunting shellsof temples, palaces and other structures had ceased to attract many archaeologists.
"A lot of people felt it had become so much an icon for the Inca and Peru," said Dr. Craig Morris, a specialist in Peruvian archaeology at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. "They became more interested in working in places not so well known."
Bingham's long shadow may also have discouraged research. In his three expeditions to Machu Picchu from 1911 to 1915, he established himself as the "discoverer" and foremost interpreter of the lost city. His 1930 book, "Machu Picchu: A Citadel of the Incas," endured as the definitive treatise on the site. His maps and photographs of the ruins were authoritative and evocative.
But he was untrained in archaeology and he did not conduct systematic excavations and rigorous analysis. "His excavation notes," Dr. Burger said, "included more on what they were eating than what they were finding."
Bingham eventually resigned his professorship at Yale to enter politics, becoming lieutenant governor and governor of Connecticut and a senator. But his influence on Inca research remained strong, in part because of his fervid writing style.
In "Lost City of the Incas," a best seller, he wrote: "Here, concealed in a canyon of remarkable grandeur, protected by nature and by the hand of man, the 'Virgins of the Sun' one by one passed away on this beautiful mountain top and left no descendants willing to reveal the importance or explain the significance of the ruins which crown the beetling precipices of Machu Picchu."
Archaeologists today forgive some of Bingham's lapses in excavation, but they have destroyed his theories.
For example, Dr. Salazar's exhaustive examination of pottery contradicted Bingham's speculation that Machu Picchu was somehow associated with the earliest Incas. All the pottery styles were 15th century. That and other evidence suggest that construction on the site began around 1450.
That was in the reign of Pachacuti, considered the Alexander the Great of the Incas. His creation, like the empire, had a relatively brief history. From the recovered pottery and Spanish documents, scholars estimate that the site was largely abandoned after only 80 years.
Plague, brought to the New World by Spaniards, had by then left the land in turmoil, and in 1532 the Spanish conquered Peru with little resistance. The few Incan holdouts, including the last emperor, capitulated in 1572 at a tropical valley refuge that bore no resemblance in Spanish descriptions to Machu Picchu. So much for another of Bingham's suppositions.
His theory about a sanctuary for virgins and priests began to unravel in 1990 with the publication of research by Dr. John Howland Rowe, an anthropologist at the University of California at Berkeley.
In archives at Cuzco, the former Inca capital, Dr. Rowe found a 16th-century suit filed by descendants of Pachacuti. They sought the return of family lands, including a retreat called Picchu. The finding sent Dr. Burger, a onetime student of Dr. Rowe, and Dr. Salazar back to Machu Picchu.
"We then felt this was a royal estate, a country palace," Dr. Burger recalled. "All Machu Picchu is a big palace, the emperor's residence across from the temple, the dwellings and workshops, everything spread out around a great plaza."
As early as the 1960's, Maria Rostworowski, an ethnohistorian in Lima, pointed out that Inca rulers had established a chain of royal estates through the region. They served as occasional royal residences, but mainly as administrative centers. Many of the estates were razed by Spanish soldiers searching for gold, and some were built over and modified beyond recognition. But remote Machu Picchu, at an elevation of 6,750 feet, survived unscathed. 
Dr. Susan A. Niles, an archaeologist at Lafayette College who is the author of "The Shape of Inca History," published in 1999, explained that it has long been known that the estates were peculiar to Inca royalty. Each ruler established his own and built a palace there as a monument to himself.
Each estate was the ruler's own private property, which was left to his family after death. The succeeding son could use the estates, but not own them. So he immediately began building his own monuments.
The estates, Dr. Niles said, were important centers for the economic management of agricultural lands, forests and mines in the surrounding region. That was presumably true, as well, of Machu Picchu.
Dr. Burger and Dr. Salazar agreed, but said little evidence had been found that ordinary administrative affairs were regularly conducted there. They emphasized the role of the site, 50 miles from Cuzco, as a country retreat for entertaining visiting dignitaries and for royal relaxation.
Though called a "lost city," it was not a true city. Probably no more than 750 people ever lived there at any given time, and in the rainy season the population dropped to just a few hundred. They were presumably the servants and artisans who attended to the royal family and their elite guests.
Bingham was not entirely wrong about the religious aspects of Machu Picchu. The buildings, ritual chambers, fountains and gardens, Dr. Salazar said, seemed to be arranged with Incan cosmology in mind. Rulers were believed to be descended from the sun, and wherever they went was sacred. Pachacuti, in particular, was looked upon as a creator god.
New investigations turned up bones of animals probably sacrificed in religious ceremonies. And there were dozens of obsidian pebbles, which scientific analysis showed had come from a revered volcano more than 200 miles away. The obsidian had never been modified for use as cutting tools. It is likely, Dr. Burger said, the obsidian had symbolic meaning. The Incas worshiped high mountains as the source of supernatural forces. 
But Bingham had gone too far with his "virgins of the sun" hypothesis, experts say. He was misled by the findings of the party's osteologist, who reported that most of the skeletons buried at the site were those of women.
In new studies, Dr. John W. Verano, a physical anthropologist at Tulane University, determined that the ratio of female to male skeletons was comparatively even. His research also showed that many families and newborn infants lived there, not what one would expect in a community of virgins.
All the burials at the site were simple, with only modest grave goods. These were the remains of the retainers rather than royalty.
"This mortuary pattern," Dr. Burger said, "is not surprising, because if members of the Inca elite had died while residing at the country palace, they would have been transported to their principal residence in Cuzco rather than being buried at Machu Picchu."
Life at the country retreat must have been reasonably healthy. An analysis of bones showed that the workers apparently ate well. There were cases of tuberculosis and parasites, as well as considerable tooth decay from the corn diets. But nearly all the burials were of adults, including quite a few who were older than 50, an advanced age in that day.
The workers were brought from all over the empire, Dr. Verano concluded. The ethnic diversity was seen in the shapes of skulls, which had been deformed through binding in infancy. Different cultures over a wide geographic range had distinctive cranial deformations. Some came from the coast, and others from the highlands and as far away as Lake Titicaca.
Investigations by Dr. Alfredo Valencia Zegarra, a Peruvian archaeologist, and Kenneth Wright, a hydrological engineer from Boulder, Colo., have uncovered the magnitude of Machu Picchu as an engineering achievement. The Incas had not only terraced the slopes for agriculture, hauling up fine sand and topsoil from the valley and erecting stone retaining walls that have survived more than 500 years. But they had also taken an uneven ridge surface and transformed it to the flat mesalike surface seen today.
Before any of the buildings rose, the Incas leveled the site with loose rock and other fill, stabilizing it with immense walls deep beneath the surface. Mr. Wright estimates that the invisible subsurface construction constitutes some 60 percent of the effort invested in building Machu Picchu.
Whatever Pachacuti, the empire builder, had in mind, Dr. Salazar said, Machu Picchu "shows what the New World had achieved before the Spanish arrived." Some of the engineering and architecture was better than in Seville, she noted, and the Spanish "could not believe how people, people without writing, could have built something like this."
Archaeologists today may have demystified the lofty ruins, but their awe remains undiminished.
Dr. Niles of Lafayette College said the "overpowering landscape alone may be why Pachacuti chose the place for what his legacy to the world should be."
Conceding that he was biased, Dr. Morris of the Natural History Museum said that Machu Picchu "is to me the most spectacular archaeological site in the world."
