HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DEMOCRATS; 
Divided Democrats Concerned About 2004

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
With rising intensity and emotion, the Democratic Party finds itself divided over war in Iraq. The turmoil in the party -- and the rising voices of the antiwar wing -- are shaping the nation's view of the Democrats as they approach a national election that could turn on the question of the country's security, party leaders said.
 Officials in both parties say the image of high-profile Democrats challenging President Bush's war policy right up through his address to the nation on Monday -- and, in fact, beyond the speech, as was clear here today -- could reinforce a perception that Republicans are better suited to deal with threats from abroad. 
 Should that happen, Democrats say, it could pose a serious obstacle for the party if the White House and Congressional contests in 2004 -- unlike the contests of 1992, 1996 and 2000 -- are fought out on issues of national security and foreign policy.
The discord is apparent in every corner of the Democratic Party: on Capitol Hill, among presidential candidates divided over whether it is appropriate even to criticize Mr. Bush's Iraq policy with the nation almost at war, and at gatherings like a Democratic Party convention in California last weekend, where two White House candidates were booed for their pro-war stands. 
Polls show that rank-and-file Democrats are much more likely than the nation at large to oppose an invasion of Iraq, particularly without the consent of the United Nations. Many middle-level Democratic officials, not facing the pressure the party's presidential contenders have to take a stand immediately, are hedging their bets, in part because of the memory of the embarrassment of Democrats who opposed what turned out to be the successful invasion of Iraq by Mr. Bush's father in 1991.
Perhaps the most striking rift has been between the two power centers of the Democratic Party: its Congressional leaders in Washington and some of its best-known presidential candidates.
Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, criticized Mr. Bush's war policies right until Mr. Bush began his White House speech, reflecting the sentiment of many in their party caucuses. By contrast, four of the major presidential candidates, aware that the electorate that will vote in next year's general presidential election is much more in favor of the war than Democrats, voiced support for removing Mr. Hussein from office, even as they questioned Mr. Bush's diplomatic skills.
Democratic leaders said the divisions were emblematic of a party that has always fought its battles in public, and of an issue -- war and peace -- that has starkly divided Republicans and Democrats since the Vietnam War. Party officials, recalling that President Bush's father lost re-election after waging a successful and popular war against Iraq in 1991, said they remained hopeful that a second Iraq war would also be eclipsed by worries about the economy, and noted that polls showed unhappiness with Mr. Bush's management of it.
Even so, many analysts said the unfolding global turmoil means that foreign affairs could be as central to the 2004 elections as in any presidential race since 1980, when hostages were being held in Teheran and the Soviet Union rattled the West with its invasion of Afghanistan. Several suggested that should the war turn out well for Mr. Bush, he could undercut the Democrats' national security credentials next year. In 2002, Mr. Bush campaigned for a Republican Congress by focusing on Democratic opposition to aspects of legislation creating a domestic security agency.
"I don't think given the instability in the world today that the American people will elect a Democrat as president unless they trust a party on foreign affairs and defense issues," said Howard Wolfson, who was executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2002, when Democrats lost six seats, an outcome that many Democrats attributed to Mr. Bush's success in focusing on national security.
Mr. Wolfson recalled that his committee's polls charted rapid drops in public support for Democrats when the debate on the Iraq resolution began last fall. "This is a threshold issue," he said. "It's possible that it goes away, but I wouldn't bet on it."
Most Democratic presidential contenders said they would refrain from criticizing Mr. Bush while troops were heading into battle. But Howard Dean, a former governor of Vermont who is running as an antiwar candidate declared he would continue his attacks, war or no war.
Dr. Dean's position prompted concern among aides to his rivals, who suggested today that it was playing into the White House's hands. "If Howard Dean didn't exist, Karl Rove would have to invent him," said a senior adviser to one of Mr. Dean's rivals, in a reference to Mr. Bush's senior political adviser.
One of the Democratic candidates who was booed in California last week, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, said today: "In the first few days, America needs to band together and be supportive of the troops. This is not going to take very long, and if Howard -- I think anybody who knows anything about this knows there will be plenty of time to be critical."
Though worried, some Democratic leaders predicted that the potential war with Iraq would ultimately have little effect on the outcome of Mr. Bush's re-election campaign.
"Let's remember that this war -- if there is a war -- is likely to be a distant memory by November of 2004," Gov. Gray Davis of California said.
"The dominant concern will be the economy and what has happened to individual Americans," he said.
Ms. Pelosi said she did not believe Mr. Bush could successfully use the issue against her party. "They try to convey that image of the Democrats as weak on defense," she said. "I don't think we should take that. There is no party position on the war, much to the dismay of our grass-roots constituents."
Still, in a poll conducted for The Los Angeles Times in December, Americans by nearly 2 to 1 said Republicans would do a better job handling national security and the fight against terrorism. 
"The party is more of a party that tends to look for diplomatic solutions before military solutions," said Bob Kerrey, a former Nebraska senator and Vietnam veteran who ran for president in 1992. "It's not the image -- it's what the party is."
At least three of the major Democratic presidential contenders -- Mr. Kerry and Senators Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and John Edwards of North Carolina -- view security as a crucial issue next year. Mr. Kerry gave a speech today outlining measures that he said should be taken to protect Americans from terrorism.
That such opinions exist in the Democratic Party is testimony to how much it has changed since Bill Clinton led it back to power in 1992. He encouraged the rise of a moderate wing that resisted the image of Democrats as weak on defense. 
The four Democratic presidential contenders who support removing Mr. Hussein from power -- Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senators Kerry, Edwards and Lieberman -- all have ties to the Democratic Leadership Council, the group that helped propel Mr. Clinton's rise to national power.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John Kerry is one Democrat who backs military action. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM EUROPE; 
Germans Balk at the Price of Economic Change

BYLINE:  By Richard Bernstein 

DATELINE: BERLIN, March 18 

 BODY:
Given the frequency of protests against an Iraq war in this country lately, you would be forgiven for thinking that the marchers who gathered last Sunday in Berlin were another group demanding, "Nein zum Krieg" -- no to war.
 But they were not. These protesters, several thousand of them, were not even expressing a view on the other great issue in German politicsthese days: the 4.7 million, or 11 percent of the workforce, unemployed and a government in prolonged semiparalysis over what to do about it. The protesters' complaint had to do with a parliamentary decision allowing shopkeepers to stay open four hours longer on Saturdays, so that instead of a mandatory closing time of 4 p.m., they could stay open until 8 p.m. 
 The protesters were saying it would be contrary to what is often referred to as social justice in Germany to require shop employees to work longer hours on weekends. If that seemed slightly out of step in a country in "deep economic crisis," as the daily newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung put it, a time when talk of deep economic reform is in the air, there they were anyway, embodiments of a political fact of life here. Even rather small changes in the elaborate rules governing economic life inevitably provoke spirited opposition from some quarters.
What does that portend for the long-anticipated program of major economic change, including cuts in the welfare state, that was announced in a major speech by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder on Monday?
Needless to say, what it portends is that Mr. Schroder's program -- criticized by the left and by parts of the right, as too much, and by other parts of the right as not enough -- will pass in Parliament only with great difficulty and, in all likelihood, in a severely attenuated form. If recent history is any guide, the great German social welfare state, widely regarded as the root of the country's economic problems, will emerge from the process largely unscathed.
Germany has one of Europe's strongest commitments to what Mr. Schroder, in past if sporadic efforts at change, has called the nanny state. Many reasons are given for this, but one of them is that Germany has almost no tradition of laissez-faire liberalism of the sort that provided intellectual justification for both the Reagan revolution in the United States years ago, or the Thatcher revolution in Britain.
It may not be exactly a precise measurement, but a look at street names in Berlin might provide a clue to this. If you walk the area around Charlottenburg, a fashionable neighborhood somewhat akin to Manhattan's Upper West Side, you will note that many of the streets are named after great German philosophers.
There are Leibnizstrasse, Kantstrasse, Niebuhrstrasse, and Mommsenstrasse, all for illustrious figures in the great German tradition of moral inquiry. But there is no Adam-Smith-Strasse in Berlin, and in contrast to Austria, the homeland of such free-market avatars as Friedrich Hayek, there are few, if any, pioneering German proponents of economic liberalism.
"The great German cause has always been stability and unity," said Adam S. Posen, a Europe expert at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The Germans have not gone in for the Anglo-American tradition of individualism and free markets." 
This has been true, Mr. Posen said, since the great 19th-century unifier, Otto von Bismarck, introduced the welfare state to Germany.
"Bismarck provided goodies," Mr. Posen said. "It was unity and stability through goodies provision."
Other factors are often cited to account for the German cultural preference for what is called social peace versus the brutalities, as they are often described here, of American-style capitalism. Among them is the catastrophic economic collapse of the pre-World War II Weimar Republic, which was one of the main causes for the rise of Nazism.
The Germans, partly as a result of this trauma, have been willing to pay the price of economic rigidity in exchange for stability. They have worked hard so that, in the past, they were able to accomplish their goals.
But there is also a sense here now that Germany is failing in the competitive international economy and that something needs to be done. Also, in the newspapers lately was a photograph of a leading free-marketeer and critic of the government, Hans-Olaf Henkel, the vice president of the German Federation of Industry, washing glasses in a Berlin restaurant and being paid about $2.20 for his half-hour of technically illegal labor.
"Strictly speaking," he said of his stint as a temporary worker, "what I did violated the law."
It was a lighthearted jab at the opposite end of the spectrum from the shop-hours rally, a protest against the extensive labor market rules that make it very cumbersome to hire and fire people.
Mr. Henkel, who called the reform program announced Monday by Mr. Schroder a drop of water on a hot stone, said the deeper problem in Germany was that the main parties of both left and right were attached to the German social welfare system. This too would seem to reflect the absence of a strong intellectual tradition of laissez-faire liberalism in German intellectual life.
All of which brings us back to the streets named after philosophers. In fact, there are two streets named after Adam Smith in Germany, though none in Berlin. One is in Bremen and the other in Ingolstadt. 
Another thinker, however, is more popular in Berlin, the capital of a united Germany. Two streets and a square are named after the philosopher most globally famous for his critique of capitalism: Karl Marx.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has announced a program for major change in the German economy, including cuts in the social welfare state. His efforts might have drawn praise from Adam Smith, right, but probably not from Karl Marx, left. (Corbis); (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: TOKYO; 
Japan Premier Supports U.S. On Iraq Stance

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 18 

 BODY:
In the face of strong and growing opposition, the Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, expressed strong support today for the United States' ultimatum to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to leave his country within 48 hours or face war.
 "Now that it is determined that the extremely dangerous regime of Hussein has no intention to disarm, I believe it appropriate to support America's use of force," Mr. Koizumi told a news conference Tuesday. 
 Mr. Koizumi's foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, reinforced the Japanese government's message on Tuesday in a meeting with Iraq's interim charge d'affaires, Qasim Shakir. "If Iraq paves the way for the abolition of its weapons of mass destruction with the exile of President Hussein, the Iraqi people will be able to avoid damage stemming from military action," Ms. Kawaguchi was quoted as telling the envoy.
"Prime Minister Koizumi made it clear that because of the constitutional constraints, Japan will not participate in any military action against Iraq," said Hatsuhisa Takashima, a foreign ministry spokesman. "However, the government of Japan will make a thorough study on how to help the rehabilitation and reconstruction of postwar Iraq and contribute to international peace and stability while making utmost efforts to secure the safety of Japanese nationals and to prevent any economic disruption."
Japan's support of American policy toward Iraq has scarcely been in doubt here. But with his public opinion ratings plummeting and opposition to the war rising, Mr. Koizumi had always been careful to hedge his statements. Recently he said that Japan's response to any American attack on Iraq would depend on "the climate of the moment."
A Kyodo News Agency poll conducted Saturday and Sunday put the prime minister's support at 41 percent, his lowest ever. Of the respondents, 53 percent said the government should not back an attack on Iraq. Another Kyodo survey suggested that 68 percent of the country's legislators did not support an attack regardless of whether a United Nations resolution authorizing war was adopted. Numerous recent polls here have shown that over 80 percent of Japanese oppose Washington's threatened use of force in Iraq Japan's streets have grown lively with antiwar protests.
Despite public opinion against the war, Mr. Koizumi said that no additional Security Council resolution would be necessary before the expected attack on Iraq, because past resolutions had already legitimized the use of force to disarm Iraq.

HEADLINE: Split on Iraq May Harm U.S.-Europe Trade Ties 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER with ERIC PFANNER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 18 

 BODY:
With France and Germany at diplomatic loggerheads with the United States over Iraq, businesspeople here are watching nervously for signs that the trans-Atlantic dispute will spill over into commerce. 
 So far, the only confirmed example of a ruptured business relationship involves a small leather manufacturer in eastern Germany. The company's owner and chief executive, Grit Kuhnt, said it had lost an important American customer because of the German government's lack of support for the United States. 
 The case drew widespread attention here because Ms. Kuhnt wrote an angry letter to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, urging him to reverse his antiwar stance, so as not to sacrifice German-American friendship on the "altar of short-term political success." 
Mr. Schroder reaffirmed his opposition to military action today; so did President Jacques Chirac of France. The United States and Britain have blamed France for much of the diplomatic impasse. 
In such a toxic atmosphere, rumors about reprisals against French and German companies flare up regularly. The latest was a radio report in Paris on Monday that a French catering company, Sodexho Alliance, had lost a $1 billion contract to supply food to the United States Marine Corps.
Sodexho and the Marine Corps denied the report, though a spokesman for the Marines in Washington, Capt. Nat Fahy, said, "We have fielded a lot of protests over the fact that we have a contract with a French-based company." 
At the start of stock trading in Paris on Monday, Sodexho's shares plunged 14 percent before the confusion was cleared up; it recovered by the end of the day, and the company demanded an inquiry by market regulators.
Other French companies are lowering their national profile in the United States. Accor, the hotel conglomerate, has taken down French flags from 7 of its 10 Sofitel hotels in the United States. 
"It was a precautionary measure to calm the situation," Paul Charoy, a spokesman, said. "There's no political statement behind this. It's more a need we have to keep our customers and employees comfortable." 
For France and Germany, the economic cost of a sundered trade relationship with the United States would be enormous. Germany exports more than $56 billion worth of products a year to the United States, making it the fifth-largest supplier to the American market. France ranks ninth with shipments worth more than $26 billion a year.
France is the fourth-largest foreign investor in the United States, after Britain, Japan and the Netherlands. France and, to a lesser extent, Germany depend on Americans to support their tourism industries. Three million Americans visited France last year. 
Some businesspeople here say the danger to European companies is exaggerated, or at least misplaced.
The rise of the euro's value against the dollar -- which is making European exports, and visits to Europe, more expensive for Americans -- poses a greater threat than any political reaction. The shaky economy in the United States is curbing Americans' appetite for French Champagne and German sports cars irrespective of politics.
Luxury goods makers like LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France and Hugo Boss of Germany said they had not detected any reaction against their goods in the United States.
"People buy Hugo Boss suits because they are well made and fashionable, not for any political reason," said Philipp Wolff, a spokesman for the designer, which gets a sixth of its total sales in the United States.
Among German exporters of heavy machinery, however, there is less confidence. In a recent survey conducted by a German trade association, 25 percent of companies said that tension between Berlin and Washington had already negatively affected their dealings in the United States. If the tension persists, 63 percent of the companies predicted it would jeopardize their business relationships.
German automobile executives have also lobbied Chancellor Schroder about the risks to their exports in the United States. Mercedes-Benz and BMW operate huge assembly plants in the United States, which underscores that there are risks on both sides of the Atlantic.
Companies that depend on American government contracts feel especially vulnerable. When the Defense Department recently scaled back a $36 million contract with Krauss-Maffei, a German maker of armored vehicles, the move prompted speculation that the company was a victim of the political crosswinds. United States officials said the decision had nothing to do with Iraq.
American business leaders in Europe are campaigning feverishly to keep these jitters from multiplying.
"Germans worry by nature," Fred B. Irwin, the chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce in Germany, said. "I keep reminding them that procurement standards in the United States are so tight."
Business diplomacy has its limits, however. Mr. Irwin tried to mediate between Lederett, the German leather maker, and its American customer, Enefco International, which is based in Auburn, Me. He finally gave up. The owner of Enefco, Norman Farrar, said in his letter terminating his business with Lederett, "Hopefully in the near future the political climate in Germany will change and I will once again feel comfortable using Lederett material."
Nothing has changed yet, a company official said today.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lederett, a small leather manufacturing concern in eastern Germany, lost its contract with Enefco, a Maine-based company, because Enefco objected to the German government's position on Iraq. (Associated Press)(pg. W7)

HEADLINE: New Columbia President Has Ambitious Arts Plan 

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
Universities and colleges come in every size and shape, but in all of them the arts play some role. That role can be curricular or extracurricular. It can be to train professional artists or to try to cultivate an appreciation for the arts among the student body. It can involve teaching by tenured faculty or by famous artists with a greater or looser connection to the institution. It can entail visiting performances and a more or less active curatorial program by the university's museum. And it can take place in a bucolic rural setting or in the middle of a bustling, highly cultured city.
 Lee C. Bollinger, the new president of Columbia University, has long been known for his advocacy of the arts as integral to the university experience. He is also a hands-on reformer, as shown by his determination somehow to reshape the craft-oriented Columbia School of Journalism. 
 Mr. Bollinger comes to New York City after five years as president of the University of Michigan. Ann Arbor may not be entirely bucolic, but it is not New York. So Mr. Bollinger finds himself running a major Ivy League research university in the most highly cultured city in the United States. He gives every sign of relishing the prospect of forging more ambitious, more glamorous bonds between the arts and the university. 
"I can't imagine a great university without a school of the arts," he said in his Lowe Library office, thus effectively depriving Harvard, which lacks such a school, of great-university status. Mr. Bollinger was widely known to have been the runner-up to Lawrence H. Summers in Harvard's search for a new president.
"If you believe, as I do, that the arts are a fundamental means of thought and communication," he went on, "why wouldn't you easily conclude that they must be part of the university community? If I had to choose between an expository form of expression and an intuitive form of expression, I would choose the latter to be more profound. I think it's a false premise that the arts are an add-on to ordinary life."
Mr. Bollinger's plans -- some about to be announced, others more vaguely under discussion -- involve a new building, expansion and upgrading of the School of the Arts and the related undergraduate department of the arts; key appointments of well-known artists (like Mikhail Baryshnikov and stars from the theater and architecture); an aggressive expansion of collaborations with New York arts institutions; high-profile visits of national and international performance groups; and the widespread integration of such visitors into university life and community outreach.
"I couldn't do this in Michigan," he added. "What we can do here in New York City is fantastic."
An early (and to hear him tell it, still vestigial) example of such visits is the series of 12 performances by the Royal Shakespeare Company of an adaptation of Salman Rushdie's novel about the birth of modern India, "Midnight's Children." 
The performances begin tomorrow and continue to March 30 at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, near the university but until now separated from it by geography (Morningside Heights vs. the flatlands) and cultural differences.
Mr. Bollinger sits on the Royal Shakespeare Company board and sponsored its extensive visits to theUniversity of Michigan. The "Midnight's Children" production was produced by Columbia with the company, the University of Michigan and its University Musical Society.
The performances come at the end of a monthlong Midnight Children's Humanities Festival, which includes public dialogues, open rehearsals, readings and debates. Several courses in different departments have been devoted to the play and the issues it raises. A performance will be held for Harlem schoolchildren.
But Mr. Bollinger would like to go beyond that. He imagines Columbia as a "potential partner" with major New York performing institutions and museums, all devoted to the exploration of themes like the Spanish Golden Age or Elizabethan London or Vienna at the turn of the last century. " 'Midnight's Children' is an experiment in this kind of effort," he said. "I think that the usual cultural experience is far too limited."
In the longer term he hopes to initiate a "very major campaign" for a new building for the School of the Arts -- currently in the inadequate Dodge Hall -- and to expand its faculty and programs, all under the continuing leadership of its dean, Bruce W. Ferguson. The new building would be part of a larger "campus planning process" that Mr. Bollinger has initiated. 
Mr. Bollinger said Columbia might expand on the south side of 125th Street near the Hudson River, where it owns property, and possibly to the north. He is especially interested in developing dance and theater programs within the School of the Arts; currently, he said, the affiliated Barnard College for women handles most of those, and would continue to do so, but he wants to refocus attention on those disciplines within the School of the Arts as well.
Mr. Bollinger said his vision for the arts at Columbia was based on his perception of how the arts related to academic life in two models, the liberal arts college and the large research university. (Although there are also hybrid models -- such as Harvard's, which may lack a school of the arts but has a growing, university-supported range of student extracurricular arts activities -- which may flourish in part, some argue, by the very absence of an intimidating faculty presence.)
"In a small liberal-arts college, a permanent faculty may teach, but students participate fully; they are the leading actors, they dance, they direct and design," Mr. Bollinger said. "In a great research university, you can have the greatest artists involved. The students may play subsidiary roles, but they're not front and center. There's a lot to be said for each of those models."
One can raise doubts about some of this. Does New York, with its crazy quilt of cultural life, need more symposiums (which many institutions already provide) and imports? Doesn't Mr. Bollinger's fascination with the Royal Shakespeare Company, which has suffered some critical slings and arrows of its own back home in recent years, have a whiff of eager Anglophilia?
Mr. Bollinger stoutly defends the company, which he called "a superb institution, very much like a university." And he makes a convincing case that a large university can provide a more financially secure form of patronage, freed from budgetary fretting. But ultimately Columbia's new energies in the arts are intended to benefit not just the city but also the university community itself.
One might think that in pursuing his artistic agenda, Mr. Bollinger would encounter resistance from those who felt left out. A law professor himself, publicly devoted to issues of free speech and tolerance, he hastens to stress that expanding the arts will not preclude fund-raising and reforms in other parts of the university.
"Nobody has complained to me about my interest in the arts," he said. "We're going to devote tremendous resources to the sciences, the humanities and to journalism. A major academic conference might cost $200,000 but will have less impact than a magnificent cultural experience. There is a yearning within this institution to become a community, to realize what this university stands for, and to be more closely connected to New York City and to our surrounding community."
Noble words for potential arts philanthropists. But how many of them are left? How, in a time of economic recession and a general decline in cultural philanthropy, does Mr. Bollinger hope to pay for all this?
"One thing I've learned in fund-raising is that you can't try to time the market," he said. "It's always possible to get major gifts. And since it takes years to develop this kind of support, it's impossible to predict how healthy the economy will be in two or five years. So I'm proceeding with only the slightest amount of trepidation."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Sending 'Liberal Media' Truism to the Fact-Checker

BYLINE:  By ORVILLE SCHELL; Orville Schell is the dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California at Berkeley.

 BODY:
WHAT LIBERAL MEDIA?
The Truth About Bias and the News
By Eric Alterman
322 pages. Basic Books. $25.
 The attacks on the World Trade Center and our subsequent military involvement in Central Asia shocked Americans into a fleeting recognition of how dependent we actually are on the news media to keep us informed about complex global issues. Now at the brink of a war against Iraq and with the United States trying to redefine its leadership role in the world, we are reminded how crucial it is to have fair and accurate news media at home, especially as we find ourselves dealing with unprecedented national security concerns, resurgent patriotism and increasingly vituperative party politics. 
 Instead of focusing on how journalism might serve this country better as it faces these hours of decision, however, we find ourselves distracted and divided by a barrage of accusations from conservatives charging the media with liberal bias.
Over the last few years a host ofbest-selling books have relentlessly and theatrically attacked major news organizations, not the least of which is The New York Times, as irredeemably liberal. Among them are "Bias: A CBS Insider Exposes How the Media Distort the News," by a former television reporter, Bernard Goldberg; "Slander: Liberal Lies About the American Right," by the media critic Ann Coulter; and "The Savage Nation: Saving America From the Liberal Assault on Our Borders, Language and Culture," by the radio talk-show host Michael Savage.
Now Eric Alterman, media columnist for The Nation, has jumped into the ring and taken off his gloves. In an impressively researched and documented book, "What Liberal Media? The Truth About Bias and the News," he provocatively challenges this conservative wisdom as a mirage. He asserts that what Americans should really fear is the far better organized, more powerful and effective propaganda machine of the right that postulates the presumption of liberal bias through research groups, religious organizations, ideological news organizations and conservative personalities that "skews the entire discourse toward the right." 
"Unbeknownst to millions of Americans who continue to believe that the media are genuinely liberal -- or that conservatives and liberals are engaged in a fair fight of relative equality," Mr. Alterman writes, "liberals are fighting a near-hopeless battle in which they are enormously outmatched." 
He attributes this imbalance and the resulting rightward drift to new media-ownership patterns and to the enthronement of a veritable aristocracy of right-wing talk-show hosts and pundits whose party-line discipline and take-no-prisoners attitude toward liberal guests has kept conservatives "on message," thereby giving their collective movement the appearance of unity and clarity of vision.
"Conservative people tend to see the world in black and white terms, good and evil," observes Bill O'Reilly, the host of the Fox News Channel's "O'Reilly Factor." "Liberals see grays. In any talk format, you have to pound home a strong point of view. If you're not providing controversy and excitement, people won't listen, or watch."
Liberals, on the other hand, do not tend to see themselves as representatives for any ideological movement. Rather than emphasizing discipline, organization and uniformity of message, Mr. Alterman suggests, they favor self-criticism, diversity and fairness, which makes them weaker competitors, especially on the kind of sound-bitten yelling contests that increasingly characterize radio and television.
Regarding the right's savage attacks on Bill Clinton while he was president, "Democrats are not likely to give as good as they got," notes John Harris, White House correspondent for The Washington Post. "They simply aren't as well organized. And they are not shouting as loudly."
While this indisposition to shout may be viewed as a virtue in liberal circles, in the rough-and-tumble world of conservative versus liberal media mud wrestling, it is a liability.
But what really undermines liberals and renders them even less effective competitors, Mr. Alterman writes, is that they are often psychologically "cowed by a combination of conservative criticism and patriotic self-censorship." For example, he suggests that by the last presidential election, "the elite media had so internalized the false message of their own 'liberalism' " that they had lost the ability to defend themselves convincingly. 
While Mr. Alterman is a self-confessed liberal, he is only too eager to throw off the yoke of liberal wishy-washiness and fight fire with fire, taking on neo-conservative writers like Andrew Sullivan, Michael Kelly and Charles Krauthammer, who he claims "have carried the talent for malevolent invective with them like a communicable disease." He is no gentler on the progenitors of Fox-style television, disdaining executives like Roger Ailes, once an adviser to Ronald Reagan and the elder George Bush and now the president of Fox News, for merging political agendas with market fundamentalism. Mr. Ailes is quoted as saying, "News is what people are interested in," then adding, "We're just getting the same girls to dance around shinier poles."
Mr. Alterman is not, however, averse to pointing out the frequently conservative biases of news media celebrities from so-called liberal organizations like The Washington Post, The New York Times and CBS. Howard Kurtz, the media columnist for The Post; Frank Bruni, a Times reporter; and the CBS anchor Dan Rather all come in for some less than worshipful criticism.
But Mr. Alterman does not hold journalists primarily responsible for the parlous state of so much of the news media. Quoting Tom Johnson, the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and later the president of CNN, he makes the point that it is finally "the owners of the media who decide the quality of the news." 
Much of Mr. Alterman's wrath is reserved for broadcast media, especially cable television news. "Across virtually the entire television punditocracy," he writes somewhat plaintively, "unabashed conservatives dominate, leaving lone liberals to offer themselves up to be beaten up by gangs of marauding right-wingers." 
After jousting with right-wing accusers, Mr. Alterman finally brings the debate back to where it should end: are the American news media up to the task of keeping this democracy well enough informed to make intelligent decisions?
"The current historical moment in journalism is hardly a happy one," he concludes. "These irresponsible attacks come at the cost of the kind of information citizens require to understand the political, social, and economic context of their lives."
In the end, for most in the news media, the challenge is not so much dodging the enervating debate of conservative versus liberal bias, as it is doing credible journalism. As Harold Evans, the former editor of The Times of London, observed, "The problem that many media organizations face is not to stay in business, but to stay in journalism." This is the subtext of Mr. Alterman's interesting book.

HEADLINE: A Most Unsettling Time For French Wineries 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BORDEAUX, France, March 18 

 BODY:
Paul Pontallier knows the notebooks of Thomas Jefferson -- when he traveled to Bordeaux, what clarets he purchased where. And from his first reading of the Declaration of Independence, Mr. Pontallier became a fan of America.
 "Imagine," he said over lamb chops washed down with a 1989 Chateau Margaux, from the venerable French winery he has managed for close to two decades. "The right to personal happiness framed in the Declaration of Independence. Unthinkable in revolutionary France." 
 Here, not just in the heart, but the very aorta of deep French red, the histories of France and the United States are intertwined like the tangled shoots of a cabernet sauvignon vine.
So the threat of a boycott of French wines by Americans annoyed at the French position on Iraq is hard to take. And it could not come at a worse time for a struggling industry. Last year was a good year, but over all the industry is under siege.
Germany, the French ally on the Iraq issue, is the biggest export market for Bordeaux wines, but that is little consolation. Last year, the value of Bordeaux shipments there slumped 7 percent, because of the sour performance of the German economy.
Mr. Pontallier, 46, whose manner is as gentle as his wines, knows about the New Jersey restaurateur who poured robust bottles of French merlot into the toilet to express his grudge against America's former bon ami.
An hour's drive to the south, Christian Delpeuch, managing director of Ginestet, one of the biggest Bordeaux wine merchants, has faxed copies of The New York Post on his desk, sent by an American friend, with photos of French wines next to California and Australian wines, under the headline "Just Say Non." Over the non-French wines is printed "Oui"; over the French wines "Non."
"It's not just this," Mr. Delpeuch said. "It's the weakness of the dollar, too. That's what troubles me."
French wines have been losing ground in a lot of traditional markets. In Britain, the country that discovered claret, the market share of French wines had fallen by 2000 to less than one-quarter, from almost half 10 years earlier. The winds of change were buffeting small French winemakers everywhere, including Bordeaux, as wines from Australia, California, Chile, South Africa and elsewhere transformed the trade from the largely European monopoly it was when Jefferson strolled the lanes of Bordeaux into a global business.
The French are fighting back. Faced with huge multinational operations like E.& J. Gallo Winery of California and Southcorp of Australia, now the world's largest, the merchants of Bordeaux are banding together, designing new labels and promoting brands alongside the heritage of growing regions, often down to the fields surrounding chateaus.
Mr. Delpeuch's company, Ginestet, is a case in point. Once important Bordeaux wine merchants, the Ginestet family watched its fortunes collapse with the Bordeaux market in the 1970's, and the company was acquired in 1978 by Groupe Taillan, a local rival. With $275 million of annual revenue, Taillan now has long-term contracts with local winemakers and promotes its wines under brand names built around the prestige of Bordeaux. In recent years, Ginestet has had notable success in penetrating Asian markets, and has sales offices in Tokyo and Bangkok. But North America remains a tough nut to crack.
"In the United States, the French and other Europeans have been cannibalized by American brands," he said. "Today, I don't have a recipe for replanting a brand in the United States. We have the product and the brand; what's missing is the financial means to promote it."
To overcome this hurdle, the Bordeaux wine merchants are pooling their money and buying ads to promote the name Bordeaux. Mr. Delpeuch, who is also vice president of the Bordeaux trade association, said the total ad budget would rise this year to more than $23 million, from $19 million in 2002. In American magazines, the ads feature the sensuous curves of wine glasses filled with deep red Bordeaux, and the words: "Fine wines. Be seduced."
The campaign is paying off. Last year, sales of Bordeaux to the United States increased 28 percent by volume, and 13 percent by value, to 182.59 million euros, or $194 million. That leaves the United States just behind Germany as Bordeaux's biggest export customer. Bordeaux's success helped push up overall sales of French wine to the United States by 12.5 percent, to 28.8 million gallons, valued at $913.5 million. France is America's third-largest wine supplier, after Italy and Australia.
Last year, the dollar declined sharply against the euro, making anything sold in euros more expensive for Americans. That frightens some traders here more than the menace of a boycott. "The whole problem is there," said Patrick Bernard, the owner of Millesima, whose two million bottle stock and 35,000 clients worldwide make it one of the biggest Bordeaux merchants. "The dollar has lost against the euro, and the market is expecting cheaper prices for the 2002 vintage. You'd have to cut your prices by 45 percent to give the American consumer the same price. That is more serious than a boycott, which would last a short time."
Mr. Pontallier says that keeping with evolving wine tastes represents a far deeper challenge.
"With New World wines we are not in direct competition," he said. "The challenge is cultural. We don't make the same kind of wine. The challenge is to convince people that our criteria are still valid."
"We are not afraid; but it's a certain challenge."
Hence, any boycott would be painful.
"I am concerned," said Corinne Mentzelopoulos, who this month purchased the share of Chateau Margaux that she did not own from the Agnelli family of Italy. "For the last 20 years, Bordeaux has never been so successful and so prestigious."
Mrs. Mentzelopoulos's father, Andre, a financier born in Athens, acquired Margaux's properties in 1976 for 77 million francs, then worth about $17 million, as a bijou for his wife, Laura -- her mother. The properties are now valued at about $440 million, a 25-fold gain.
"I got letters," she said, referring to the threat of boycott, "and I answered them all."
"America saved us in two world wars and from communism," she said. "I haven't forgotten that."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
American unilateral bravado regarding the war would be misplaced and could be costly when it comes to the economy.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and the journal Indicators, and he also teaches at Cooper Union and New School University. His new book is "Why Economies Grow," from Basic Books. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
THERE have been a number of lofty pronouncements lately from commentators that the deepest interests of the United States and Europe are diverging. The Iraq crisis has obviously inflamed the rhetoric. 
 But those familiar with the economic developments of the last half century must be shocked by such claims. To the contrary, in economic terms, the nations of the developed world have never been so dependent on one another. 
 This includes the United States. Yes, its economy is the most powerful and the wealthiest. But to support its growth, it must attract hundreds of billions of dollars of the world's savings, much of it from Europe. It imports far more than it exports. Many of its best companies are dependent on foreign markets, simultaneously exporting products and importing parts and supplies.
Unilateral bravado on any nation's part is misplaced and will be costly. Increasing friction among allies will exact an economic price on which few people are focusing. 
The place to begin is America's need for foreign investment. The current account deficit, the amount by which imports of goods and services as well as income on financial transactions exceeds exports, must be financed by foreigners to the tune of as much as $500 billion a year. 
As a result, says Catherine Mann of the Institute for International Economics, foreign investors own 36 percent of American government debt, up from 17 percent in 1984, and they hold 18 percent of the corporate debt. Others estimate that European investors alone own 10 percent of American equities. 
Foreign investors, of course, did not buy American assets to do the United States a favor. They made plenty of profit on those investments. 
But in light of how much the United States depends on foreign investors, there is little room for arrogance. A change in investment attitudes can have a significant impact, forcing the dollar down, raising import prices and possibly forcing interest rates up even in a slow economy. In fact, the dollar has fallen about 20 percent in the last year, and foreign investors have been pulling back.
Also, many countries have increasingly opened their doors to American capital in the last decade or so. Such capital flows have been very profitable to American investors and financial companies. The Bush administration wants to end remaining controls on capital mobility. 
This would be an error. Hot, unrestricted capital was quickly withdrawn from Asia in 1997, contributing to the financial crisis. But political friction and growing distrust will also restrain useful changes and needed cooperation among nations. This will involve not only capital flows but also international accounting rules, bankruptcy procedures, World Bank policies and the rescue missions of the International Monetary Fund. 
As for the flow of goods, American imports have risen sharply, to 17 percent of gross domestic product, from about 5 percent in 1970.
But that does not tell the whole story. G.D.P. includes only final sales to consumers and to business for capital investment; it does not include most goods and services bought and sold between companies, like parts and supplies.
In total, Ms. Mann points out, imports come to nearly half of all the durable goods -- like steel products, appliances and cars -- that the nation's individuals and businesses consume.
In a recent Conference Board report, Gail D. Fosler, the board's chief economist, estimated that apparel imports come to 45 percent of domestic consumption by consumers and business. About 42 percent of all computers and office equipment sold are imported. In cars, imports equal almost 30 percent of American purchases. 
The rest of the world is lucky that the United States provides such an exuberant market. But domestic business and consumers also depend on the quality and uniqueness of overseas products, not to mention all that foreign capital.
At the same time, American companies -- often big exporters -- need foreign markets. J. David Richardson, a professor of economics and international relations at Maxwell School of Syracuse University, points out that companies that are both major exporters of products and importers of equipment and supplies often invest the most and pay the highest wages. 
Is this interdependence of trade and capital flows in jeopardy? The answer is yes. Mr. Richardson notes, to take a recent example, that deteriorating relations between President Vicente Fox of Mexico and President Bush over Iraq and terrorism have already resulted in a cooling of important discussions about changes to trade and immigration agreements. And there is a long agenda of trade grievances and needed changes around the world, both among rich countries and between rich nations and poor. 
Political decisions cannot be subject only to economic considerations, but fanciful and ideological claims about inevitably diverging interests are dangerous. They are also on balance simply untrue. 
Dividing the world between friends and foes will be economically costly. Trade and capital flows are by no means the only sources of growth in the world. Too often, workers' rights and environmental degradation have been ignored when it comes to liberalizing trade and capital flows. But few would argue that trade and capital flow have not been major contributors to growth.
Will the world return to business as usual after the Iraq conflagration? I have doubts, especially if more military missions are undertaken. Friction, supported by the new ideological claims, may be becoming embedded.
The economic goal should be the opposite -- to ease the path toward converging interests among developed nations, not to deny them. Even more important, the converging interests between the rich of the West and the poor of Africa, Latin America and the Middle East must be pursued. The latter in particular is essential to fighting terrorism in the long run. There is no standing alone in the contemporary world.

HEADLINE: Morgenthau Is Fighting Cuts to Investigations of Fraud 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
Faced with as much as $10 million in budget cuts, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, is trying to protect his office's resources by arguing that fighting white-collar crime is literally an investment that pays dividends.
 Prosecuting street criminals brings safer streets and is therefore good for business, tourists and residents. But beyond that, Mr. Morgenthau is arguing that investigations of white-collar and financial fraud in Manhattan deliver "an enormous financial return." 
 Mr. Morgenthau, who runs the largest district attorney's office in the city and has done so since 1975, has taken an unusually public stance on the issue and has taken his argument to the City Council. He contends that the mission of his office is unique in the five boroughs because it covers the financial heart of the city.
Over the last several months alone, investigations of white-collar crime and financial fraud in Manhattan have returned more than $6.3 million to government coffers, most of it from the buyers of fine art who were caught trying to exempt themselves from paying sales taxes. The prosecutors who pursue such cases are now the ones most vulnerable to cuts, Mr. Morgenthau said.
"The only place cuts can come from at this point are investigations," Mr. Morgenthau said. "We think that's shortsighted because investigations raise a lot of money for the city and the state."
Jerry Russo, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said that the Manhattan district attorney's office is not exempt from budget cuts, and that it could take a lesson from other departments in the city which have managed to operate with increasingly less money.
"We are confident that the district attorney will follow the Police Department example of doing more with less," Mr. Russo said, "and driving down crime 18 percent despite having reduced their headcount and their budget." (Mr. Russo said the cuts to which he referred happened over two years.)
The Manhattan district attorney's office has lost almost 15 percent of its budget over the last two fiscal years, and this year's cuts, if they pass unchanged, could lower Mr. Morgenthau's budget another 12.5 percent, to $54.2 million. Negotiations are continuing between the city and the district attorney's office.
Mr. Morgenthau and James Kindler, the chief assistant district attorney, said that they have already pared down the trial division to the bare minimum needed to staff the Manhattan Criminal Court, one of the busiest justice systems in the country. There have been no merit raises since the summer of 2001. Prosecutors routinely work more than 50 hours per week and are not paid overtime. Mr. Morgenthau estimated the unpaid overtime to be worth $17 million last year.
The annual class of 65 or so new hires was pared down to 40 last year. As for perks for the new assistant district attorneys, Mr. Morgenthau said, "we make sure they have a flag" for their offices. "If we're really going a long way, they get a rug and a flag," he said.
The investigations division, which accounts for 45 percent of the staff of 485 assistant district attorneys, is home to many prosecutors with rare expertise in complex financial investigation.
"You lose an experienced investigator, and you can't go out and hire someone with similar experience because they're not out there," Mr. Kindler said.
Some in the legal community say that the burden on big city prosecutors has grown, even as crime has fallen nationally. They say local and state prosecutors are taking more of the sort of cases that would have traditionally gone to the federal courts: expensive, labor-intensive financial investigations.
"Across the country we are experiencing cutbacks in the number of cases the federal government traditionally did because they are reorganizing their resources to do homeland security cases," said Dan M. Alsobrooks, the president of the National District Attorneys Association. "This is a very poor time to be cutting back on resources."
The amount of investigating a district attorney is compelled to do is also a function of location, Mr. Alsobrooks said, so it should come as no surprise that the Manhattan district attorney's office would use a significant part of its budget on financial fraud.
Mr. Morgenthau told the City Council this month that he feels his office must ensure fair-dealing in business and labor practices and maintain the integrity of the financial markets because it is located in Manhattan. "We're looking at cases that affect the economic and social viability of the city," he said.
Mr. Morgenthau said recent events, including the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and the stock market boom and bust, have created unprecedented opportunities for fraud. "It's worse now," he said, "the whole system of checks and balances seems to have broken down."
In one case being handled at the moment, investigators are trying to understand why an unlicensed Midtown money transmitter wired more than $3 billion last year to an off-shore bank, keeping the identities of the account holders hidden along with any hint of why they might want to stash billions of dollars in the Bahamas, among other places.
The answer to Mr. Morgenthau's questions might lie in 270 boxes of financial records that court-authorized search warrants have allowed his investigators to collect. If the parties involved are indicted on tax evasion charges and Mr. Morgenthau is able to successfully prosecute them, he said the government could expect to collect its due of $3 billion -- an amount that far exceeds the proposed budget cuts.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, says the mission of his office is unique because it covers the financial heart of the city. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Comptroller Expects City's Recession to Linger 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday that he expected the city to remain in recession this year for the third year in a row.
 "We still see this year as a bad year," Mr. Thompson said during a lunch with editors and reporters of The New York Times. "We see next year as, at most, I guess you would say, a flat year." 
 Mr. Thompson said that his prediction that the recession would linger took into account the possible economic effects of a war with Iraq, effects that he said would be difficult to estimate without knowing the duration of a war. He made the forecast a week after his office released a report showing that the city's economy remained in recession during 2002, even as the national economy began to grow moderately.
The bleak economic outlook makes it more difficult to close a city budget gap for the fiscal year beginning July 1. Mr. Thompson estimates that gap at $3.9 billion, and he said it had widened because of proposals by Gov. George E. Pataki that would cost the city money. Mr. Thompson held out hope that the city could win approval for some form of restored commuter tax, but not at the rate that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is seeking.
To make up for the difference, he said, the city will have to look at other possible sources of revenue. He said his office was studying the effects of imposing a surcharge on the personal income tax of high-income people for a limited time.
Mr. Thompson was cool to a proposal for the city to swap the land under La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, which the city owns, by giving it to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in exchange for the land of the World Trade Center site. He said he was not sure the trade would be a good deal for the city because the airports could provide significant revenue if the city was able to raise the rent for them.

HEADLINE: House Votes To Make It Harder to Seek Bankruptcy 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
The House voted overwhelmingly today to make it harder for people to eliminate their debts by filing for bankruptcy, heeding complaints from lenders and businesses that the system is being abused.
 Opponents of the measure, adopted 315 to 113, said it was flawed and ill timed because it could fall hardest on people already struggling in a troubled economy. 
 The authors of the long-sought overhaul of the bankruptcy system said it was intended to prevent people who could afford to pay some of their debts from using the courts to escape payment while protecting those who were truly strapped.
"For someone who is genuinely down and out and has no chance of repaying their debt, it doesn't change the law at all," said Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee. 
Mr. Sensenbrenner said the measure would force people who have some capacity to pay their debts to do so over the course of five years. "I don't think there is anything wrong with that," Mr. Sensenbrenner said.
Some Democrats, joined by consumer groups and labor organizations, said the measure was a bow to politically influential banks and credit card companies. The opponents said the lenders contributed to the problem by making credit too easy to obtain and already profited substantially from that part of their business.
"This is purely a bill by and for the large credit card companies and big banks," said Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of Brooklyn, who offered a Democratic alternative that was soundly defeated.
The bankruptcy measure has been circulating in Congress for years, and its fate in the Senate, where it has been caught up in an abortion debate, remains uncertain. The bill nearly passed Congress last November but died when opponents of abortion refused to support it because of a provision that would prevent protesters who block access to abortion clinics from avoiding court fines through bankruptcy.
That provision is not in the measure that cleared the House today, but Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, indicated he would try to attach it in the Senate.
"Just as creditors need protection from abuses of the bankruptcy law, so do women who are trying to protect their constitutionally given rights," Mr. Schumer said.
Proponents of the bankruptcy changes said they hoped they could finally move the measure without the abortion language, with the Senate under Republican control.
"We are going to work very hard to keep that out of the final bill," Representative Christopher B. Cannon, Republican of Utah, said, adding that he believed the margin of support in the House was the largest it had ever been in the half-dozen times the measure had been on the floor. 
All 225 Republicans voting supported the measure, along with 90 Democrats; 112 Democrats and an independent voted no.
Under the proposal adopted by the House, people filing for bankruptcy would undergo a screening that would dismiss those deemed to have sufficient resources to pay their debts or shift them to a process known as Chapter 13. People in that category agree to repay part of their obligations over five years as opposed to those filing under Chapter 7, which discharges most debts.
Credit card companies and banks say some people are gaming the system after running up large debts and then walking away from them. According to the United States Chamber of Commerce, bankruptcies have risen to 1.4 million a year from 348,000 over the last 15 years and cost other borrowers an estimated $400 each a year. 
"It is vital to our economy to bring a sense of personal responsibility back into a critically flawed system," Thomas Donohue, the chamber president, said.
Opponents of the bill say that the percentage of abuse is small and thatthe overhaul is poorly conceived since it considers in its screening process income that might no longer be available to someone who has lost his job.
"It is against the best interests of America to punish those families pummeled by record unemployment and soaring health care costs with inflexible bankruptcy reform," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the House judiciary panel chairman. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ANKARA; 
Turkey Limits Military Help to U.S. on Iraq

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, March 19 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said today that Turkey was poised only to open its airspace to American warplanes bound for Iraq, a degree of military cooperation vastly more limited than the United States had initially sought.
 Mr. Erdogan and other senior government officials said a resolution to be debated in the Turkish Parliament, probably on Thursday, would not authorize United States forces to use Turkish air bases and would not permit the movement of American ground troops through Turkey. 
 Citing that decision, both Turkish and American officials said today that Turkey would not receive a special package of at least $6 billion in new aid that the United States had offered. The aid was tied to full military cooperation, and those officials said it would be either scaled back substantially or eliminated. 
Today's developments caused an immediate plunge in stocks here. They also represented a setback for American military planning and reflected a serious strain in relations between Turkey and the United States, longtime allies and NATO partners.
"These two countries are strong partners," said a senior Turkish government official. But, the official added: "If you said there would be no impact on our relationship, that's unrealistic. There is going to be a sort of mark, especially on the American side. They are more upset than we are."
Even the use of airspace was not entirely settled, because the Turkish Parliament has to vote on it. Almost three weeks ago, the Parliament narrowly rejected an earlier resolution to allow American ground troops in Turkey and the use of Turkish bases and airspace.
The United States had wanted to move armed forces across the southeastern border of Turkey into northern Iraq at the start of an invasion, an option that might have expedited a military victory. For months, American officials pushed for such permission and were at times assured by the Turkish government that it was coming.
It is now out of the question. So is the possibility of using American military aircraft at the Incirlik base in southern Turkey for any imminent war efforts. Those jets have long flown from Incirlik to enforce a no-fly zone over northern Iraq.
Asked today if the new parliamentary resolution included American use of Turkish bases or the ability to have planes refuel in Turkey, Mr. Erdogan said, "No, none of those are in it," according to the Turkish state-run news agency.
Turkish government officials predicted that the scaled-back resolution for air rights would pass, but several Turkish politicians who strongly opposed the previous measure spoke out just as emphatically today against the new one.
In addition, a senior member of Mr. Erdogan's Justice and Development Party said in an interview that the withdrawal of the full American aid package might embitter some members of Parliament.
Both Turkish and American government officials said a new, reduced package could still be negotiated, especially if Turkey decided later to increase its cooperation with American military efforts in Iraq.
Justice Minister Cemil Cicek said today that a parliamentary motion to allow American troops into Turkey could re-emerge, prompting financial aid.
Turkish government officials fear that the country could suffer dire economic consequences from a war in Iraq. They say that Turkey lost of tens of billions of dollars in diminished trade and tourism after the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
They also worry that a war could lead to the establishment of an independent Kurdish state in northern Iraq and rekindle separatist demands among Kurds in southeastern Turkey, some of whom waged a prolonged, bloody campaign for autonomy during the 1990's.
In addition, the Turkish government is on guard against any movement of refugees into Turkey. Government officials said the new parliamentary resolution would include authorization for Turkish troops to enter northern Iraq to prevent that, although American officials are still urging Turkey to keep troops away.
Iraqi Kurds have warned in the past that they might shoot at Turkish soldiers coming into the region.
Zalmay Khalilzad, the American special envoy to the Iraqi opposition, concluded talks in Ankara today that were intended to ease tensions between Turkish government officials and Iraqi Kurds.
Those talks produced public assurances from Iraqi Kurds that they would put their military forces under the command of an American-led alliance.
Over the last two weeks, Mr. Erdogan's government had sent conflicting signals to the United States about how much military help Turkey could offer, and today began with Mr. Cicek saying that the new parliamentary resolution would include permission for American troops. Little more than an hour later, Mr. Cicek said it would cover only air rights.
In the brief span of time between those statements, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told the Turkish government that at this late juncture, air rights were the Bush administration's overriding interest.

HEADLINE: State Budget Cuts Endanger Famed Psychiatric Center 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: ORANGEBURG, N.Y. 

 BODY:
For a half-century, the Nathan S. Kline Institute, a state-owned psychiatric research center here, has won renown for its research on mental health, from drug treatments for Alzheimer's disease to violence among the homeless mentally ill.
 But as of July 1, under a budget proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki, the institute, in Rockland County, will no longer exist. Instead, it will become a satellite campus of the larger New York State Psychiatric Institute in Manhattan, and the state will eliminate 113 research positions from the combined institutions, with most coming from Kline. 
 The state has moved to close Kline as part of a huge package of cuts across all agencies meant to close a $11.5 billion budget gap over the next two years. The state's Office of Mental Health estimates that the state would save $7.8 million in the first year by merging the two centers.
The plan, which requires legislative approval, also calls for closing, by July, three upstate psychiatric centers that have fewer than 125 patients each, and closing the Bronx Psychiatric Center and the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center in 2005.
As for Kline, state officials say their goal is to end duplication of research efforts at the two institutes.
"The fact is that New York leads the country in terms of psychiatric research and will continue to do so," said Roger Klingman, a spokesman for the Office of Mental Health. "The idea is to preserve key areas of research and as much as possible go for administrative savings."
But researchers and advocates for the mentally ill say the merger will amount to a closing -- and a significant loss for mental health research, which has witnessed promising advances in recent years. They say Kline is noted for its applied research, looking at the practical problems of people living with mental illnesses.
Besides its studies of brain imaging and new drug treatments, the center, on the grounds of Rockland Psychiatric Center, has explored aggressive behavior, the impact of managed care on mental health financing and the dual diagnosis of mental illness and drug addiction.
"We're devastated," said Rena Finkelstein, co-president of the Rockland County chapter of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill. "It's a terrible blow to research."
Ms. Finkelstein, who sits on the center's institutional review board, overseeing research protocols, said researchers there brought in an additional $15 million a year in the form of foundation and government grants. "Some of them are multiyear grants, and they will come to a grinding halt," she said.
Legislative approval for the merger, and the rest of the cuts, is far from certain. On Wednesday, a State Supreme Court justice temporarily halted preparations for closing the three upstate centers until he hears a legal complaint brought by public employees' unions. 
A particular concern at Klein is the conflicting affiliations of the two centers to be merged. New York State Psychiatric is affiliated with Columbia University, while Kline has had a relationship with the New York University School of Medicine since 1979. Many researchers at Kline hold faculty positions at N.Y.U. and much of the research work takes place at N.Y.U.'s campus in Manhattan.
Researchers at Kline, who have been told by the Office of Mental Health not to talk to reporters about the planned closing, said that even if their positions were spared, their research would be jeopardized without access to N.Y.U.
"It's much more complicated than saying you'll cherry-pick the best research programs," said one researcher, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "How do you move people from one institution to another? The work I was doing, work that I thought was important for New York State, will now be interrupted for years."
Concerned about the impact of the merger, N.Y.U. has contacted state officials to try to work out a solution. In a letter to the commissioner of the Office of Mental Health, Dr. Robert Glickman, dean of the School of Medicine, even proposed that N.Y.U. acquire Kline.
But Dr. Andrew W. Brotman, vice dean for Clinical and Hospital Affairs at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine, said that so far the state had not been receptive in talks. "Attempts to come up with other solutions that would save the state the same amount of money have not been successful on our part," he said.
Dr. Brotman said state officials had indicated that the "bulk of the positions will come out of Kline" rather than the Psychiatric Institute.
This is not the first time Kline has been threatened. In 1991, during the financial crunch of the last recession, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget cutters proposed its closing,questioning the need for two research centers. But Kline was ultimately spared, in part because of the different missions of the two research institutes.
"Psychiatric Institute does basic research, and Nathan Kline really focuses on what impact services have on patients today," said Richard C. Surles, a former commissioner of the Office of Mental Health who fought to keep the Rockland research center.
While it is not a treatment center per se, Kline does provide treatment to local residents through experimental drug therapies that are not yet approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration.
Some families in Rockland County expressed dismay that their relatives might lose access to drugs if the merger went forward. Rose Angerame of Nanuet said her husband, Anthony, 83, had benefited from an Alzheimer's drug used in Europe but not available in the United States.
Mr. Angerame has taken the drug for about a year, with careful follow-up and monitoring at Kline. "They are amazed at how it has maintained the illness," Mrs. Angerame said. "It has not gotten worse, and there are no side effects at all. I'm very concerned."
Mr. Klingman said that some research would continue at Kline, whose two-story mocha-colored building here underwent a $40 million makeover four years ago. But Dr. Brotman said the cuts would hurt mental health research in general.
"We worry that this size of a cut and the elimination of Kline as a separate entity will result in instability among the remaining people," he said. "It is not possible to surgically remove programs from a site like that."

Harbus for The New York Times) Map of New York State shows the location of Orangeburg: The Nathan S. Kline Institute in Orangeburg may be closed.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
A City in Fear Loses Some Of Its Swagger

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE morning dawned yesterday with the awareness of a persistent grinding sound just outside the window. Probably a helicopter on a surveillance mission, came the thought, as sleep blessedly (if momentarily, alas) returned.
 Later, consciousness brought perspective. Silly, to think that the grinding noise was a hovering helicopter. Probably a garbage truck. 
 Or maybe not.
Alarmist thoughts seep in all the time now. Subtle fears have been part of life in New York for a long time, since Sept. 11. But they are more pronounced in the face of war, and it was unsettlingly apparent yesterday that those fears have blunted New York's insolent edge. For now, at least.
The brashness does not feel the way it used to. New York can take anything, and it has. But though antiwar demonstrators are as fierce as ever, the less political New Yorker seems chastened by terrorism's persistent threat and a troubled economy.
There are days lately when the sidewalks are passable and the breakfast coffee carts are still filled with seeded rolls by lunch. "It's dead," said Mojeb Hakimi, from his cart opposite Radio City Music Hall yesterday.
Maybe it's the talk of war, or school vacations; perhaps it's the economy in general, with everything from Wall Street to tourism hurting. Even guardians of the ever-optimistic theater industry are cautious, saying the theaters are slowly returning to normal after the recent musicians' strike, and cite the quieter-than-usual streets. "There's a general malaise in the whole city," one ticket agent said.
How could it be otherwise, given the sense of watchfulness and the suspicions? There are warnings from Washington; the possibility of new terrorist attacks; the Police Department's new Operation Atlas, its wartime security plan.
"Everywhere you look, there's a New York City police officer," said Nicole Orrell, a college student from Des Moines who was visiting Rockefeller Center with her family. Indeed, the block above the skating rink was watched over by four police cars, three police officers on foot, one on horseback.
Visitors seemed grateful for the police presence; New Yorkers seemed equally grateful or indifferent -- and maybe a little uncomfortable at the need for so much protection. Throughout Midtown, the police are on streets, in subways, at bridges and tunnels. They dominate Times Square. They are in front of ABC on the West Side, giving the thumbs up to Regis (live).
"It's a new way of life," said Steven Musumeci, a nine-year veteran of the Police Department, noting that the city now has to fight terrorism as well as more conventional crime.
Officer Musumeci was part of a four-officer team inspecting trucks on the southwest corner of 96th Street and Broadway yesterday, watched over by a homeless man conducting an animated conversation with himself; by people who stopped on their way into the subway station, glanced, then kept on going; by reporters who found themselves treated with unusual openness by the officers -- surely as deliberate as the show of force.
AT the checkpoint, one of several operating yesterday along 96th Street, nearly every truck and van was stopped for a brief examination by the officers, who checked licenses and registrations as well.
Another member of the team said that in two months of working at checkpoints, he has found some expired registrations, but nothing more. Is the effort worth it? "It's a precaution," the officer said. "We could find anything at any time. I hope we don't."
What was most surprising yesterday was the absence of animus, from passers-by and from the drivers themselves. It was not hard to imagine that a short time ago, the drivers would have resented the intrusion, complained that their rights were being violated, their livelihoods hurt. Yesterday, they said they were used to it and understood the rationale for the inspections.
"It's better to be cautious," said Gerard Romano, who was stopped on his way to delivering roast turkey to a deli downtown. Elad Bello, driver of the Oz Moving and Storage truck, didn't think the city was doing enough. "They should stop everybody," said Mr. Bello, who immigrated from Israel a year ago. "Better to be safe."
Hard to argue with that, though we have to admit missing New York's old stubborn carelessness. No place for that now. Not when the ominous sounds of hovering aircraft can invade our dreams, and make us wish for the growl of garbage trucks beneath our windows.
