HEADLINE: The New Uncertainty in Bridgeport: Who's in Charge? 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 19 

 BODY:
The conviction of Mayor Joseph P. Ganim on federal racketeering charges today may have ended the legal saga in this long-beleaguered city. But in other ways the outcome has placed Bridgeport in a new sort of limbo, with uncertainty mounting over the city's leadership in the coming days and months.
 Under state law, Mr. Ganim would lose his mayoralty only upon both conviction and incarceration. But today the judge freed him on bail and set a sentencing date of July 1. 
As residents of this polyglot, financially pinched city of 140,000 wrestled with their disappointment or disgust with the conviction, depending on their allegiances, the City Council called on Mr. Ganim to step aside.
"There is now no doubt that the public trust has been violated, that public confidence in the mayor's capacity to lead and effectively govern this city has been destroyed," said the Council president, John M. Fabrizi, who under the City Charter would automatically become mayor when Mr. Ganim resigns or is imprisoned.
"As we, the City Council, anticipate," Mr. Fabrizi said, "now is the time, for the benefit and the good of the city of Bridgeport, for the mayor to resign his position immediately."
Later, at an evening news conference, about 75 residents repeatedly shouted "resign now" and Mr. Fabrizi said Mr. Ganim had told him he would quit, but would not say when.
Across this 19-square-mile city, many people lashed out at Mr. Ganim. For months, they had heard testimony about the fancy gifts he had accepted as bribes, from custom-made suits and crates of expensive French wine to diamond earrings for his wife, Jennifer.
"Bridgeport's free now," said a visibly angry Joe Braca, who owns a dry cleaning business on East Main Street. "He took a lot of bread off the tables of Bridgeport citizens. We've been used and abused in this city."
Ron Smith, a mortgage consultant for Citibank and a Bridgeport resident, never accepted the defense argument that associates of Mr. Ganim had orchestrated the bribe-taking scheme without his knowledge. "Did he have on earmuffs and blindfolds?" he asked. "Come on."
But others here seemed conflicted about Mr. Ganim's felony conviction, which is certain to bring prison time. Those who know him, city employees, for example, kept talking about how sociable and caring he was as he navigated the warren of offices in City Hall. 
"He was very friendly and would not turn his back on anyone," said Jessica Santiago, a clerk in the city's benefits office. "He was always coming in with a smile, saying 'good morning.' I just wish that none of this had happened and he would go on being the mayor."
Others pointed to the myriad improvements in Bridgeport under his leadership. The economic rebirth was marked by the development in just the last five years of new shopping centers, supermarkets, a Home Depot, a multiscreen cinema, a minor-league ballpark and a 10,000-square-foot arena. 
Sonja Singletary, a cook who has lived in Bridgeport for 30 years, praised Mr. Ganim's efforts to rehabilitate her section of the city, the East End, which has a large African-American population. 
"He tore down a lot of abandoned houses and fixed sidewalks that had been broken for years," she said. "You feel safe and secure because we got police substations now. I love the mayor. Even though he's guilty, he's in my prayers every night."
Economic growth in the city started to stall in the last year or two. Business leaders say the mayor's troubles probably accelerated a downturn that would have come anyway, as the national economy faltered. But some are worried that the cloud of corruption could hamper further redeveloment.
Paul S. Timpanelli, president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, which serves as a chamber of commerce, said the city "was almost bankrupt" a decade ago, with "no leadership, no economic development and no private investment." What it did not lack, he said, was "rampant crime and a very poor public image."
"Over the mayor's term of office, until recently, all that was beginning to change and change dramatically," he said. "Unfortunately, the scandal has set us back. Whenever a city experiences the kind of scandal we're experiencing, businesses always hesitate." 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about reaction in Bridgeport, Conn., to the federal racketeering conviction of the city's mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, misstated the square footage of Arena at Harbor Yard, which was built during his administration. It is 41,000 square feet (10,000 is the number of seats).

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: TELECOMMUNICATIONS; 
A Trade Show Talks Shop Between Talk Of an Invasion

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, March 19 

 BODY:
Despite a giddy atmosphere including raucous parties in the French Quarter and the rollout of fanciful new mobile computing services, war worries were pervasive at a large international gathering of the wireless communications industry, which ended here today. 
 Participants in the three-day Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association's annual wireless convention, attended by nearly 40,000 people, seemed to spend as much time discussing the looming prospect of military action in Iraq as on ways to maintain growth in their industry. 
 The wireless segment has been a rare bright light in an otherwise gloomy global telecommunications market, and the trade show's organizers tried to direct attention to new data indicating that wireless subscriptions in the United States were up 10 percent last year, growing to 140.8 million from 128.4 million the year before.
But many at the convention found it hard to ignore the apparently imminent invasion of Iraq. 
"Some of my buddies are already over there in Kuwait," said Vik Sanchez, an Army reservist and sales representative for TimesTen, a Silicon Valley software company that had a small booth at the show. 
About 15 percent of the attendees and exhibitors came from outside the United States, about the same level as last year, said Kimberly Kuo, a spokeswoman for the association, noting that China, South Korea and the Scandinavian countries were strongly represented.
Samsung Electronics of South Korea had a large booth featuring a troupe of Broadway-style singers and dancers. But even there, the sales song and dance seemed only a partial distraction from geopolitics. 
"Any type of war is not positive," said Junho Park, who works in Seoul, South Korea, for Samsung's wireless handset division. "A lot of people are worried that North Korea could be the next bombing target after Iraq."
None of the international high-ranking executives scheduled to address the convention, including John Koo, vice chairman of the large South Korean company LG Electronics, and Jorma Ollila, the chief executive of the Finnish cellphone manufacturer Nokia, canceled their participation. Senior executives from American companies, including Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, took part in the gathering as planned.
Ted Turner, the vice chairman of AOL Time Warner, was on hand as keynote speaker today. Mr. Turner repeated indications that he made on Tuesday in New York that he might remain on the company's board, even after he steps down as vice chairman in May. His purpose, he said today, would be to help the company with strategy. "Who knows, the war might spread," Mr. Turner told the audience. "I'm good when things get bad. I don't run."
Many of the executives at the convention said they hoped that any conflict in Iraq would be brief and only minimally disruptive to the economy. Despite growing subscribership, relatively slack demand for next-generation wireless services and fierce competition among large carriers have meant sluggish growth prospects for many companies.
Among the innovative new services and products rolled out at the show and meant to buoy the industry's fortunes were so-called streaming video capable of delivering short movies on cellphones, sophisticated gaming consoles built into handsets. But some executives said war could at least temporarily distract consumers from such offerings. 
"A big issue for our industry with the war is that we want it over quickly so we can get more clarity as to where we're headed," said Rick Darnaby, chief executive of Somera, a company in Santa Barbara, Calif., that helps wireless carriers manage their networks more efficiently. 
Some people at the conference had broadly international perspectives, like Brandon Haase, who lives with his Turkish wife in Seoul, where he is a senior project manager for LG Electronics. 
Mr. Haase, an American whose parents live in Beirut, also has a Lebanese passport and is able to travel unhindered on business throughout the Middle East. He said he had recently returned from Iran, where he found people riveted by the prospect of war in neighboring Iraq.
"It's something that's understandably on people's minds," Mr. Haase said, measuring his comments as an international diplomat might.
Some others attending the trade show used the event as an opportunity to forget briefly about global uncertainty and, as some mentioned, the threat of retaliatory terrorist attacks in this country. 
As in previous years, public relations firms organized elaborate open-bar parties for several of the larger companies, even though the lavishness did not measure up to the boom times of a few years ago. 
"People want to have fun with all that's taking place," said Nicky Csellak-Claeys, a marketing executive from Belgium who works for Sony Ericsson, the Japanese-Swedish handset venture, which gave a party for more than 500 guests at the House of Blues nightclub on Tuesday night, with a mosh pit in front of the stage where the rock band Good Charlotte performed. 
But escape tended to give way to realities, whether mundane or cosmic. Jyrki Antikainen, an executive with Nokia, said he hoped flights back to Helsinki would not be delayed by military action. 
Keiji Tachikawa, chief executive of Japan's largest wireless carrier, NTT DoCoMo, took the larger view.
"The pending conflict is of a different paradigm than what we had during the cold war and in previous years," Mr. Tachikawa said in an interview. "It's a conflict between very different cultural models, which makes rational attempts to achieve resolution less effective."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: AUTOS; 
Detroit Fears Sales Will Turn More Sluggish

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 19 

 BODY:
Zero percent financing got this town through one war. But two?
 Car lots are emptying, and auto dealers, suppliers and analysts are worried that, in contrast to the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, Detroit may not have a tonic to offer a paralyzed economy. 
 "Zero percent has been around for quite a while," said Conrad Darby, who owns four General Motors dealerships in Sarasota County, Fla., "and the American public tends to get jaded on anything that's longer than their short-term memory." Sales, he added, are "very soft" this month. 
Even G.M.'s chief sales analyst, Paul Ballew, can muster only a tepid endorsement of the deals that have been the heart of the company's sales strategy for the last 18 months. "Zero percent continues to be more effective than any other offer out there," he said today. But, he acknowledged, "in this environment of uncertainty, we are all wondering how effective any incentive program will be." 
G.M. initiated free financing on Sept. 19, 2001, after the Bush administration appealed to Detroit for a patriotic gesture to rev up the economy. Ford and Chrysler quickly matched the offer, and the deals worked, stimulating consumer spending. October 2001 turned out to be the biggest sales month in the industry's history, and sales remained vigorous throughout much of 2002. 
The incentive spending cut into the Big Three's profits, but the deal making kept factories running, dealers happy and suppliers busy. It was also a boon for the economy at large, since automobiles and parts account for 3.5 percent of the nation's total output. The industry plays an even bigger role not just in traditional auto-making states like Michigan and Ohio, but also in Southern states like Alabama and Mississippi, where foreign automakers have factories.
This year, though, sales over all have been sluggish even as incentive spending -- particularly by the domestic automakers -- has continued to rise. That makes for an unattractive business recipe. 
"What are the incentives getting you? It's clear they are not working as well," said Maryann Keller, a veteran auto analyst. "There's no urgency or call to action from incentives anymore."
Some industry experts say that high gasoline prices, driven up by tight supplies and war jitters, are cutting into car sales over all and are beginning to color car shoppers' preferences. While S.U.V.'s in general continue to gain market share, for example, sales of the largest S.U.V.'s have been sluggish. 
Donald V. Esmond, general manager of the Toyota brand in the United States, said that Toyota's largest vehicles, like the Sequoia S.U.V., were selling "not as well as some of the more fuel-efficient vehicles," like the smaller Highlander sport utility.
He also sees evidence of at least a short-term shift by customers toward more fuel-efficient vehicles in sales of the company's Prius, a small car that saves gas by supplementing its internal combustion engine with electric power. 
"We sold 1,968 last month, up 32.9 percent from a year before," Mr. Esmond said. "It was our best-ever Prius month, and right now we're tracking to well exceed that this month."
Mr. Ballew, the G.M. sales analyst, said the weakness in sales of the biggest S.U.V.'s was "not because of fuel economy," but a result of the many alternatives that have emerged, like luxury and smaller S.U.V.'s and so-called crossover vehicles that combine aspects of cars and sport utilities.
Over all, February was the second- worst sales month of the last four years, with sales falling 6.7 percent from a year earlier, to a seasonally adjusted annual sales rate of 15.4 million vehicles. 
J. D. Power is expecting the pace to fall to 15.25 million in March. Last year, the industry sold 17.1 million vehicles in the United States, a strong showing.
Even as sales were falling in February, incentive spending rose 33 percent from a year earlier. Merrill Lynch, in a report this week, noted that automakers spent an average of $2,225 per vehicle on incentives in February, compared with $1,673 in February 2002. 
"Based on February sales results, we are concerned that consumers' responsiveness to incentives is beginning to dull," the report said. "Nevertheless, with inventories mounting, we believe still higher incentives are in store for the near future."
In the meantime, Wall Street has been cutting its earnings forecasts for the carmakers, and the Big Three have been cutting their production schedules. Ford announced last week that it would reduce production 17 percent for the second quarter, the sharpest cut yet. 
David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, has cut his 2003 earnings estimates for automakers and suppliers by an average of 24 percent this month. "At particular risk near-term, in our view, are Ford and its largest supplier, Visteon," he wrote in a report Monday. 
Ford has lost $6.4 billion in the past two years, and many analysts believe that it will struggle to stay out of the red this year. As goes Ford, so goes Visteon, which used to be a Ford division and still derives 80 percent of its business from the company. Together, Ford and Visteon employ more than 160,000 people in the United States. 
Some car dealers said this week that the manufacturers might again inspire shoppers if they brought back the across-the-board zero percent financing offers that were widely available for months after the Sept. 11 attacks.
"Zero percent for 60 months on a whole product line is very different than what's been out for the last few months," said Michael Maroone, president of AutoNation, the country's largest chain of dealerships. 
Jerry Reynolds, a Ford dealer in Garland, Tex., agreed -- though he blamed oil prices for consumers' decision to keep their wallets closed.
"People with large S.U.V.'s and pickups are not willing to give up what they have just yet, so they're waiting, and people who have more economical vehicles and would have moved up are waiting and thinking about it," he said. "Gas prices are our problem at this minute."
Mr. Darby, the Florida dealer, said, "We have to do something to whet the appetite."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PETROLEUM; 
Persian Gulf Oil Disruptions Have Already Begun

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
As the United States military completed its plans to invade Iraq, disruptions of oil supplies and shipments from the Persian Gulf appeared to have already begun yesterday, industry experts said.
 Most notably, exports from Iraq under the United Nations oil-for-food program dwindled to a trickle, a spokesman for the program confirmed, after Kofi Annan, the secretary general, suspended the program within Iraq on Monday. More broadly, some oil tankers scheduled to arrive at other Middle Eastern countries are refusing to enter the Persian Gulf because of security concerns, said Nader Sultan, chief executive of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation. 
 "Companies are saying, 'Do I send my ships up to the gulf?' " Mr. Sultan said in a phone interview from Kuwait. "And it's not just to Kuwait. Then, the question is up to the captain. Beyond insurance, it's safety, and someone has to make a judgment as to whether it's safe." 
He added: "It's already happening, already in the whole of the gulf, there are tankers not going up. Certain shipping companies and certain countries are rethinking that their ships shouldn't come here."
So far, the oil markets have shrugged off concerns that such disruptions could be substantial or last long. At the end of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, oil for May delivery dropped to $29.36 a barrel, while oil for April delivery fell $1.79, to $29.88 a barrel. The price of oil has fallen 21 percent this week on the belief that a war in Iraq will be quick and that there will be little damage to Iraq's oil fields and facilities.
Iraq shipped some of its biggest loads last week, averaging about 1.8 million barrels a day, according to Walid Khadduri, editor in chief of the Middle East Economic Survey and an expert on Iraq's oil industry. But shipments began to shrink considerably by the end of the week, he said.
Now, with the suspension of the oil-for-food program, the loading of oil from the port of Mina al-Bakr, Iraq, on the Persian Gulf has stopped, said Ian Steele, a program spokesman. He said that oil was still flowing from Iraq's northern Kirkuk field to the Turkish port of Ceyhan, where one tanker took on oil Tuesday and another is expected tomorrow.
Oil traders and other industry experts said they expected Iraqi exports to end soon, even from Ceyhan, because the Iraqis would probably shut down most production in preparation for the war. Iraq sends about 35 percent of its oil to the United States, according to PFC Energy, a Washington consulting group, and substantial shipments also go to European oil companies like Eni of Italy and TotalFinaElf of France.
Representatives of the oil industry said the industry would not be badly hurt by the suspension of Iraqi exports because it had already scaled back imports from Iraq over the last year.
A pricing plan for Iraqi oil under the oil-for-food plan proved particularly onerous and discouraged oil sales to many foreigners, oil traders and companies said. Iraq's own decisions throughout the year to increase and decrease exports at will also frustrated buyers. Over the last two months, Iraqi exports have increased as Baghdad compensated for a shortfall of oil from Venezuela because of the general strike there. Still, the growing probability of war over the last few months sent many companies looking elsewhere for more stable oil supplies.
"People have anticipated the possible cutoff of Iraqi oil for months now," said Sara Wachter, a spokeswoman for TotalFinaElf, whose own imports have fallen to "pretty minuscule levels" now from 2.5 million barrels a month in November.
Ms. Wachter said that oil companies operating in OPEC states were producing more oil along with OPEC members, which are producing far above their quotas to make up for the sharp decline in Venezuelan exports and for a possible halt in Iraqi oil. They are also buying up some of the extra OPEC output, she said.
But oil companies buying oil from other Persian Gulf states now face increasingly more expensive insurance rates that are making the journey to that region particularly difficult, industry experts said. 
Mr. Sultan of Kuwait Petroleum said that the broad hesitation to bring tankers into the gulf arises from memories of the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's, when oil tankers were strafed and bombed by the warring sides. He said he thought that this time, as in the first Persian Gulf war, Navy ships might be willing to escort tankers requesting such protection. A spokesman at the Navy Central Command in Bahrain could not be reached for comment. 
Moreover, the Persian Gulf countries will be willing to ship the oil themselves to foreign tankers that are reluctant to enter their waters, Mr. Sultan said. "If they're not prepared to come here, we're prepared to take the oil to them," he said. "There won't be a supply disruption. It will be more like a blip in programming. A country like Kuwait, we can make up for a shortfall by delivering oil south of Hormuz. All the logistics are in place. We just need to give the green light to put it all in motion."
Industry experts said that although official Iraqi oil shipments had all but stopped, a chance remained that Iraq could illegally export oil as it has long done, though in far smaller quantities. 
Over the last few weeks, oil traders have received reports that five to seven Jordanian-chartered tankers had each loaded about a million barrels of Iraqi crude oil at the Khor al-Amaya port on the Persian Gulf, a transaction and a port outside the purview of the United Nations. The tankers then moved through the gulf without being stopped by the United States-led Multinational Interception Force, which, traders say, routinely searches even small boats.
A spokesman, however, said United States forces do not routinely check ships belonging to allies. He added: "We consider Jordan to be a vital ally in the global war on terrorism."

HEADLINE: Time Runs Out: The Battle for Iraq Is at Hand 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "It's the Economy, Stupid. It's the War, Stupid" (Week in Review, March 16): 
 Your lucid description of the interconnection between the economy and war with Iraq misses one very cogent point -- the main economic rationale for invading Iraq. 
Victory in the war is likely ultimately to enable the United States to exert great influence over the control of Iraq's oil spigots and thereby help stabilize world oil prices. 
 Such an occurrence, while unpredictable, is also clearly doable, and would be a huge boon to the American economy and other Western economies as well. 
If such a scenario were to happen, all the arguments that have been raised in the United States both for and against war will quickly recede into oblivion, as will the protests of France, Germany, Russia and others.

JERRY RAPP
New York, March 17, 2003

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: NEW YORK; 
City Fortifies Entry Points To Guard Against Terrorism

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Concerned that river crossings are among the likelier potential targets for terrorist attacks, the New York Police Department sharply increased its patrols at bridges and tunnels yesterday. The patrols, along with inspections of trucks in Manhattan, slowed traffic to a single-lane crawl on entrance ramps and avenues.
 The traffic snarls were perhaps the most visible evidence that New York was feeling the squeeze of security in anticipation of the American-led attack on Iraq. Officials said that officers at more than a dozen checkpoints used hand-held devices the size of a cellphone to scan cargo for radiological material. 
 "The idea is to avoid anything going down there -- downtown -- blowing anything up," said Sgt. Al Flaxman, the chief of the unit inspecting trucks heading south of 96th Street in Manhattan.
The inspections -- part of Operation Atlas, the Police Department's comprehensive security plan to prevent retaliatory terrorist attacks -- reflected a sense of what might be on the minds of terrorists. While no specific threat against a particular bridge or tunnel has been received, officials said, in recent months intelligence analysts studying statements by captured terrorists found several mentions of the economic disruption that would follow an attack on any of the major routes into the city.
For that reason, police harbor patrols have been told to concentrate on the areas around bridges and tunnels, officials said. That directive strengthened an earlier focus on river crossings that included posting a police launch in the East River near the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges and installing a new system of surveillance cameras and alarms on bridges and tunnels.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge, has also stepped up truck inspections and is counting on help from New Jersey state troopers. City officials said delays on the bridges averaged 20 to 40 minutes yesterday, though drivers said they seemed much longer.
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said the checkpoints were among many prudent measures being taken. "When New Yorkers see the precautions we have put into place, they should feel assured that the city is doing everything in its power to protect them and feel free to live their lives," he said.
But, in an increasingly nervous city, some people had apparently decided not to venture out. There came a moment in the afternoon when someone seemed to pull the plug on tourism in Midtown Manhattan. "We were doing really well in the morning," said Peter Oratowski, a Gray Line tour guide at 47th Street and Eighth Avenue. "Then, in the afternoon, it just trailed off. I think they went home to watch television and wait for the war."
With the waiting came new precautions and preparations. State officials advised schools to prepare for "lockdowns" to protect students in case of terrorist attacks against schools. A memo from the State Education Department also advised local officials to review safety plans, increase surveillance of schools, restrict parking near buildings and consider postponing field trips. And the Police Department began distributing thousands of first-aid kits, respirator masks and rubber gloves for officers to use in response to chemical or biological attack.
For several weeks, additional police personnel have been assigned to several New York City bridges. But they have generally monitored traffic for unusual events and not spent much time stopping and searching vehicles. Yesterday, that changed, and some drivers were annoyed at the latest ritual -- being pulled over, being asked for license and registration, being asked to open the door to the cargo area and, in some cases, being asked to open packages.
"I'm behind schedule as it is," said Fernando Cruz, an appliance repairman who was stopped on Second Avenue on the way to East Ninth Street after fixing a refrigerator on East 114th Street. "It's slowing me up." 
The challenge for the police inspections was to strike a balance between the flow of commerce and the need to tighten security around what Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly called "the core business district."
"The definition of where that begins is somewhat flexible," the commissioner said. "We don't say it's only going to be at 96th Street. Quite frankly, we could do locations south of that anywhere before you get to 59th Street." Later, he added: "Don't hold us to the 96th Street location. That was kind of notional."
For much of the day yesterday, though, it was more than notional. The officers inspecting the trucks moved from avenue to avenue but were always along 96th Street -- officials said it was selected because it is a choke point well south of the George Washington and Triborough Bridges. The inspection team spent a couple of hours at Central Park West, but by the time an all-news radio station was broadcasting a report from there, it had moved to the East Side, first to Fifth Avenue, later to Second Avenue.
Sergeant Flaxman, of the truck-inspection unit, said the checks were different from those his officers usually carry out. Most days, his unit inspects trucks for safety problems -- bald tires, worn brake lines, cracked windshields.
"Now we're supposed to be out looking for anything suspicious," Sergeant Flaxman said. "It's preventive. It's good to have a nice show out here. Police presence is a deterrent."
And the level of scrutiny is likely to increase. The authorities have become concerned by various developments, including reports that men had been seen videotaping the undersides of the George Washington or the Verrazano-Narrows Bridges from boats or the edge of the water. But officials said the calls may simply have reflected new awareness of routine tourist activity.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow andS.& P. 500 Advance for Sixth Consecutive Day

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street notched its longest winning streak in nearly three years yesterday, as investors picked up shares before the deadline President Bush had set for the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to flee or face war.
 Analysts said volume was somewhat light as many investors chose to see what happened once the deadline of 8 p.m. Eastern time passed. Technology shares, however, sagged on a cautious outlook from Oracle. 
 "There's a sense of relief that we now understand all the war variables for the first time in a month," said Brian Pears, head equity trader at Victory Capital Management. "We know there's a military solution. That euphoria won't last forever, but it certainly accounts for one of the best rallies in three years."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 71.22 points, or 0.9 percent, at 8,265.45, for a six-day advance of 741 points.
It was the highest closing level since Jan. 23, when the Dow finished at 8,369.47.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.57 points, or 0.9 percent, to 874.02. The last time the Dow and S.& P. 500 had six consecutive days of gains was in August 2000.
A third market indicator finished lower, however. The Nasdaq composite index declined 3.48 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,397.07.
Oracle dropped 94 cents, to $11.31, after it warned that profits might sag if the anticipated war was not completed quickly. The news weighed on other technology companies, including Siebel Systems, which declined 53 cents, to $8.79.
"We're used to Oracle being the cheerleader in the technology sector since it historically has given us relatively positive guidance," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "Yet their guidance was cloudy, so that didn't help."
Investors have pushed stocks sharply higher in the last week, bolstered by hopes of a short and successful war with Iraq.
Still, analysts caution that Wall Street could quickly have losses should the military assault led by the United States fail to achieve a quick victory.
"Unfortunately, we're going to trade headline to headline for a while," Mr. Pears of Victory Capital Management said. "It's really difficult to say what the market will do in the short term, depending on what happens overseas."
"For the rally to continue, it would have to be a quick and relatively casualty-free war," he said.
Gainers included the military contractors General Dynamics, which climbed 67 cents, to $58.42, and Northrop Grumman, which rose $1.29, to $87.45.
Albertson's increased $1.25, to $20, after it reported fourth-quarter earnings that met analysts' expectations.
FedEx rose $3.50, to $55.18, after it reported earnings that fell a penny short of analysts' expectations.
But Bayer declined $1.19, to $14.21, pulling back after a huge increase the day before. The company's shares traded in the United States rose 37 percent on Tuesday after Bayer was cleared of liability in the first lawsuit to go to trial accusing it of ignoring research linking its cholesterol-lowering drug Baycol to dozens of deaths.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 5-to-4 ratio on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was moderate.
Bond prices fell. The benchmark 10-year note lost 20/32 , to 99 3/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.99 percent from 3.91 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year bond dropped 29/32 , to 106 24/32 . Its yield jumped to 4.93 percent from 4.87 percent.

HEADLINE: Spitzer Unpopular on Street He Made His Beat 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Fresh from a string of appearances on magazine covers and a statewide race in which he was re-elected with a commanding two-thirds of the vote, Eliot Spitzer is widely considered to be a politician with a future.
 Mr. Spitzer, a Democrat who is the attorney general, is widely acknowledged by both Democrats and Republicans as the candidate to beat should he choose to run for governor in 2006. His favorability ratings are high, according to the polls. 
 But a poll of those who work in the securities industry -- and those who recently did -- would probably show much different results. Reeling from a contracting economy and a loss of faith in the stock markets, many of the people who work on and around Wall Street see Mr. Spitzer at the root of their troubles. 
Many say his investigations into Wall Street practices continue to harm an industry that is already down and out, and accuse him of pursuing the issue for his own political gains. And they are angry.
Some said their feelings were evident this week, for example, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Gov. George E. Pataki and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor, were among the political notables invited to the gala 70th birthday party for Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup -- and Mr. Spitzer was not.
A spokesman for Citigroup did not return calls for comment.
Whether Mr. Spitzer's absence from the event Sunday at Carnegie Hall is related to his aggressive pursuit of malfeasance among corporate and Wall Street executives is unclear. But he has certainly left bitter feelings in his wake.
"Look I've seen this movie before," said Michael Holland, a former Salomon Brothers partner and a fund manager at Holland & Company. "Spitzer has obviously overreached. I view all of this as very Rudy Giuliani-like. Both of these guys made their mark the same way, and it turned out that a lot of it was overreaching and overzealousness. Eliot Spitzer is a good politician -- he saw his opportunity and he took advantage of it."
In response, Mr. Spitzer said that his investigations were necessary to clean up practices among Wall Street firms and that any price he might pay in unpopularity among executives was immaterial.
"Like most people, I would prefer to be liked than disliked," Mr. Spitzer said in an interview. "But does it matter if I'm disliked by some? No, it doesn't matter. My job is to enforce the law and we will continue to do that. I continue to believe that what we did was correct, what we did was important to the public interest and, in the long term, beneficial to Wall Street."
Mr. Spitzer added, "I don't mean to be cavalier about it, but if I've lost some friends, so be it."
In the Wall Street community, the animosity toward Mr. Spitzer is hardly a secret. He made a name for himself by taking out of mothballs the Martin Act, a 1921 state law giving the attorney general jurisdiction over securities trading. With that, he took on Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's biggest brokerage firm and a pillar of New York's financial community.
Mr. Spitzer's investigations unearthed damaging e-mail messages among Merrill stock analysts. He charged that the analysts, while portraying their financial advice as objective, urged customers to buy stocks they believed were bad deals to please companies whose investment banking business the firm wanted. Merrill Lynch has since agreed to pay $100 million in fines.
In a bear market, such investigations are easy, some Wall Street analysts said. But in this bear market, they have added to a climate of reluctance to trade stocks that has led to large layoffs in the industry -- as well as the city and state budget crises, which are caused largely by dwindling tax revenues.
Normally, these kinds of feelings would spell trouble for a politician seeking statewide office. But some suggest that Mr. Spitzer's troubles with Wall Street are unlikely to have much of an impact on his ability to be elected, should he decide to run for governor.
For one thing, they point out, the next gubernatorial election is three years away, an eternity in the world of shifting political fortunes. But they also say that for every Wall Street executive Mr. Spitzer has alienated, there are a far larger number of average investors who are more likely to view him as their champion.
"The attorney general has earned the affection of millions of disgruntled I.R.A. owners," said Evan Stavisky, a political consultant who works with Democratic candidates. "I think the average voter is certainly very enthusiastic about the attorney general's efforts to crack down on abuses on Wall Street."
Wall Street, Mr. Stavisky said, "is certainly not something to be trifled with." But, he added: "In raw political terms, they are dwarfed by the millions of people who have seen their life savings evaporate because of securities fraud. What he did seems more like a home run, politically."
And, should the hard feelings linger, he may have enough fund-raising prowess to offset the normally generous executives' closed wallets.
Some politicians close to Mr. Spitzer say that he believes the hard feelings are dissipating and, perhaps, will be gone by the time of the gubernatorial election, particularly if Mr. Spitzer is increasingly viewed as a front-runner. No one, they said, likes a winner more than Wall Street.
And, some point out, Mr. Giuliani was once loathed for leading Wall Street executives out of their offices in handcuffs. Now executives are jumping to hire his security firm and stand close to him at public events. Add in a return to a bull market and this, too, shall pass, they say.
"There are some business leaders all over this city, state and this nation who applaud what I've done," Mr. Spitzer said.
But will the anger hurt him should he decide to run for governor? "Maybe we'll find out," Mr. Spitzer said.

HEADLINE: Palestinian Becomes Premier, Diminishing Arafat's Power 

BYLINE:  By GREG MYRE 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 19 

 BODY:
In a move that marks the most significant cut in Yasir Arafat's powers since he became leader of the Palestinian Authority in 1994, his longtime deputy, Mahmoud Abbas, tonight accepted the new post of Palestinian prime minister.
 With the United States and Israel boycotting Mr. Arafat, the appointment of Mr. Abbas also offers some slim hope for restarting dialogue, and perhaps even peace talks, that collapsed during 30 months of Middle East fighting. 
 Mr. Abbas accepted the job at a meeting with Mr. Arafat tonight in the West Bank city of Ramallah, and the two men discussed the broad outlines of the future government, which the prime minister has three weeks to assemble.
Mr. Arafat, the pre-eminent Palestinian leader for more than three decades, has seen his authority diminished on several fronts in the last year. He wrangled for days with his own Fatah movement and Palestinian legislators over how much political control he would have to cede to the new prime minister.
Mr. Arafat, 73, has retained his role as overall commander of the security forces, and he will also have the final say on any peace negotiations with Israel. But Mr. Abbas, 67, will form the cabinet and handle the day-to-day running of the government, powers that Mr. Arafat previously held for himself.
The Israeli government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has placed tight restrictions on Mr. Arafat's movements since December 2001, and the Palestinian leader has left Ramallah only once, for a day trip, since then. Last summer, he responded to international pressure for reforms by shaking up his cabinet and appointing an influential finance minister, Salam Fayyad. That chipped away at Mr. Arafat's control of Palestinian finances.
With Mr. Abbas assuming office, Mr. Arafat will now have to deal with an independent-minded prime minister and an increasingly restive parliament that has shown its willingness to stand up to him. 
The publicity-shy Mr. Abbas, commonly known as Abu Mazen, has said almost nothing about his intentions, though his appointment has been widely welcomed.
Palestinian political reformers, who sought to dilute the power concentrated in Mr. Arafat's hands, have been supportive. The United States and Israel, which pressed for the creation of the prime minister's position as a way to neutralize Mr. Arafat, now say they are waiting to see how much influence Mr. Abbas will have.
Given Mr. Abbas's low-key style, and with the spotlight on the American showdown with Iraq, he is not expected to make any major announcements in the next few days.
"Maybe by the beginning of the next week he will be able to declare a government and define his plans," said the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo. "I do not advise him to take this step during the first few days of a war, because I do not think anyone will be listening."
Mr. Abbas faces huge challenges and Palestinians will be looking for him to deliver quickly. Since the Palestinian uprising began in September 2000, almost 2,000 Palestinians have been killed, the economy is in tatters, and Israeli troops operate throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
Mr. Abbas has said Palestinian attacks against Israel have been counterproductive for the Palestinians, though he has not said what he might do to stop them. 
In renewed violence today, Palestinian gunmen shot and killed a 50-year-old Jewish settler in a roadside ambush near Jenin, in the northern West Bank, the Israeli military said.
Mr. Abbas's choice for interior minister, the post that oversees the security forces, will be closely watched. Hani al-Hassan, the current minister, is likely to be replaced, according to Palestinian sources who are in contact with Mr. Abbas.
The United States favors Muhammad Dahlan, who until last year was in charge of the Palestinians' Preventive Security forces in the Gaza Strip, the sources said. Mr. Abbas is considering other candidates as well, and also is expected to confer with Mr. Arafat on the post.
Mr. Hassan held quiet talks last week with the Israeli president, Moshe Katsav, and said the Palestinians were prepared to retake control of security in the West Bank if the Israeli troops withdrew, the Israeli radio reported.
The Palestinians say their security forces have been decimated by the Israeli military crackdown, while the Israelis say they were forced to act because the Palestinians failed to halt suicide bombings and other attacks that have killed more than 700 Israelis in the current round of fighting.
The Israeli forces have been in or near Palestinian cities and towns in the West Bank since last June, and have given no indications that they are on the verge of leaving.
Mr. Abbas was a key figure in the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in the 1990's, and is seen as a tough, pragmatic negotiator. He is Mr. Arafat's deputy in the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the two men have been close allies since the 1960's, though they have also had bitter arguments over the years. Mr. Abbas has always preferred to operate behind the scenes, in contrast to Mr. Arafat, who enjoys the limelight.
The two men are both looking to move ahead quickly with the diplomatic initiative known as the "road map," which calls on Palestinians and Israelis to take a number of steps that will lead them back to full-fledged peace negotiations.
President Bush last week said he would formally introduce the plan when a Palestinian prime minister with "real authority" was appointed. The United Nations, the European Union and Russia are also backing the proposal.
But the plan has been sidelined as the Middle East violence grinds on, and the conflict in Iraq could also prevent any movement in the coming days and weeks.
Mr. Sharon says he supports the plan in principle. But his government objects to several key points, and wants the violence to end before taking the steps outlined in it.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

U.N. Envoy Sees Hope
(By The New York Times), UNITED NATIONS, March 19 -- The Security Council's special coordinator for the Middle East said today after the appointment of a Palestinian prime minister that "for the first time in two and a half years, I believe we have a real opportunity to begin rebuilding the shattered Israeli and Palestinian relationship." 
The envoy, Terje Roed-Larsen, told the Council that he saw "a small window of opportunity to get back to the table and out of the abyss of terrorism, violence, economic misery and general human suffering."
He called on the Palestinian Authority to declare an unequivocal end to violence and on the Israelis to stop attacks on civilians and demolition of Palestinian homes, and to dismantle West Bank settlements built in the last two years.
But Mr. Roed-Larsen laced his cautious optimism with sharp criticism of both sides. He called Palestinian suicide bombings "mass murder." He dwelt even more on recent deaths of Palestinians and one American in confrontations with Israeli troops in the West Bank and Gaza. The American, Rachel Corrie, was crushed by an Israeli military bulldozer.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Homes Where Industry Shied Away

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG'S plan to build or preserve 65,000 housing units is less a cohesive single program than a patchwork of actions and aspirations; a sum of parts as small as the rezoning of a few rather scraggly blocks in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx that might -- just might -- create some 300 apartments.
 Each piece of the patchwork has its own complications. For instance, there is concern that an important financing tool, the federal low-income housing tax credit, may be jeopardized by President Bush's tax cut proposal. 
 In the case of Morrisania, the complexity is historical. Though residential rezoning in the old manufacturing district along Washington and Third Avenues is now embraced by City Hall as part of the mayor's plan, it was a step that the city itself resisted in the early 1990's, when the Economic Development Corporation envisioned the creation of an industrial park. 
Last week, Amanda M. Burden, director of the City Planning Department, announced a new approach: a hybrid zoning district on 14 blocks from East 163rd to East 168th Street, allowing low-density light manufacturing and medium-density apartment houses, typically six stories.
In their environmental assessment, city planners estimated the rezoning had the potential for 321 units, said Kelly Murphy, deputy director of the Bronx planning office. Mixed industrial-residential zoning, called MX, was first applied to the Port Morris section of the Bronx in 1997.
"This is going in the right direction," said Adolfo Carrion Jr., the Bronx borough president, who holds a master's degree in urban planning. "I'm not going to pretend that it's going to be a SoHo or a TriBeCa, but it will be better for businesses and residents."
Because the proposal is beginning a 150-day public review, Mr. Carrion shied from commenting too specifically, though he noted that six-story buildings were the "signature stock for the working-class areas of the city."
A leading Bronx developer, Procida Realty and Construction Corporation, believes the rezoning "can't happen soon enough," said Christine Procida, its senior vice president. "We have a database full of people asking for housing." Working with the Economic Development Corporation, Procida is already planning a two-block retail center called Washington Plaza, between 163rd and 164th Streets, including a much-needed supermarket.
Foundations are being excavated for Taino Plaza, a six-story, 105-unit apartment building at Washington Avenue and 164th Street, by the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation. It required a variance but would have been allowed automatically under the new zoning, said Raffaela Petrasek, senior vice president of the city Economic Development Corporation.
OFFICIALS are also working with Katz Metal Fabricators and the Falcon Construction Corporation on industrial projects that would have retail space.
Morrisania's industrial zone developed alongside and to the east of the New York Central rail line. There were breweries, bakeries, commercial laundries and, until 1975, a large plant operated by the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, said Carlos J. Tejada of the Bronx planning office.
As a neighborhood, Morrisania was in dire straits by the 60's. "Its streets -- the playgrounds of its children -- are littered with broken glass, abandoned tires, discarded furniture, overturned trash cans and cannibalized cars," the City Planning Commission said in 1969.
Residential rezoning has long been a priority of Community Board 3. This was outlined formally in a community-based plan in 1992, the first such plan to be issued under Section 197-a of the City Charter.
At the time, however, city officials were pursuing development of the Morrisania industrial park, which would have preserved some of the substantial apartment buildings and local landmarks like the 19th-century Centenary Methodist Church, said R. Andrew Parker, who was the planner in charge.
The industrial park faced one insuperable problem. "There were just no takers," recalled Fernando Ferrer, who was then borough president and is now president of the Drum Major Institute for Public Policy. "Morrisania wasn't in the remotest sense an industrial park, just a hodgepodge of industrial users under what used to be the Third Avenue el."
With its junkyards and parking lots, Morrisania is an increasingly conspicuous anomaly in a residential swath that takes in the Melrose Commons Urban Renewal Area to the south, the Claremont Village complex of public housing to the north and a corridor on the Boston Road to the east.
"It makes enormous sense in terms of residential redevelopment," Mr. Ferrer said. As to the rezoning, he said yesterday, "The only good thing I've derived is that I've lived long enough to see it."

GRAPHIC: Map of the Bronx and surrounding areas: A hybrid zone in Morrisania has the potential for 321 housing units.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DESERT FRONT; 
In Day of Waiting, First Surrenders and the First Missile Attack

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, March 19 

 BODY:
Army engineering battalions acting as the vanguard of invasion late today pushed into the demilitarized zone along the Iraqi border as the first soldiers from Saddam Hussein's army, a group of 17, surrendered.
 Later in the day, the air war against Iraq opened with what military officials said wasa limited cruise missile strike aimed at Saddam Hussein, his sons and senior Iraqi leaders. 
 The missile attack followed a punishing day of sandstorms that raked the war zone along a 60-mile front, while American and British warplanes flew small-scale bombing missions against a dozen Iraqi artillery and surface-to-surface missile positions in southern Iraq that were within range of allied forces, military officials said.
United States military officials warned Iraqis against following Mr. Hussein's orders to destroy their oil fields, while Special Operations forces were said to be spreading through southern Iraq to prepare the battlefield. 
Late tonight, an American and British Army strewn across a vast desert landscape stood in eerie silence and at a high state of readiness under dusty moonlight, awaiting President Bush's order to move into Iraq. 
The White House acted only an hour and a half after the expiration of a 48-hour ultimatum demanding that the Iraqi leader and his sons leave the country. Earlier, the White House spokesman Ari Fleischer had warned that the nation was "on the brink of war" and that "Americans have to be prepared for loss of life." 
American warplanes dropped about two million leaflets on southern Iraq during the day, telling Iraqi troops how to surrender and how "to avoid destruction." They were instructed to drape white flags on their tanks and military vehicles, move away from them, throw down their weapons and wait for allied forces to round them up for processing.
Rumors of defection and uprising streaked through the region like tracer fire. First came word that Mr. Hussein's trusted deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, had defected, and then that residents of Basra, Iraq's southern port, were staging an uprising. Both were quickly deflated. 
Mr. Aziz turned up in Baghdad to give a news conference, and United Nations humanitarian workers on the Iranian border near Basra said they could detect no unusual activity in the city. 
Also tonight, in the most explicit warning to date, an Air Force mobile broadcasting aircraft beamed a message in Arabic to the Iraqi people saying that "The days of Saddam's regime are over" and asserting that the Iraqi leader had personally issued orders to destroy Iraq's richest southern oil fields.
The broadcast, monitored and translated by The New York Times, said: 
"You will face complete destruction if you comply with these orders to sabotage the oil wells. He can't destroy them himself. He will need your help. Follow the instructions of the coalition. You have two choices: listen to Saddam and face the consequences, or refuse to follow his orders and save yourself for a post-Saddam Iraq." 
The effort to protect Iraq's oil resources reflected the intensity with which the Bush administration is seeking to prevent the repeat of the environmental and economic disaster inflicted on Kuwait by Iraqi forces 12 years ago. But it also underscored the critical role those oil resources are expected to play in financing Iraq's reconstruction as Washington faces massive rebuilding costs and uncertain partners with whom to share the burden.
The first Iraqi soldiers to surrender came as a group of 15 men, according to Capt. Darren Theriault, commander of the headquarters company of the Third Infantry Division's First Brigade. Later, two more Iraqi soldiers gave themselves up near a farming settlement on Kuwait's border with Iraq. 
All 17 were in Kuwaiti custody, officials said. 
"There are no prisoners under American control at this moment, but we are prepared to deal with that," Capt. Theriault said. 
Mass surrender by tens of thousands of Iraqi troops was a daunting logistical challenge of the 1991 war. 
In the Persian Gulf, the commander of naval forces in the region, Rear Adm. John M. Kelly, said Iraqi air defense forces fired repeatedly Tuesday night at American warplanes that are rapidly escalating operations over southern Iraq. In response, Admiral Kelly said, Navy jets early this morning bombed a series of targets that he refused to specify, saying only that they were related to Mr. Hussein's "command and control capabilities."
At the same time, Navy officials said that their fear that Mr. Hussein had dispatched more than 250 small cargo and fishing vessels into the gulf from Iraqi ports to conduct suicide missions against allied warships was a false alarm. The vessels, mostly small traders manned by South Asian crews, were either fleeing the region or were ordered to leave Iraq after Mr. Bush's Monday night speech.
Most of the dhows were checked and allowed to leave the Persian Gulf. But one was attacked by a Kuwaiti Coast Guard vessel, killing a crewman in what the Navy described as an "unfortunate accident."
At midmorning, the commander of the Navy's Fifth Fleet, Vice Adm. Timothy J. Keating, flew aboard the carrier Abraham Lincoln to rouse a crew of 6,000 that tomorrow will enter the ninth month of its deployment, one of the longest in modern naval history.
Facing a throng of sailors on the hangar deck, the admiral told the crew members that their names would be written "in gold" on the pages of history for helping to liberate the Iraqi people.
"Folks who have never known freedom, who have never been able to worship at the time and place of their choosing, will now be able to speak freely, to worship when and where they choose, to go where they choose," the admiral said. 
His remarks were greeted enthusiastically by some, but many sailors listened with arms folded and expressions of skepticism or uninterest. Some may have been puzzled by his expression of concern about freedom of worship in Iraq, a right that is well protected among the Muslim population.
"It doesn't really matter what they say," said Eli Muhammad, a 30-year-old electronics technician who works to maintain the carrier's radar system. "Whatever happens, whatever the president tells us to do, we'll do, so we can go home."
The imminence of war touched off final acts of political desperation by Arab leaders who had been counting on the legal authority of a United Nations Security Council resolution to ease the political backlash of a highly unpopular war. 
In Cairo, President Hosni Mubarak warned Egyptians to brace themselves for regional upheaval.
"As an Arab nation, we must continue to exert all efforts to rescue the people of Iraq from annihilation, the land of Iraq from division and the resources of the Arab nation from being tampered with," he said in a nationally televised address.
In Bahrain, King Hamad made a last-ditch appeal, as other Arab leaders had before him, for Mr. Hussein to go into exile. He even offered his own tiny nation, home to the American Navy in the gulf, as a refuge for the Iraqi leader.
Saudi Arabia, whose leaders in January had first privately advocated an arrangement to offer Mr. Hussein exile as a strategy to avert war, issued a statement today saying reports that it was pursuing such a strategy were "baseless." 
Late today, as troops moved into attack positions, the Third Infantry Division, which will lead the thrust toward Baghdad, readied itself by clearing sand from personal gear and weaponry. A sandstorm that set up a pall of dust over the region dissipated as the day wore on and the army shook itself off and carried on.
"There's a heightened sense of anticipation," said Col. William F. Grimsley, commander of the first brigade. "The trick is not to let it become overwhelming."
While the soldiers readied their gear, logistics experts fretted over the problem of creating a network to supply a fast-moving force that consumes 15 million gallons of fuel a day.
Maj. Gen. Dennis K. Jackson, director of logistics and engineering for Central Command, said in an interview today that it was possible that the advance of armored columns and helicopter-borne troops would be limited by the ability of fuel tankers to keep up.
But Colonel Grimsley had another concern. As night fell on the desert and the swirling plumes of dust settled, what was missing, he said, was any sign of defensive preparation by Iraqi forces on the other side of the border.
"Surprisingly," he said, "we have seen very little over there since the president's speech."

(Vincent Laforet/The New York Times); Maj. Frank McClary of the Third Infantry Division scanned the demilitarized zone along the border between Iraq and Kuwait yesterday. (Scott Nelson/Getty Images)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: CALIFORNIA; 
Approach of War Reveals An Alienation in California

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 

 BODY:
As Americans braced in recent days for a war against Iraq, many Californians were feeling strangely out of it. The great expanse between the coasts appeared ever vaster. The sense of threat, so acute in the East, was real but less immediate here.
 The University of California Board of Regents canceled a meeting in San Francisco today because of "concerns about travel," but the National Guard soldiers posted at the Golden Gate Bridge amounted to a small fraction of the deployments in New York or Washington. 
 Even when the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences decided to forgo the traditional red carpet entrance to Sunday's Oscar ceremonies in Los Angeles, officials said it was more a matter of wartime propriety than battle-eve jitters. 
From stockbrokers in San Francisco to software engineers in Silicon Valley to studio executives in Los Angeles, many Californians were puzzled by the connection between the terror attacks of Sept. 11 and the danger posed by Saddam Hussein, something taken for granted in many other parts of the country.
"I am hoping the administration has so much more knowledge that it can justify its actions, because on the face of it, I can't see a reason for doing this," said David Randall, a philanthropic fund-raiser in San Francisco.
"There are many good reasons to get rid of Saddam," Mr. Randall said. "But when did the events of Sept. 11 get transformed into going to war with Iraq? Why war with this one country, right now? I can't figure out how we got to this point."
That confusion is evident even though California has contributed more men and women to the call-up of reservists and National Guard forces than any other state. The defense industry pumps about $30 billion a year into California's economy. And while 29 military bases were closed in the 1990's, 61 installations remain in use statewide.
But California's isolation from Washington, geographically and, in recent years, politically, has helped foster a sense of alienation. The state, which had such an affinity for Bill Clinton, voted decisively against President Bush in 2000.
"There is a growing disbelief among Californians that the White House is really representing their views and interests," said Mark Baldassare, the director of research at the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan group in San Francisco that recently conducted an opinion poll of public attitudes toward President Bush, the war, which was then imminent, and other issues.
Mr. Baldassare said this attitude had been building for several years, starting with the state's energy crisis and the administration's handling of it. "Because of this disconnect," he said, "many Californians don't give the president the benefit of the doubt on the issue of Iraq any more than they give the president the benefit of the doubt on whether we really need to do away with taxes on dividends or whether a tax cut will lead to a better economy."
In fact, many people acknowledged that they might feel differently if a Democrat were leading them into battle. "I was wondering if I would feel more comfortable if it were Bill Clinton and Al Gore saying we needed to do this now, and I think I would," said Felicia Marcus, who was the regional administrator in California for the United States Environmental Protection Agency in the Clinton administration.
In some lunchtime and water-cooler chatter there has even been longing for President Clinton, a Hollywood favorite, who, the reasoning goes, would never have allowed a war to play havoc with Oscar night, one of the state's most hallowed traditions.
Some say the chasm in attitudes between East and West is new only in its intensity. Many residents have always enjoyed thinking of themselves as different from the rest of the country, especially those in the Hollywood pop-culture factory. 
"Californians love that sense of distinctiveness," said Peter Bart, editor of Variety. "We're not going to see the 60's again, but I think we are going to see a lot of rebellion against the mandates of Washington. This is an unpredictable and bizarre place, and I think we are definitely heading into an intensely politicized time in Hollywood."
Since many of the most prominent antiwar spokesmen in recent months have been Hollywood celebrities, this has further bolstered California's self-image and the state's image around the country as the epicenter of antiwar sentiment. The Academy Awards on Sunday night, if they come off as planned, will probably only harden that perception.
Robert Greenwald, a Hollywood producer and director who helped found Artists United to Win Without War, said a number of celebrities had committed to wearing antiwar pins at the awards, including Ben Affleck, Kirsten Dunst, Jake and Maggie Gyllenhaal, Dustin Hoffman, Jessica Lange, Meryl Streep and the entire U2 rock band.
Doubting in California, however, is not the sole province of Hollywood, or even of the career leftists and peace advocates who were among those blocking streets today in downtown San Francisco. The police said one peace demonstrator died when he jumped from the Golden Gate Bridge in an apparent suicide.
"There is less fear of conforming here," said Warren Langley, the former president of the Pacific Stock Exchange. "People are more willing to question what the president says."
Mr. Langley found himself in an unusual place last week: At the San Francisco jail after being arrested for blocking the entrance to the exchange in an antiwar protest. The blockade was his first act of civil disobedience -- he even attended an evening of training in preparation -- but probably not his last, he said.
"It has been 30 years since I even had a traffic ticket," said Mr. Langley, who led the exchange between 1996 and 1999 and was arrested. He also happens to be a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who was once an instructor at the Air Force Academy, "We are not going to stop this war. I know that," he said. "But I have to find a way I can help others, help us as Americans become good citizens of the world again."
It is also the case, some say, that Californians do not feel as unsafe as people in other parts of the country.
"We didn't feel or see any of the shocks of Sept. 11 except on television," said Steven Maviglio, a spokesman for Gov. Gray Davis. "We don't have anything like they do in Washington, where trucks are rolled up on the grounds of the Washington Monument, or where there was a mad rush for duct tape."
Robert J. Waste, a professor of public policy at California State University, Sacramento, said the state's ethnic and racial diversity and large immigrant population also played a part, making it distinctive -- and less receptive to the president's message.
"The deepest penetration of the president's case for war is among white males and Republicans," Professor Waste said. "That is not the whole of California."
An opinion poll conducted last week in the Sacramento area by the university's Institute for Social Research pointed to diversity as a determining factor on the war question.
The poll showed that support for a war was weakest among racial minorities and strongest among men. In El Dorado County, a mostly white and conservative area in the Sierra Nevada, 65 percent of respondents favored military action. In Sacramento County, where there are large immigrant and minority communities, support was 49 percent.
"California is more diverse than the rest of the country, and this diversity is the hardest part of the sell for war," Professor Waste said. 
Mr. Baldassare of the Public Policy Institute said an opinion poll conducted last month by the group showed that the troubled California economy had colored the views of residents about many subjects, like the popularity of Governor Davis (he registered a 60 percent disapproval rating; to the state's future (only 28 percent said the state was headed in the right direction), to President Bush's handling of the situation in Iraq (50 percent said they disapproved, while 46 percent approved).
"People are in a kind of nervous mood I haven't seen since the early 1990's," Mr. Baldassare said. "They are very wary of the state's vulnerable position economically right now. That has made people cautious about things they might view as extraneous events, including going to war with Iraq."
It is not just Californians who view themselves as different and apart. So do some of their visitors.
David Houston, a self-described conservative from Tampa Bay, Fla., who was on a vacation in California, said many people in the state seemed out of touch with the rest of America. "It is obvious a lot of people here are against the war," he said. "Of course, if a lot of them went to visit the World Trade Center, they might think differently."
